title: Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, Inc. v. County of Aiken
description: The court construes S.C. Code Ann. section 38-53-100(D) to authorize the clerk of court to collect only $150 per year per individual rather than $150 per year per license held by a bondsman.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, Inc.,
        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
County of Aiken and Liz Godard, Clerk of Court for Aiken County,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3621
Heard March 12, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  7, 2003

REVERSED


  
    
      
Robert T. Williams, Sr., of Lexington, for Appellant.
W. Lawrence Brown and Robert M. Bell, both of Langley, for Respondents.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds 
  brought an action seeking to enjoin the Aiken County Clerk of Court from assessing 
  a $150 fee for each license their bondsmen possessed.Â  After a non-jury proceeding, 
  the circuit court refused to enjoin the Clerk of Court from charging the fee.Â  
  We reverse.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds (â€œCarolinaâ€) 
  is a corporation organized, incorporated, and doing business in Aiken County 
  pursuant to the laws of South Carolina.Â Â  Carolina employs several surety bondsmen 
  who operate as agents for multiple insurance companies that guarantee the bonds 
  they write.Â  The bondsmen have an independent license for each insurance company 
  for which they are an agent.Â  These separate licenses are filed with the Aiken 
  County Clerk of Court.Â  The Clerk of Court is required to process, file, and 
  record additional documents for each filed license.Â  The Clerk of Court collects 
  licensing fees pursuant to South Carolina law.Â  The Clerk of Court collects 
  $150 dollars annually for each license held by Carolinaâ€™s bondsmen.
Carolina filed an action seeking to enjoin 
  the Clerk of Court from collecting $150 for each individual license held by 
  a bondsman, arguing South Carolina law only empowers the Clerk of Court to charge 
  $150 a year per individual holding a license, not for each individual license.Â  
  The parties agreed to a non-jury trial on the pleadings and stipulated to the 
  facts of the case.Â  The circuit court denied the injunction, ruling that the 
  statute enables the Clerk of Court to collect $150 for each license held by 
  a bondsman.
ISSUE
Does S.C. Code Ann. section 38-53-100(D) 
  authorize the Clerk of Court to collect only $150 per year per individual or 
  $150 per year per license held by that individual?
LAW/ANALYSIS
Carolina argues the circuit court erred 
  when it denied its action to enjoin the Aiken County Clerk of Court because 
  S.C. Code Ann. section 38-53-100(D) only entitles the Clerk of Court to collect 
  $150 dollars for each bondsman who holds a license and not $150 for each license 
  a bondsman holds.Â  We agree.
I.Â  Statutory Construction
The cardinal rule of statutory interpretation 
  is to ascertain the intent of the legislature.Â  State v. Scott, 351 S.C. 
  584, 588, 571 S.E.2d 700, 702 (2002); City of Camden v. Brassell, 326 
  S.C. 556, 560, 486 S.E.2d 492, 494 (Ct. App. 1997); see also Olson 
  v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 344 S.C. 194, 205, 544 S.E.2d 38, 44 
  (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThe quintessence of statutory construction is legislative 
  intent.â€).Â  A statute should be given a reasonable and practical construction 
  consistent with the purpose and policy expressed in the statute.Â  Davis v. 
  NationsCredit Fin. Servs. Corp., 326 S.C. 83, 484 S.E.2d 471 (1997); Daisy 
  Outdoor Adver. Co. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 352 S.C. 113, 120, 
  572 S.E.2d 462, 466 (Ct. App. 2002); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 
  S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  All rules of statutory construction 
  are subservient to the one that legislative intent must prevail if it can be 
  reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be construed 
  in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.Â  Ray Bell Constr. Co. 
  v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville County, 331 S.C. 19, 501 S.E.2d 725 (1998); 
  State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 574 S.E.2d 203 (Ct. App. 2002); State 
  v. Hudson, 336 S.C. 237, 519 S.E.2d 577 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The determination 
  of legislative intent is a matter of law.Â  Charleston County Parks & 
  Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 459 S.E.2d 841 (1995); Olson, 
  344 S.C. at 207, 544 S.E.2d at 45.
The legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained 
  primarily from the plain language of the statute.Â  Morgan, 352 S.C. at 
  366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Stephen, 324 S.C. at 339, 478 S.E.2d at 77.Â  
  The language must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject 
  matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  Hitachi Data Sys. v. Leatherman, 
  309 S.C. 174, 420 S.E.2d 843 (1992); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d 
  at 206; Hudson, 336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 582.Â  The courtâ€™s primary 
  function in interpreting a statute is to ascertain the intent of the General 
  Assembly.Â  Smith, 350 S.C. at 87, 564 S.E.2d at 361.Â  A statute must 
  receive a practical and reasonable interpretation consistent with the â€œdesignâ€ 
  of the legislature.Â  Id.Â  "Once the legislature has made [a] choice, 
  there is no room for the courts to impose a different judgment based upon their 
  own notions of public policy."Â  South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. 
  Co. v. Mumford, 299 S.C. 14, 19, 382 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. App. 1989).
When faced with an undefined statutory 
  term, the court must interpret the term in accord with its usual and customary 
  meaning.Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 
  504 S.E.2d 117 (1998); Adoptive Parents v. Biological Parents, 315 S.C. 
  535, 446 S.E.2d 404 (1994); Hudson, 336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 581; 
  see also Santee Cooper Resort v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 
  298 S.C. 179, 184, 379 S.E.2d 119, 122 (1989) (â€œWords used in a statute should 
  be taken in their ordinary and popular significance unless there is something 
  in the statute requiring a different interpretation.â€).Â  Dictionaries can be 
  helpful tools during the initial stages of legal research for the purpose of 
  defining statutory terms.Â  Heilker v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals for City of Beaufort, 
  346 S.C. 401, 552 S.E.2d 42 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The terms must be construed in 
  context and their meaning determined by looking at the other terms used in the 
  statute.Â  S. Mut. Church Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Windstorm & Hail 
  Underwriting Assâ€™n, 306 S.C. 339, 412 S.E.2d 377 (1991); Hudson, 
  336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 581.Â  Courts should consider not merely the language 
  of the particular clause being construed, but the word and its meaning in conjunction 
  with the purpose of the whole statute and the policy of the law.Â  Whitner 
  v. State, 328 S.C. 1, 492 S.E.2d 777 (1997); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 
  366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; see also Stephen, 324 S.C. at 340, 478 
  S.E.2d at 77 (Statutory provisions should be given reasonable and practical 
  construction consistent with the purpose of the entire act).Â  Statutes must 
  be read as a whole and sections which are part of the same general statutory 
  scheme must be construed together and given effect, if it can be done by any 
  reasonable construction.Â  Higgins v. State, 307 S.C. 446, 415 S.E.2d 
  799 (1992).
If a statuteâ€™s language is unambiguous and clear, 
  there is no need to employ the rules of statutory construction and this Court 
  has no right to look for or impose another meaning.Â  Paschal v. State Election 
  Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 454 S.E.2d 890 (1995); Cowan v. Allstate Ins. Co., 
  351 S.C. 626, 631, 571 S.E.2d 715, 717 (Ct. App. 2002); Olson, 344 S.C. 
  at 207, 544 S.E.2d at 45; see also Brassell, 326 S.C. at 561, 
  486 S.E.2d at 495 (â€œWhere the language of the statute is clear and explicit, 
  the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it which are not 
  in the legislatureâ€™s language.â€).Â  When the terms of a statute are clear, the 
  court must apply those terms according to their literal meaning.Â  Cooper 
  v. Moore, 351 S.C. 207, 212, 569 S.E.2d 330, 332 (2002); Holley v. Mount 
  Vernon Mills, Inc., 312 S.C. 320, 440 S.E.2d 373 (1994); Carolina Alliance 
  for Fair Employment v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 
  337 S.C. 476, 523 S.E.2d 795 (Ct. App. 1999); see also Parsons v. 
  Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366 (1995) (Where the terms of 
  a relevant statute are clear, there is no room for construction.).Â  What a legislature 
  says in the text of a statute is considered the best evidence of the legislative 
  intent or will.Â  Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 
  542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The words of a statute must be given their 
  plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction.Â  
  Durham v. United Cos. Fin. Corp., 331 S.C. 600, 503 S.E.2d 465 (1998); 
  Adkins v. Comcar Indus., Inc., 323 S.C. 409, 475 S.E.2d 762 (1996); Worsley 
  Cos. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 351 S.C. 97, 
  102, 567 S.E.2d 907, 910 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Timmons v. South 
  Carolina Tricentennial Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 378, 175 S.E.2d 805 (1970) (Where 
  the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite 
  the statute and inject matters into it that are not in the legislatureâ€™s language.).Â  
  Under the plain meaning rule, it is not the courtâ€™s place to change the meaning 
  of a clear and unambiguous statute.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 533 
  S.E.2d 578 (2000); Bayle, 344 S.C. at 122, 542 S.E.2d at 739.
If the language of an act gives rise to doubt or 
  uncertainty as to legislative intent, the construing court may search for that 
  intent beyond the borders of the act itself.Â  Morgan, 352 S.C. at 367, 
  574 S.E.2d at 207; see also Wade v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 
  224, 229, 559 S.E.2d 586, 588 (2002) (â€œ[W]here a statute is ambiguous, the Court 
  must construe the terms of the statute.â€).Â  An ambiguity in a statute should 
  be resolved in favor of a just, beneficial, and equitable operation of the law.Â  
  Hudson, 336 S.C. at 247, 519 S.E.2d at 582; Brassell, 326 S.C. 
  at 561; 486 S.E.2d at 495; City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 Blue 
  Mazda Truck, 330 S.C. 371, 498 S.E.2d 894 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In construing 
  a statute, the court looks to the language as a whole in light of its manifest 
  purpose.Â  State v. Dawkins, 352 S.C. 162, 573 S.E.2d 783 (2002); Adams 
  v. Texfi Indus., 320 S.C. 213, 464 S.E.2d 109 (1995); Brassell, 326 
  S.C. at 560, 486 S.E.2d at 494.Â  
II.Â  Section 38-53-100(D)   
The statutory provision in question reads:

[A] professional or surety bondsman shall pay to the clerk 
  of court of his home county the sum of one hundred fifty dollars annually for 
  each licensee to be paid directly to and retained by the clerk.Â  In addition, 
  each bondsman and runner shall pay to any other county where he is doing business, 
  the sum of one hundred dollars to be paid and retained by the clerk.Â  The fee 
  must be paid annually and directly to the clerk of court who shall deposit it 
  in an account maintained by the clerk.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-53-100(D) (2002).
Although not binding or controlling, this 
  court gives deference to the opinion of a state agency charged with the duty 
  and responsibility of enforcing a state statute.Â  The South Carolina Department 
  of Insurance is given general oversight responsibility in regard to the licensing 
  of a bondsman.Â  Willie Seawright, the Licensing Coordinator for the South Carolina 
  Department of Insurance, who is not an attorney, has offered his interpretation 
  that â€œ[t]his charge can only be assessed one time a year, regardless of the 
  number of licenses that a bondsman register [sic] in your county.â€Â  Additionally, 
  David K. Avant, Assistant Attorney General, opined: â€œIt is also my opinion that 
  each person licensed under Chapter 53 of Title 38 is subjected to one fee under 
  Section 38-53-100(D), no matter how many licenses that person holds.â€
South Carolina has long recognized the 
  rule that an opinion or construction of a statute by an agency that is in charge 
  of enforcing the statute should be given great deference.Â  "[T]he construction 
  of a statute by the agency charged with its administration will be accorded 
  the most respectful consideration and will not be overruled absent compelling 
  reasons."Â  Brown v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 
  348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414 (2002) (quoting Dunton v. South Carolina 
  Bd. of Examiners in Optometry, 291 S.C. 221, 223, 353 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987)); 
  see also Nucor Steel, a Div. of Nucor Corp. v. South Carolina Public 
  Serv. Commâ€™n, 310 S.C. 539, 543, 426 S.E.2d 319, 321 (1992) (â€œWhere an agency 
  is charged with the execution of a statute, the agency's interpretation should 
  not be overruled without cogent reason.â€); Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 337 S.C. 
  476, 523 S.E.2d 795 (Ct. App. 1999).
The circuit court established that â€œlicenseeâ€ meant 
  â€œone to whom a license is granted.â€Â  The circuit court also noted that the legislature 
  did not intend to apply the fee to the individual bondsman or it would have 
  used the term â€œbondsmanâ€ exactly as it did in the following sentence of the 
  statute.Â  In examining the legislative purpose of the statute, the circuit court 
  found the intent of the legislature was to

create a system whereby fees would be generated to offset 
  the expense of registering and monitoring the qualifications of bail bondsmen 
  and runners in a given county. . . . Additionally, the court finds that the 
  increased time and effort required to maintain records and supervise bondsmen 
  with multiple licenses warrants a separate charge for each license that the 
  bondsman holds in the county.Â  

The circuit court felt such a ruling was equitable because 
  â€œ[a]llowing the Clerk to collect only one fee for [the] registration of multiple 
  licenses for an individual bondsman would not be logical or fair.Â  Bondsmen 
  with multiple licenses would pay a proportionately smaller fee for registration 
  of each license than would a bondsman with a single license.â€
We disagree with the circuit courtâ€™s interpretation 
  of the statute.Â  The term licensee encapsulates both bondsmen and runners as 
  evidenced by the second passage in the statute.Â  The statute directs a bondsman 
  operating in another county to pay a $100 fee without regard to the number of 
  licenses he or she holds.Â  If the legislature had intended for the fee to be 
  $150 for each license, the legislature could have articulated this requisite 
  with exactitude.Â  Instead, the statute as written requires a licensee to pay 
  $150 to the clerk without specific reference to any number of licenses a bondsman 
  or a runner holds.Â  We acknowledge that the legislative purpose of the statute 
  is to obtain fees to defray the costs of monitoring and licensing bondsmen.Â  
  However, the legislature, in penning this statute, had sound reasons for circumscription 
  of the fee to the licensee.Â  An obvious legislative policy response 
  was that an open-ended per license charge would make the process expensive for 
  a bondsman to enter and remain in the profession.Â  In any event, it is not necessary 
  to bestow the rules of statutory interpretation because it is clear that the 
  term licensee encompasses bondsman and the statute only orders 
  the licensee to pay $150 to the clerk without any mention of the number of individual 
  licenses the licensee holds.
CONCLUSION
Utilizing the â€œplain meaningâ€ rule of 
  statutory construction, we hold that S.C. Code Ann. section 38-53-100(D) requires 
  a bondsman to pay the $150 fee as a licensee and does not require 
  an additional fee for each license the bondsman owns.Â  The circuit court erred 
  when it denied Carolinaâ€™s action to enjoin the Clerk from assessing a $150 fee 
  for each license a bondsman has.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court 
  is 
 REVERSED.
 HUFF, J., and MOREHEAD, Acting Judge, 
  concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jimmy Dodd, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3622
Heard February 25, 2003 â€“ Filed April 7, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey, 
  of the SC Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief 
  Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General 
  Charles H. Richardson, Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, of Columbia;Â  
  and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg; for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Jimmy Dodd was indicted for 
  the armed robbery of a convenience store.Â  The trial judge denied his motion 
  for directed verdict, and the jury found Dodd guilty of armed robbery.Â  He was 
  sentenced to life without parole.Â  Dodd appeals, arguing the state failed to 
  prove the corpus delecti [1]  of armed robbery aliunde [2]  his confession.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
At trial, the State produced evidence that Dodd entered 
  a Liâ€™l Cricket store and told the clerk to get down on the floor or he would 
  kill her. The clerk testified that she did not know what Dodd was going to kill 
  her with and that the only thing she saw in his hand was a rolled up t-shirt. 
  The State also presented the following statement from the defendant:

I just want to see that lady at Liâ€™L Cricket and hug 
  her and apologize to her for coming in the store and robbing her on Monday night.Â  
  I did not mean to hurt her and never pointed the gun at her.Â  I just 
  threatened her to scare her.Â  I took my shirt off right before I walked in the 
  store because I was hot and was on drugs.Â  Iâ€™ve had a drug problem and I feel 
  like it controls everything I do. (emphasis added)

The defense moved for a directed verdict, and the motion 
  was denied. The jury found Dodd guilty of armed robbery. 
DISCUSSION
Dodd argues that his motion for 
  directed verdict should have been granted because the Stateâ€™s evidence failed 
  to provide sufficient evidence aliunde his confession of the corpus 
  delicti of armed robbery.
The â€œcorroboration 
  ruleâ€ requires that extra-judicial confessions of a defendant be corroborated 
  by proof aliunde of the corpus delicti.Â  State v. Osborne, 
  335 S.C. 172, 175, 516 S.E.2d 201, 202 (1999).Â Â Â  â€œThe [rule] is satisfied if 
  the State provides sufficient independent evidence which serves to corroborate 
  the defendantâ€™s extra-judicial statements and, together with such statements, 
  permits a reasonable belief that the crime occurred.â€Â  Id. at 180, 516 
  S.E.2d at 205.Â  
â€œ[G]enerally speaking, 
  the term â€˜corpus delictiâ€™ means, when applied to any particular offense, 
  that the specific crime has actually been committed.â€Â  State v. Teal, 
  225 S.C. 472, 474, 82 S.E.2d 787, 788 (1954) (citations omitted).Â  The State 
  may prove the corpus delicti of armed robbery by establishing that a 
  robbery was committed and either one of two additional elements: (1) that the 
  robber was armed with a deadly weapon or (2) that the robber alleged he was 
  armed with a deadly weapon, either by action or words, while using a representation 
  of a deadly weapon or any object.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-330(A) 
  (Supp. 2001); State v. Muldrow, 348 S.C. 264, 268-269, 559 S.E.2d 847, 
  849 (2002).Â  
Considering the second prong 
  first, we note that although Dodd threatened to kill the store clerk, he never 
  alleged that he was armed nor used an item to represent a deadly weapon.Â  Therefore, 
  this prong of the statute was not satisfied.
The question, then, is whether 
  Doddâ€™s admission that he had a gun coupled with the clerkâ€™s testimony that he 
  threatened to kill her, satisfied the first prong of the statute, which requires 
  that the State prove Dodd was armed with a deadly weapon.Â  We believe that it 
  does.
Once Dodd confessed to having 
  a gun during the commission of his robbery, the State only needed to present 
  sufficient independent evidence to corroborate those statements so that a jury 
  could reasonably believe an armed robbery occurred.Â  See Osborne. 
  335 S.C. at 180, 516 S.E.2d at 205; see also State v. Trexler, 
  342 S.E.2d 878, 880 (N.C. 1986) (finding that the corroboration rule only requires 
  the Stateâ€™s independent evidence to â€œtouch or be concerned with the corpus 
  delictiâ€ and, standing alone, it need not prove any element of the crime).Â  

Here, Doddâ€™s confession to having 
  a gun was corroborated by his threat to the clerk that he would kill her if 
  she did not do as he told her.Â  Although his threat, unaccompanied by any representation 
  of a deadly weapon, would not independently be sufficient to establish 
  the element of a deadly weapon, the threat is sufficient to corroborate 
  Doddâ€™s confession to being armed.Â  See Muldrow, 348 S.C. 264 at 
  268, 559 S.E.2d at 849 (holding that the State did not sufficiently prove the 
  defendant was armed when the only evidence against him was that he handed a 
  clerk a note that read: â€œGive me all your cash or Iâ€™ll shoot you,â€ and there 
  was no confession to having a gun).Â  When there is any evidence tending to establish 
  the corpus delicti of a crime, it is the trial judgeâ€™s duty to pass that 
  question to the jury.Â  See Osborne, 335 S.C. at 180, 516 S.E.2d 
  at 205; State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 381, 385, 468 S.E.2d 656, 658 (1996).Â  
  Therefore, the trial judge did not err in denying Doddâ€™s motion for a directed 
  verdict.
Accordingly, 
  Doddâ€™s conviction for armed robbery is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY 
  and SHULER, JJ., concur.

    Law Dictionary 344 (6th ed. 1990).

 
   [2] â€œFrom another source.â€ Id. 
    at 73.

        of Thomas Edison Fields, Deceased,

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
J. Marvin Mullis, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Julius W. McKay, II and Kathleen Devereaux Schultz, 
  both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Vergie Fields brought an 
  action individually and on behalf of her husbandâ€™s estate against Orangeburg 
  Regional Medical Center (â€œhospitalâ€) and Dr. Simons Hane for wrongful death 
  and medical malpractice. Fields claimed the hospital and Hane were negligent 
  and committed medical malpractice leading to her husbandâ€™s death.Â  During the 
  trial, the circuit court excluded the testimony of one of Fieldsâ€™s experts regarding 
  his credentials.Â  Additionally, the circuit court refused to allow Fields to 
  use a treatise to cross-examine Hane.Â  Fields argues these are reversible errors 
  which entitle her to a new trial. Â We reverse and remand for a new trial.Â  
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On September 14, 1994, Thomas Fields called 
  his wife, Vergie Fields, at her job and asked her to take him to the hospital 
  because he was experiencing severe chest pains, which radiated down into both 
  arms.Â  Fields was a forty-nine-year-old smoker with a family history of heart 
  disease.Â  In 1976, Fields became disabled when he received severe injuries from 
  falling at work.Â  From 1976 to 1994, Fields suffered from a variety of physical 
  and psychiatric ailments and made numerous trips to the emergency room at the 
  hospital.Â  He was hospitalized several times to treat his psychiatric problems 
  during this period.
Fields had previously experienced bouts 
  of chest pain.Â  From 1981 until his death in 1994, the hospital performed fifteen 
  EKGs on Fields.Â  In 1993, Fieldsâ€™s doctor arranged a cardiac catheterization 
  to evaluate whether Fields had coronary artery disease.Â  The results were negative 
  and were in Fieldsâ€™s files at the hospitalâ€™s emergency room.
When Fields arrived at the hospitalâ€™s 
  emergency room on September 14, 1994, Dr. Fisher saw him.Â  Fisher ran an EKG 
  and ordered a chest X-Ray, which read normal.Â  Fisher diagnosed Fields with 
  gastrointestinal reflux and chronic back pain.Â  Fisher prescribed Fields a G.I. 
  cocktail, which was administered in the emergency room, and advised Fields to 
  consult his family doctor.Â  Before Fields left, he informed Fisher the G.I. 
  cocktail had provided some relief.Â  Fields saw his psychiatrist the same week 
  and made an appointment to see his family physician the following week.
On September 18, 1994, Fields awoke during 
  the early morning hours once again hurting from severe chest pain, which radiated 
  down both arms.Â  Fields went to the hospitalâ€™s emergency room in the middle 
  of the night where Hane examined him.Â  When Fields arrived, he asked Hane for 
  another G.I. cocktail.Â  Fields was in so much pain on this occasion that he 
  was sobbing.Â  Hane ran an EKG and reviewed the results from the X-Ray and EKG 
  from September 14th as well as the other records contained within 
  Fieldsâ€™s file, including the results of the 1993 catheterization.Â  The hospital 
  placed Fields on a heart monitor for approximately forty-five minutes to an 
  hour.Â  The monitor kept track of Fieldsâ€™s cardiac activity during that time, 
  all of which appeared normal.Â  Hane diagnosed Fields with histrionics and gastrointestinal 
  pain.Â  Fields received a G.I. cocktail and a shot of Vistaril and Nubain to 
  treat the histrionics. Â Hane released Fields at 3:50 a.m. and instructed 
  him to return to the emergency room if the condition persisted or worsened and 
  to consult his family physician.
When Fields and his wife left the 
  hospital, his pain intensified one or two miles away from the hospital.Â  They 
  stopped for a drink at a gas station and decided to drive to the Palmetto Baptist 
  Hospital in downtown Columbia, about forty-five minutes away.Â  When they reached 
  Baptist, Vergie Fields informed the emergency room staff that she thought her 
  husband was having a heart attack.Â  The Baptist emergency physicians performed 
  an EKG which confirmed Fields was having a heart attack.Â  The cardiologist at 
  Baptist decided not to treat Fields with clot buster drugs but instead had Fields 
  transported by helicopter to Providence Hospital to have an emergency cardiac 
  catheterization performed.Â  While undergoing the procedure, one of Fieldsâ€™s 
  coronary arteries dissected, a known risk of the procedure.Â  He died shortly 
  thereafter.
Vergie Fields brought a wrongful death 
  suit against the hospital andÂ  Hane, contending they were negligent and committed 
  medical malpractice by failing to admit Fields on September 18th.Â  
  The case went to trial, and the jury returned a verdict in favor of the hospital 
  and Hane.Â  Vergie Fields appeals, alleging the circuit court erred by not admitting 
  testimony regarding the credentials of one of her expert witnesses and failing 
  to allow her to use a treatise during Haneâ€™s cross-examination.Â  After Vergie 
  Fields filed this appeal, she reached a settlement with the hospital.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Expert Witness Qualifications
In order for a plaintiff to recover for 
  medical malpractice, he must illustrate the physician failed to exercise the 
  degree of care and skill which is ordinarily employed by the profession under 
  similar conditions and like circumstances.Â  Jernigan v. King, 312 S.C. 
  331, 333, 440 S.E.2d 379, 381 (Ct. App. 1993); Bonaparte v. Floyd, 291 
  S.C. 427, 434, 354 S.E.2d 40, 45 (Ct. App. 1987); Welch v. Whitaker, 
  282 S.C. 251, 258, 317 S.E.2d 758, 763 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  This must be established 
  by expert testimony unless the subject matter is of common knowledge or experience.Â  
  Bramlette v. Charter-Med.-Columbia, 302 S.C. 68, 72, 393 S.E.2d 914, 
  916 (1990); Pederson v. Gould, 288 S.C. 141, 142, 341 S.E.2d 633, 634 
  (1986); Green v. Lilliewood, 272 S.C. 186, 192, 249 S.E.2d 910, 913 (1978); 
  Bonaparte, 291 S.C. at 434, 354 S.E.2d at 45; 61 Am. Jur. 2d Physicians, 
  Surgeons Â§ 318 (2002).Â  
Qualification of an expert and the admission or 
  exclusion of his testimony is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial 
  court, whose decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  
  Payton v. Kearse, 329 S.C. 51, 60-61, 495 S.E.2d 205, 211 (1998); Means 
  v. Gates, 348 S.C. 161, 166, 558 S.E.2d 921, 923 (Ct. App. 2001); Small 
  v. Pioneer Mach., Inc., 329 S.C. 448, 469-70, 494 S.E.2d 835, 846 (Ct. App. 
  1997).Â  To warrant reversal, the appellant must prove both the error of the 
  ruling and resulting prejudice.Â  Burroughs v. Worsham, 352 S.C. 382, 
  391, 574 S.E.2d 215, 219 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when 
  there is an error of law or factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support.Â  
  Fontaine v. Peitz, 291 S.C. 536, 538, 354 S.E.2d 565, 566 (1987); Burroughs, 
  352 S.C. at 391, 574 S.E.2d at 219; Hedgepath v. Amer. Tel. & Tel. Co., 
  348 S.C. 340, 353, 559 S.E.2d 327, 334 (Ct. App. 2001); Bayle v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 128, 542 S.E.2d 736, 742 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
  A courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of an expertâ€™s testimony constitutes an 
  abuse of discretion where the ruling is manifestly arbitrary, unreasonable, 
  or unfair.Â  Gates, 348 S.C. at 166, 558 S.E.2d at 924.Â  The appellant 
  must show prejudice for the Court of Appeals to reverse a judgment.Â  Hanahan 
  v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 156, 485 S.E.2d 903, 911 (1997); Commerce Ctr. 
  of Greenville v. W. Powers McElveen & Assocs., Inc., 347 S.C. 545, 559, 
  556 S.E.2d 718, 726 (Ct. App. 2001).
To be competent as an expert, a witness must have 
  acquired, by reason of study or experience, or both, such knowledge and skill 
  in a business, profession, or science that he is better qualified than the fact 
  finder to form an opinion.Â  Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 
  S.C. 248, 252-53, 487 S.E.2d 596, 598 (1997); Ott v. Pittman, 320 S.C. 
  72, 76, 463 S.E.2d 101, 104 (Ct. App. 1995); Hall v. Clarendon Outdoor Adver., 
  Inc., 311 S.C. 185, 188, 428 S.E.2d 1, 2 (Ct. App. 1993); Rule 702, SCRE 
  (â€œIf scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier 
  of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness 
  qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education, 
  may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.â€).Â  It is incumbent 
  that the party offering the expert manifest that the witness possesses the necessary 
  learning, skill, or practical experience to enable him to give opinion testimony.Â  
  State v. Myers, 301 S.C. 251, 391 S.E.2d 551 (1990); Thomas Sand Co. 
  v. Colonial Pipeline Co., 349 S.C. 402, 410-11, 563 S.E.2d 109, 113 (Ct. 
  App. 2002).Â  The test is a relative one, depending on the particular witnessâ€™s 
  reference to the subject.Â  Gooding, 326 S.C. at 253, 487 S.E.2d at 598; 
  Lee v. Suess, 318 S.C. 283, 285, 457 S.E.2d 344, 346 (1995).Â  An expert 
  is not limited to any class of persons acting professionally.Â  Gooding, 
  326 S.C. at 253, 487 S.E.2d at 598; Botehlo v. Bycura, 282 S.C. 578, 
  320 S.E.2d 59 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  There is no exact requirement concerning how 
  knowledge or skill must be acquired. Â Honea v. Prior, 295 S.C. 526, 369 
  S.E.2d 846 (Ct. App. 1988).
Usually, if opinion testimony is offered by a physician 
  or surgeon, his competency to testify as an expert is sufficiently established 
  by the fact that he has been duly licensed to practice medicine or surgery.Â  
  State v. Moorer, 241 S.C. 487, 129 S.E.2d 330 (1963) (overruled on other 
  grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991)); Hill 
  v. Carolina Power & Light Co., 204 S.C. 83, 28 S.E.2d 545 (1943).Â  A 
  physician or surgeon is not incompetent to testify as an expert merely because 
  he is not a specialist in the particular branch of his profession involved in 
  the case.Â  Creed v. City of Columbia, 310 S.C. 342, 426 S.E.2d 785 (1993).Â  
  The fact that the physician is not a specialist in the particular area affects 
  only the weight of the witnessâ€™s testimony and affords no basis for completely 
  rejecting it.Â  Hill, 204 S.C. at 109, 28 S.E.2d at 555; Brown v. LaFrance 
  Indus., 286 S.C. 319, 333 S.E.2d 348 (Ct. App. 1985).
A proper technique for attacking an expertâ€™s testimony 
  is to impeach him on his limited experience in the area about which he has testified.Â  
  Any defects in the amount and quality of education or experience go to the weight 
  to be accorded the expertâ€™s testimony, but not its admissibility.Â  State 
  v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 505, 435 S.E.2d 859, 861 (1993); State v. 
  Myers, 301 S.C. 251, 391 S.E.2d 551 (1990); Ott, 320 S.C. at 76, 
  463 S.E.2d at 104.Â  An expert is not limited to any class of persons acting 
  professionally, for the test for qualifying as an expert is a relative one that 
  is dependent on the particular witnessâ€™s reference to the subject.Â  See 
  Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 317 S.C. 320, 324, 454 S.E.2d 328, 
  330 (Ct. App. 1995), revâ€™d in part on other grounds, 326 S.C. 248, 487 
  S.E.2d 596 (1997) (an emergency room technician who was licensed to perform 
  intubations and had taught the procedure was qualified to testify about the 
  proper way to intubate a patient in a medical malpractice suit against a board-certified 
  anesthesiologist); McMillan v. Durant, 312 S.C. 200, 439 S.E.2d 829 (1993) 
  (a neurosurgeon who was also a teacher in nursing was qualified to testify about 
  the appropriate standard for nursing care).
One of Fieldsâ€™s experts was Dr. George Podgorny. 
  Â Podgornyâ€™s testimony was taken by video deposition and was introduced during 
  the trial.Â  The deposition showed that Podgorny specialized in emergency medicine 
  and had practiced emergency medicine for twenty-five years.Â  Fieldsâ€™s counsel 
  asked Podgorny whether he was board-certified in emergency medicine.Â  Podgorny 
  answered that he was not and sought to explain his answer.Â  â€œThe reason 
  [why Iâ€™m not board-certified] is that I was the first president of the Board 
  of Emergency Medicine and was instrumental in development of the examination, 
  and then served for many years as the editor of both the written and the oral 
  exam.â€Â  Hane objected to the reason coming before the jury on hearsay 
  grounds.Â  The circuit court agreed it was hearsay and excluded it.Â  Fields proffered 
  Podgornyâ€™s remaining testimony regarding this issue.Â  â€œ[T]he opinion of 
  legal counsel was that there may be a conflict of interest if I [had taken] 
  the exam [because it would have been perceived] that I knowed [sic] all the 
  answers.â€
Fields maintains the circuit court erred 
  by excluding Podgornyâ€™s testimony regarding his explanation for not being board-certified 
  in emergency medicine and is entitled to a new trial.Â  We agree.
Hearsay is â€œa statement, other than one 
  made by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence 
  to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE.Â  Proof of a 
  statement introduced to show a party heard and acted upon information is not 
  objectionable hearsay.Â  Webb v. Elrod, 308 S.C. 445, 449, 418 S.E.2d 
  559, 562 (Ct. App. 1992); 31A C.J.S. Evidence Â§ 259 (1996) (â€œ[T]estimony 
  is not hearsay where it relates to what the witness himself did in reliance 
  on, or in response to, a statement, facts upon which action was taken, personal 
  observations, explanation of conduct, the effect of statements on the listener, 
  the fact that something was said, or identifying what was said.â€).
Podgornyâ€™s statement is a classic example 
  of showing an action based upon information and is not offered for the truth 
  of the matter asserted.Â  The statement was not offered to prove that the counsel 
  was correct in showing that there would be a conflict of interest if Podgorny 
  took the test, but rather explained why Podgorny did not take the test and therefore, 
  was not board-certified.Â  
This case presented the quintessential 
  battle of the experts.Â  Fieldsâ€™s experts, including Podgorny, contended the 
  hospital and Hane failed to reach an appropriate level of care. Fields specifically 
  avowed they committed malpractice by failing to take an adequate history and 
  failing to admit Fields in light of his history.Â  The hospitalâ€™s and Haneâ€™s 
  experts professed that because they were so familiar with Fields and had reviewed 
  so many of his prior medical records, they met a reasonable level of care by 
  not admitting Fields.Â  In this scenario, the credentials of the experts are 
  critical when the jury is determining the credibility of the competing expert 
  witnesses.
Hane protests that even if the statement 
  was not hearsay, its exclusion was harmless error.Â  We disagree.Â  Each expert 
  was asked whether he was board-certified in emergency medicine when testifying 
  during the trial.Â  Even Hane was asked if he was board-certified during his 
  testimony.Â  During the closing arguments, Haneâ€™s counsel asserted that his expert, 
  Bartlett, was board-certified in emergency medicine and was a true expert as 
  opposed to Podgorny, who was not board-certified.Â  â€œRemember Dr. Bartlett 
  . . . This man is a true expert. He knows what heâ€™s talking about.Â  Dr. Podgorny, 
  what evidence is there that Dr. Podgorny writes the test?Â  Ridiculous!Â  Dr. 
  Podgorny never took the test to be board certified.â€
Haneâ€™s closing argument shows that 
  Fields was irrefutably prejudiced by the exclusion of this testimony.Â  Since 
  the statement was not hearsay, the jury was entitled to hear Podgornyâ€™s response 
  to the question of why he had never taken the test for board certification in 
  emergency medicine.Â  This case demonstrated the paradigmatic example of â€œclashing 
  experts and debatable qualifications.â€Â  It was reversible error to exclude Podgornyâ€™s 
  testimony.
II.Â  Admission of Learned Treatise
During Haneâ€™s cross-examination, Fieldsâ€™s 
  counsel queried Hane whether he thought a single isolated EKG, as opposed to 
  continued monitoring with multiple EKGs, was appropriate.Â  Hane stated he thought 
  it was appropriate.Â  Fields then asked Hane if he was familiar with a textbook 
  of emergency medicine authored by Tintinalli, Krome and Ruiz.Â  Hane responded 
  that he was familiar with the treatise since it was used as a reference text 
  in the emergency room.Â  Hane admitted the book was an authority in emergency 
  medicine.Â  Fieldsâ€™s counsel noticed the text was sitting on Haneâ€™s table and 
  asked whether Hane had reviewed the text prior to his testimony.Â  Fields sought 
  to question Hane on the contents contained in the text.
Haneâ€™s counsel objected to the question 
  referring to the text on the basis of an improper foundation and the text was 
  not referred to in the answer to interrogatories, which asked what treatises 
  or materials Fields would use during the trial.Â  The circuit court sustained 
  Haneâ€™s objection on the grounds that Fields failed to list the treatise in the 
  answer to interrogatories.Â  
Fields asserts the circuit court committed 
  reversible error when it sustained Haneâ€™s objection and prohibited Fields from 
  questioning Hane about the text of the treatise.Â  We agree.
Parties are allowed to cross-examine an 
  expert witness about a treatise used or relied upon by the expert witness to 
  support his opinion in direct examination.Â  31A Am. Jur. 2d Expert and Opinion 
  Evidence Â§ 104 (2002).

To the extent called to the attention of an expert witness 
  upon cross-examination or relied upon by the expert in direct examination, statements 
  contained in published treatises, periodicals, or pamphlets on a subject of 
  history, medicine, or other science or art, established as a reliable authority 
  by the testimony or admission of the witness or by other testimony or by judicial 
  notice [are not excluded by the hearsay rule.]

Rule 803(18), SCRE.
There is no question in this case that 
  the Tintinalli book is a recognized treatise.Â  Hane acknowledged the book is 
  a commonly used reference in the emergency room and he admitted reviewing the 
  text prior to his testimony.Â  There was certainly a sufficient foundation established 
  for its use.
Haneâ€™s interrogatories propounded to Fields 
  asked: â€œGive the title, author, date, volume and page, where appropriate, of 
  any periodical, journal, text, paper or other publication of any kind, to which 
  [Fields] intends to refer, or about which [Fields] intends to ask any questions, 
  during the examination o[r] cross-examination of any witness at trial or during 
  any deposition.â€Â  Fields responded, â€œPlaintiff has not yet identified any specific 
  journals, text of learned treaties. [sic]Â  The Plaintiff reserves the right 
  to supplement this interrogatory at a later date once an expert witness has 
  been identified or once discovery from the other parties has been completed.â€Â  
  Fields did not supplement her answers and stated she was not aware of the Tintinalli 
  treatise until the morning of the trial.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Rule 37(b)(2), SCRCP allows a court to 
  impose a variety of sanctions for failure to comply with a discovery order. 


[T]he court in which the action is pending may make 
  such orders in regard to the failure as are just, and among others the following:
  
(A) An order that the matters regarding 
  which the order was made or any other designated facts shall be taken to be 
  established for the purposes of the action in accordance with the claim of the 
  party obtaining the order;
(B) An order refusing to allow 
  the disobedient party to support or oppose designated claims or defenses, or 
  prohibiting him from introducing designated matters in evidence;
(C) An order striking out pleadings 
  or parts thereof, or staying further proceedings until the order is obeyed, 
  or dismissing the action or proceeding or any part thereof, or rendering a judgment 
  by default against the disobedient party;
(D) In lieu of any of the foregoing 
  orders or in addition thereto, an order treating as a contempt of court the 
  failure to obey any orders except an order to submit to a physical or mental 
  examination;
(E) Where a party has failed to 
  comply with an order under Rule 35(a) requiring him to produce another for examination, 
  such orders as are listed in paragraphs (A), (B), and (C) of this subdivision, 
  unless the party failing to comply show that he is unable to produce such person 
  for examination.
  
In lieu of any of the foregoing orders or in addition 
  thereto, the court shall require the party failing to obey the order or the 
  attorney advising him or both to pay the reasonable expenses, including attorney's 
  fees, caused by the failure, unless the court finds that the failure was substantially 
  justified or that other circumstances make an award of expenses unjust.

Rule 37(b)(2), SCRCP.Â  The circuit court sanctioned 
  Fields by disallowing the use of the Tintinalli treatise during Haneâ€™s cross-examination.
The decision of what kind and whether 
  to impose discovery sanctions is left to the sound discretion of the circuit 
  court.Â  Griffin Grading & Clearing v. Tire Serv. Equip. Mfg. Co., 
  334 S.C. 193, 198, 511 S.E.2d 716, 718 (Ct. App. 1999); Downey v. Dixon, 
  294 S.C. 42, 45, 362 S.E.2d 317, 318 (Ct. App. 1987); McGaha v. Mosley, 
  283 S.C. 268, 277, 322 S.E.2d 416, 466 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  In deciding what sanction 
  to impose, the circuit court should weigh the nature of the interrogatories, 
  the discovery posture of the case, willfulness, and the degree of prejudice.Â  
  Samples v. Mitchell, 329 S.C. 105, 112, 495 S.E.2d 213, 216 (Ct. App. 
  1997); Moran v. Jones, 281 S.C. 270, 276, 315 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App. 
  1984).Â  A circuit courtâ€™s failure to exercise discretion is itself an abuse 
  of discretion.Â  In re Robert M., 294 S.C. 69, 71, 362 S.E.2d 639, 640 
  (1987); State v. Smith, 276 S.C. 494, 498, 280 S.E.2d 200, 202 (1981); 
  State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 86, 538 S.E.2d 257, 267 (Ct. App. 2000); 
  Balloon Plantation, Inc. v. Head Balloons, Inc., 303 S.C. 152, 155, 399 
  S.E.2d 439, 441 (Ct. App. 1990).
Failure to disclose a witness in answer to an interrogatory 
  when only discovered several days before trial does not show willfulness.Â  Martin 
  v. Dunlap, 266 S.C. 230, 239, 222 S.E.2d 8, 12Â  (1976); Laney v. Hefley, 
  262 S.C. 54, 202 S.E.2d 12 (1974). The purpose of interrogatories is to promote 
  full and fair disclosure to prevent surprise to either party.Â  South Carolina 
  State Hightway Depâ€™t v. Booker, 260 S.C. 245, 252, 195 S.E.2d 615, 619 (1973); 
  see also Reed v. Clark, 277 S.C. 310, 316, 286 S.E.2d 384, 388 
  (1982) (â€œDisclosure of information between the parties before trial is designed 
  to avoid surprise and to promote decisions on the merits after a full and fair 
  hearing.â€).
In this case, Fields stated she only found 
  out about the treatise on the day of the trial.Â  Concomitantly, there was no 
  showing of willfulness.Â  Hane had a copy of the treatise with him during the 
  trial and admitted using it to prepare for his testimony.Â  Therefore, Hane could 
  certainly not be surprised by being asked about this treatise as it was the 
  very same one he was using himself.Â  This negates any contention that Hane was 
  prejudiced by Fieldsâ€™s failure to supplement her interrogatories.Â  The only 
  factor the judge discussed when excluding questions involving the treatise was 
  the nature of the interrogatory:Â  â€œThatâ€™s the reason we have interrogatories 
  so we wonâ€™t have surprises in trials, right?â€
In Samples v. Mitchell, the court instructed: 
  â€œIn deciding what sanction to impose for failure to disclose evidence during 
  the discovery process, the trial court should weigh the nature of the interrogatories, 
  the discovery posture of the case, willfulness, and the degree of prejudice.â€Â  
  329 S.C. at 112, 495 S.E.2d at 216 (citing Laney, 262 S.C. at 60, 202 
  S.E.2d at 15 (1974); Moran, 218 S.C. at 276, 315 S.E.2d at 139-40).Â  
  The circuit court failed to exercise discretion.Â  â€œA failure to exercise discretion 
  amounts to an abuse of that discretion.â€Â  Samples, 329 S.C. at 112, 495 
  S.E.2d at 216 (citing Fontaine, 291 S.C. at 538, 354 S.E.2d at 566 (â€œWhen 
  the trial judge is vested with discretion, but his ruling reveals no discretion 
  was, in fact, exercised, an error of law has occurred.â€); Balloon Plantation, 
  303 S.C. at 155, 399 S.E.2d at 441 (quoting Smith, 276 S.C. at 498, 280 
  S.E.2d at 202 (â€œIt is an equal abuse of discretion to refuse to exercise discretionary 
  authority when it is warranted as it is to exercise the discretion improperly.â€))).Â  
  We find the circuit court erred when it disallowed Fields from using the Tintinalli 
  treatise in cross-examining Hane.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the decision 
  of the circuit court is
 REVERSED AND REMANDED. 
 HUFF, J., and MOREHEAD, Acting Judge, 
  concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Sharon D. Moody,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Dairyland Insurance Company,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3624
Submitted March 10, 2003 - Filed April 
  14, 2003 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas M. Gagne, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Robert W. Buffington, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 HOWARD, J.:Â  Sharon D. 
  Moody brought a declaratory judgment action against her automobile insurance 
  carrier, Dairyland Insurance Company (â€œDairylandâ€), claiming her insurance policy 
  should be reformed to include underinsured motorist (â€œUIMâ€) coverage up to the 
  policyâ€™s statutory minimum liability limits (â€œstatutory minimum limitsâ€) because 
  Dairyland failed to make a meaningful offer of UIM coverage.Â  The circuit court 
  granted Dairylandâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Moody appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On June 14, 2000, Moody purchased an automobile 
  insurance policy with the statutory minimum limits from Dairyland. 
  [1] Â  Dairyland offered Moody UIM coverage only in an amount equal to the 
  statutory minimum limits of her policy.Â  Moody expressly rejected Dairylandâ€™s 
  offer of UIM coverage.
Subsequently, Moody was involved in an automobile 
  accident in which she alleged the other driver was at fault.Â  She claimed she 
  was entitled to proceeds from her policyâ€™s UIM coverage because her damages 
  exceeded the limits of the at-fault driverâ€™s liability insurance policy.Â  Dairyland 
  denied the claim, stating Moodyâ€™s policy contained no UIM coverage.
Moody filed this declaratory judgment action, seeking 
  to have her insurance policy reformed to include UIM coverage.Â  She argued Dairyland 
  failed to make a meaningful offer of UIM coverage in amounts less than the statutory 
  minimum limits.Â  Dairyland moved for summary judgment.Â  Dairyland argued, pursuant 
  to South Carolina Code Annotated section 38-73-470 (Supp. 2002), it was not 
  required to offer UIM coverage in amounts less than the statutory minimum limits.Â  
  The circuit court agreed and granted Dairylandâ€™s motion.Â  Moody appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is granted â€œwhen there is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as 
  a matter of law.â€Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 
  (2001).Â  When reviewing a grant of summary judgment, this Court must use â€œthe 
  same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56, SCRCP.â€Â  Lanham 
  v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of South Carolina, Inc., 349 S.C. 356, 361, 
  563 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002).Â  Moreover, â€œ[o]n appeal from an order granting summary 
  judgment, [this Court] will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences 
  arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving 
  party.â€Â  Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 
  563, 564 S.E.2d 94, 96 (2002).
DISCUSSION
Moody argues the circuit court erred in granting 
  Dairylandâ€™s motion for summary judgment, asserting Dairyland did not make a 
  meaningful offer of UIM coverage because it failed to offer coverage in amounts 
  less than the statutory minimum limits. [2] Â  We disagree.
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is 
  to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€Â  Hawkins v. Bruno 
  Yacht Sales, Inc., Op. No. 25592 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Feb. 3, 2003) (Shearouse 
  Adv. Sh. No. 5 at 11, 19).Â  Moreover, â€œ[w]here the terms of the statute are 
  clear, [this Court] must apply those terms according to their literal meaning.â€Â  
  Brown v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 
  507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414 (2002); see also Rowe v. Hyatt, 
  321 S.C. 366, 369, 468 S.E.2d 649, 650 (1996) (holding when â€œinterpreting a 
  statute, words must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting 
  to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operationâ€).
In relevant part, section 38-73-470 provides â€œ[t]here 
  is no requirement for an insurer or an agent to offer underinsured motorist 
  coverage at limits less than the statutorily required bodily injury or property 
  damage limits.â€ [3] Â  Dairyland asserts this amendment 
  specifically alleviated the requirement that insurers offer UIM coverage in 
  any amount below the statutory minimum limits.
However, Moody argues the language of section 38-73-470 
  â€œbasically states a contract principle which states that no one had to make 
  any offer [at all].â€Â  Furthermore, Moody asserts South Carolina Code Annotated 
  section 38-77-160 (Supp. 2002) (requiring automobile insurance carriers to offer 
  UIM coverage â€œup to the limits of the insured liability coverageâ€) and the cases 
  interpreting this section, required Dairyland to offer UIM coverage at amounts 
  less than the statutory minimum limits.Â  In each of the following cases, Butler 
  v. Unisun Ins. Co., 323 S.C. 402, 407, 475 S.E.2d 758, 761 (1996), Norwood 
  v. Allstate Ins. Co., 327 S.C. 503, 489 S.E.2d 661 (Ct. App. 1997), and 
  Osborne v. Allstate Ins. Co., 319 S.C. 479, 488, 462 S.E.2d 291, 296 
  (Ct. App. 1995), the central holding was section 38-77-160 mandates an insurer 
  to offer UIM coverage in amounts less than the statutory minimum limits.
Both of Moodyâ€™s arguments fail.Â  First, we decline 
  to accept Moodyâ€™s particularly parsed and strained reading of section 38-73-470.Â  
  The relevant statutory language in this section is unambiguous and conveys a 
  clear and definite meaning that insurance carriers are under no duty to offer 
  UIM coverage at any amount less than the statutory minimum limits.
Moreover, Moodyâ€™s reliance on section 38-77-160 
  and the cases interpreting it is misplaced.Â  Butler, Norwood, 
  and Osborne were decided prior to the effective date of the 1997 amendment 
  to section 38-73-470.Â  Thus, these cases were correctly decided under the then-existing 
  law.Â  However, these cases are no longer controlling because each was decided 
  prior to the 1997 amendment.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s 
  order granting Dairylandâ€™s motion for summary judgment is
AFFIRMED. [4] 
CURETON and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-140 (Supp. 2002) (stating the minimum 
    liability coverage limits are â€œfifteen thousand dollars because of bodily 
    injury to one person in any one accident . . . , thirty thousand dollars because 
    of bodily injury to two or more persons in any one accident, and ten thousand 
    dollars because of injury to or destruction of property of others in any one 
    accidentâ€ or 15/30/10).

 
   [2]  Our supreme court has adopted 
    a four-part test to determine whether an insurer has made a meaningful offer 
    of optional insurance coverages: â€œ(1) the insurerâ€™s notification process must 
    be commercially reasonable . . . ; (2) the insurer must specify limits of 
    optional coverage and not merely offer additional coverage in general term; 
    (3) the insurer must intelligibly advise the insured of the nature of the 
    optional coverage; and (4) the insured must be told that optional coverages 
    are available for an additional premium.â€Â  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. 
    v. Wannamaker, 291 S.C. 518, 521, 354 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1987).

 
   
    [3]  This portion of section 38-73-470 was added in 1997 by Act No. 154 
    Â§ 3.

 
   [4] 
     Because oral argument would not aid the Court in resolving any issue 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Douglas Edward McCloud,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3625
Heard February 25, 2003 - Filed April 
  14, 2003Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia; 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  all of Columbia; Solicitor John R. Justice, of Chester; for Respondent.
      
    
  

 GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Douglas Edward McCloud 
  appeals his conviction for criminal domestic violence of a high and aggravated 
  nature (CDVHAN), arguing the indictment did not enumerate the elements of the 
  offense and was therefore insufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction 
  on the trial court.Â  We affirm.
The indictment was captioned â€œINDICTMENT 
  FOR CRIMINAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE â€“ AGGRAVATED.â€Â  The body of the indictment 
  read as follows:Â  â€œThat Douglas Edward McCloud did in Fairfield County on or 
  about June 16, 2000 commit an act of violence against Kermisha L. Golden, by 
  striking her in [the] face with his closed fist, also hit her in [the] head 
  and pulled her hair an[d] scratched her neck.â€Â  The indictment concluded 
  with the standard phrase â€œ[a]gainst the peace and dignity of the State and, 
  contrary to the statute in such case made and provided.â€Â  
When the case was called for trial on October 26, 
  2000, McCloud failed to appear and was tried in his absence.Â  The jury 
  found him guilty, and a bench warrant was issued for his arrest.Â  
  On April 19, 2001, McCloud was brought before the trial court, at 
  which time the clerk read the sentence imposed on him.
1.Â  McCloud first argues that the indictment was 
  deficient because it failed to allege that the victim was a â€œhousehold member.â€Â Â  
  We disagree.
South Carolina Code section 16-25-20 provides 
  that â€œ[i]t is unlawful to: (1) cause physical harm or injury to a personâ€™s own 
  household member, (2) offer or attempt to cause physical harm or injury to a 
  personâ€™s own household member with apparent present ability under circumstances 
  reasonably creating fear of imminent peril.â€ 
  [1] Â  Section 16-25-10 defines â€œhousehold memberâ€ as â€œspouses, former spouses, 
  parents and children, persons related by consanguinity or affinity within the 
  second degree, persons who have a child in common, and a male and female who 
  are cohabiting or formerly have cohabited.â€ 
  [2] Â  Section 16-25-65(A) provides that â€œ[t]he elements of the common law 
  crime of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature are incorporated 
  in and made a part of the offense of criminal domestic violence of a high and 
  aggravated nature when a person violates the provisions of Section 16-25-20 
  and the elements of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature are 
  present.â€ [3]   
At trial, Golden testified that McCloud 
  had been her boyfriend for six years and they had a three-year-old child together.Â  
  Admittedly, however, the indictment does not allege that Golden was McCloudâ€™s 
  â€œhousehold memberâ€ or otherwise set forth the criteria that would accord her 
  this status.Â  Nevertheless, we believe this deficiency did not deprive 
  the trial court of jurisdiction to hear the case.
â€œAn indictment is adequate if the offense 
  is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the court to 
  know what judgment to pronounce, the defendant to know what he is called upon 
  to answer, and acquittal or conviction to be placed in bar to any subsequent 
  conviction.â€ [4] Â  Moreover, these 
  indictment sufficiency criteria â€œmust be viewed with a practical eye; all 
  the surrounding circumstances must be weighed before an accurate determination 
  of whether a defendant was or was not prejudiced can be reached.â€ [5] Â  â€œ[O]ne is to look at the â€˜surrounding 
  circumstancesâ€™ that existed pre-trial, in order to determine whether a given 
  defendant has been â€˜prejudiced,â€™ i.e., taken by surprise and hence unable to 
  combat the charges against him.â€ [6] 
Here, the pretrial surrounding circumstances 
  of this case do not warrant dismissing the indictment.Â  Although the indictment 
  failed to allege that Golden was McCloudâ€™s household member or specify how she 
  would qualify as such, there was no dispute either at trial or on appeal that 
  she was the alleged victim in this case and had â€œa child in commonâ€ with McCloud. 
  [7] Â  In addition, McCloud had received a preliminary hearing, a 
  circumstance that would support the conclusion that, under the â€œpractical eyeâ€ 
  test, he â€œobviously knew the crimes for which he was being triedâ€ [8]  and was therefore not unduly prejudiced by the alleged defect 
  in the indictment.Â  Moreover, the indictment contained the standard language 
  that the offense alleged was â€œ[a]gainst the peace and dignity of the State, 
  and contrary to the statute in such case made and providedâ€; therefore, we hold 
  it satisfied the statutory requirements to be deemed sufficient to give the 
  trial court subject matter jurisdiction to hear the case. 
  [9] Â  Finally, the caption of the indictment named the offense that McCloud 
  was alleged to have committed, and although it was not a part of the indictment, 
  it was â€œconsistent with the charging language.â€ 
  [10]   
2.Â  We further reject McCloudâ€™s argument that the 
  indictment failed to specify circumstances of aggravation necessary to establish 
  CDVHAN. Among other things, the indictment alleged that McCloud struck the victim 
  in the face with his closed fist, hit her in the head, pulled her hair, and 
  scratched her neck.Â  Furthermore, the arrest warrant contained an affidavit 
  stating the victim suffered swelling and bruising to her right eye and had to 
  seek medical attention at the hospital.Â  Finally, it is apparent from the indictment 
  that there was a difference in gender between McCloud and Golden, as evidenced 
  by the allegation that McCloud committed an act of violence against Golden â€œby 
  striking her in [the] face with his closed fistâ€ [emphasis added].Â  
  These averments in the indictment, when considered with the surrounding 
  circumstances that had surfaced before the commencement of the trial, were sufficient 
  to notify McCloud that he was charged with causing serious bodily injury to 
  the victim. [11] 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., concurs.Â  SHULER, J., 
  dissents in a separate opinion. 
 SHULER, J., dissenting:Â  Because 
  I believe the language of McCloudâ€™s indictment did not sufficiently state the 
  offense of criminal domestic violence of a high and aggravated nature (CDVHAN), 
  I respectfully dissent.
The majority concludes McCloudâ€™s indictment 
  is sufficient because they find, in evaluating the circumstances surrounding 
  the indictment, he was apprised of the charge against him.Â  However, as I interpret 
  South Carolina precedent regarding indictments and subject matter jurisdiction, 
  the body of the indictment must sufficiently identify the elements of the charged 
  offense.Â  See, e.g., Locke v. State, 341 S.C. 54, 56, 533 S.E.2d 
  324, 325 (2000) (holding â€œ[a] circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction 
  if . . . there has been an indictment which sufficiently states the offense. 
  . . .â€) (emphasis added); Granger v. State, 333 S.C. 2, 4, 507 S.E.2d 
  322, 323 (1998) (finding the true test of the sufficiency of an indictment is 
  whether it contains the elements of the offense and sufficiently apprises 
  the defendant of what he must be prepared to meet) (emphasis added).Â  As such, 
  McCloudâ€™s indictment for CDVHAN is clearly insufficient, as it neither identifies 
  the victim as a household member nor specifically alleges an aggravating circumstance.
The elements of CDVHAN are satisfied 
  when an individual causes physical harm to a household member and the elements 
  of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN) are present.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 16-25-20, 16-25-65 (2003).Â  â€œA â€˜household memberâ€™ means spouses, 
  former spouses, parents and children, persons related by consanguinity or affinity 
  within the second degree, persons who have a child in common, and a male and 
  female who are cohabiting or formerly have cohabited.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-10 
  (2003).Â  As the majority acknowledges in its opinion, McCloudâ€™s indictment clearly 
  fails to allege the victimâ€™s status as a â€œhousehold member,â€ an element necessary 
  to sustain an indictment for CDVHAN.Â  While McCloud and the victim have a child 
  together, this fact is not stated in the indictment.Â  Thus, the key element 
  necessary for a proper CDVHAN indictment is missing. 
There is no mention of the statute or code section 
  in either the body of the indictment or the caption.Â  Thus, the elements cannot 
  be implied in that manner.Â  See, e.g., State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 
  637, 649, 552 S.E.2d 745, 751 (2001) (holding the failure to include an element 
  of a statutory offense in the body of an indictment will not invalidate the 
  indictment if specific reference to the statute is made in the body of the indictment).Â  
  Furthermore, one cannot infer the elements of an offense from the caption of 
  the indictment.Â  See State v. Lark, 64 S.C. 350, 353, 42 S.E. 
  175, 176-77 (1902) (finding the caption of the indictment cannot be used to 
  expand or contract the allegations, because it is not a part of the findings 
  by the grand jury); cf. State v. Tabory, 262 S.C. 136, 141, 202 
  S.E.2d 852, 854 (1974) (holding the State may not support a conviction for an 
  offense intended to be charged by relying upon a caption to the exclusion of 
  the language contained in the body of the indictment).Â  As such, the fact that 
  McCloudâ€™s indictment was captioned as â€œcriminal domestic violence â€“ aggravatedâ€ 
  is not enough to render the indictment sufficient.Â Â Â  
Therefore, all that should be 
  examined in this particular situation is the actual body of the indictment itself.Â  
  See Tate v. State, 345 S.C. 577, 581, 549 S.E.2d 601, 603 (2001) 
  (finding it is the body of the indictment that is controlling).Â  In the instant 
  case, the body of the indictment alone does not sufficiently describe the elements 
  needed for a CDVHAN offense.Â  In fact, the description of the offense in the 
  body of McCloudâ€™s indictment is sufficiently vague that it could satisfy the 
  elements of either ABHAN [12]  
  or simple assault and battery. [13] Â  Without mention of the crucial element of 
  CDVHAN â€“ the victimâ€™s status as a household member â€“ it is impossible to determine 
  from the body of the indictment the crime with which McCloud was charged.Â  As 
  such, I believe McCloudâ€™s indictment for CDVHAN was deficient.Â  See S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20 (2003) (an indictment is sufficient if it â€œcharges the 
  crime substantially in the language . . . of the statute prohibiting the crime 
  or so plainly that the nature of the offense charged may be easily understood.â€); 
  see also State v. Bullard, 348 S.C. 611, 614, 560 S.E.2d 436, 
  437 (Ct. App. 2002).
Furthermore, common sense dictates 
  that adopting the majorityâ€™s reasoning undermines the purpose of the grand jury 
  system.Â  The 18 members of the grand jury are convened as an impartial panel 
  for the purpose of reviewing the Stateâ€™s evidence against a criminal defendant.Â  
  The grand jury must pass on the elements alleged in the indictment before the 
  indictment can be true-billed.Â  If the majorityâ€™s analysis is adopted, the actual 
  body of the indictment will become inconsequential because â€“ long after the 
  grand jury has deliberated â€“ a court will be able to supplement the language 
  of the indictment by examination of pre-trial circumstances.Â  In my view, this 
  type of analysis after the fact serves to weaken the role and function of the 
  grand jury system.
For the foregoing reasons, I would vacate McCloudâ€™s 
  conviction for CDVHAN.  

 
   
    [1] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-20 (2003).Â  This statute was last amended 
    in 1994.Â  1994 S.C. Acts 519, Â§ 1.

 
   [2] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-10 (2003).Â  

 
   [3] Â  Id. Â§ 16-25-65(A).

 
   [4] Â  State v. Crenshaw, 274 S.C. 475, 477, 
    266 S.E.2d 61, 62 (1980).

 
   
    [5] Â  State v. Adams, 277 S.C. 115, 125, 283 S.E.2d 582, 588 (1981) 
    (emphasis added), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 
    305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).

 
   [6] Â  State v. Wade, 306 S.C. 79, 86, 409 S.E.2d 
    780, 784 (1991).

 
   
    [7] Â  See State v. Reddick, 348 S.C. 631, 560 S.E.2d 441 
    (Ct. App. 2002) (holding that an indictment alleging the defendant threw bodily 
    fluids on a correctional officer but failing to specify that he was an â€œinmateâ€ 
    was sufficient to vest the trial court with subject matter jurisdiction because 
    there was no confusion regarding his status as an inmate), cert. denied 
    (Oct. 11, 2002).

 
    [8] Â  Adams, 277 S.C. at 126, 283 S.E.2d at 
    588.

 
   
    [9] Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-65(C) (2003) (stating the statute 
    creates â€œa statutory offense of criminal domestic violence of a high and aggravated 
    natureâ€); id. Â§ 17-19-20 (1985) (listing the necessary criteria for 
    an indictment to be â€œsufficient and good in law,â€ including the requirement 
    that, â€œif the offense be a statutory offense, that the offense be alleged 
    to be contrary to the statute in such case made and providedâ€).

 
   
    [10] Â  State v. Wilkes, Op. No. 25607 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Mar. 
    17, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 10 at 24, 27).

 
    [11] Â  See State 
    v. Wright, 349 S.C. 310, 312 n.1, 563 S.E.2d 311, 312 n.1 (2002) (noting 
    that CDVHAN incorporates the elements of ABHAN, including â€œcircumstances of 
    aggravation,â€ which include â€œinfliction of serious bodily injuryâ€ and â€œa difference 
    in genderâ€ between the defendant and the victim).

 
   
    [12]  State v. Fennell, 340 S.C. 266, 274, 531 S.E.2d 512, 516 
    (2000) (defining ABHAN as â€œthe unlawful act of violent injury to another, 
    accompanied by circumstances of aggravation.â€).Â Â Â  

 
   [13]  State v. Patterson, 
    337 S.C. 215, 231, 522 S.E.2d 845, 853 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding simple assault 
    and battery is an unlawful act of violent injury to another unaccompanied 
    by any circumstances of aggravation).Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
James Nelson, Jr., as guardian ad litem 
        for Ty'Quain S. Nelson, a minor child,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
QHG of South Carolina, Inc., d/b/a Carolina 
        Hospital System, Quorum Health Group, Inc., Drs. Coker, Phillips, and
Haswell, P.A., and Thomas W. Phillips, M.D.,       
Defendants,
of whom Drs. Coker, Phillips, and
Haswell, P.A. and Thomas W. Phillips, 
        M.D. are        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â L. Henry McKellar, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3626
Heard March 13, 2002 - Filed AprilÂ  
  14, 2003

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Edward L. Graham, of Florence, for Appellant.
Robert H. Hood, Hugh W. Buyck, and D. Nathan Hughey, all of Charleston, for 
  Respondents.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Tyâ€™Quain S. Nelsonâ€™s guardian 
  ad litem brought suit against Thomas W. Phillips, M.D., Drs. Coker, Phillips, 
  and Haswell, P.A., QHG of South Carolina, Inc., d/b/a Carolina Hospital System, 
  and Quorum Health Group, Inc. seeking recovery for damages caused by alleged 
  medical malpractice during Nelsonâ€™s delivery.Â  The circuit court granted the 
  motion to dismiss on behalf of Drs. Coker, Phillips, and Haswell, P.A. and Thomas 
  W. Phillips, M.D.Â  Nelson appeals.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Tyâ€™Quain S. Nelson was born on March 5, 
  1993.Â  Thomas W. Phillips, M.D. was the attending obstetrician during Nelsonâ€™s 
  delivery.Â  During delivery, a complication occurred where Nelsonâ€™s shoulder 
  became lodged behind the motherâ€™s pubic bone. Â This is known as shoulder dystocia.Â  
  Nelsonâ€™s upper and lower portions of his right-side brachial plexus nerves were 
  injured during the delivery.Â  The damage to the upper portion, called â€œErbâ€™s 
  palsy,â€ involves primarily the shoulder, elbow, and their related muscles.Â  
  The damage to the lower portion, known as â€œKlumpkeâ€™s palsy,â€ causes paralysis 
  to the hand and results in fingers which are grossly deformed, misshapen, twisted, 
  and contorted.
On February 26, 2001, Nelson sued Thomas 
  W. Phillips, M.D., his medical group, Drs. Coker, Phillips, and Haswell, P.A., 
  QHG of South Carolina, Inc., d/b/a Carolina Hospital System, and Quorum Health 
  Group, Inc., alleging that Thomas W. Phillips, M.D. was negligent in managing
