  skill which is ordinarily employed by the profession under similar conditions 
  and in like circumstances.Â  Keaton v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 334 S.C. 
  488, 514 S.E.2d 570 (1999).Â  In South Carolina, to sustain a cause of action 
  in a medical malpractice case, the plaintiff is required to establish the relevant 
  standard of care and a breach of the standard of care by expert witness testimony.Â  
  Pederson v. Gould, 288 S.C. 141, 341 S.E.2d 633 (1986); Botehlo v. 
  Bycura, 282 S.C. 578, 320 S.E.2d 59 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Gooding v. St. 
  Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 487 S.E.2d 596 (1997), articulates the 
  quintessential mandate thrust upon a plaintiff in a medical malpractice case.Â  
  Gooding inculcates:

[T]he plaintiff must present (1) evidence of the generally 
  recognized practice and procedures that would be exercised by competent practitioners 
  in a defendant doctorâ€™s field of medicine under the same or similar circumstances 
  and (2) evidence that the defendant doctor departed from the recognized and 
  generally accepted standards, practices, and procedures in the manner alleged 
  by the plaintiff.Â  Further, unless the subject is a matter of common knowledge, 
  the plaintiff must use expert testimony to establish both the standard of care 
  and the defendantâ€™s failure to conform to that standard.

Id. at 254, 487 S.E.2d at 599.
A case that is dismissed â€œwith prejudiceâ€ indicates 
  an adjudication on the merits and, pursuant to res judicata, prohibits subsequent 
  litigation to the same extent as if the action had been tried to a final adjudication.Â  
  Lawlor v. Natâ€™l Screen Serv. Corp., 349 U.S. 322, 75 S.Ct. 865, 99 L.Ed. 
  1122 (1955); Nunnery v. Brantley Constr. Co., 289 S.C. 205, 345 S.E.2d 
  740 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  When an action has been dismissed with prejudice, the 
  judgment operates in subsequent litigation to the same extent as if the action 
  had been tried to a final adjudication.Â  Jones v. City of Folly Beach, 
  326 S.C. 360, 483 S.E.2d 770 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  If the first case is dismissed 
  with prejudice on purely procedural grounds without a consideration of the underlying 
  merits of the action, then the party is barred from asserting collateral estoppel 
  or res judicata.Â  Id.; see also Sealy v. Dodge, 289 S.C. 
  543, 347 S.E.2d 504 (1986) (holding that a medical malpractice action was not 
  barred by res judicata where the initial action did not involve an adjudication 
  on the merits but instead involved the childâ€™s capacity to sue and whether there 
  was an improper joinder of the causes of action).
Nelson contends that the circuit courtâ€™s 
  dismissal was for failure to comply with the courtâ€™s extensions of time to present 
  expert witness testimony and was procedural rather than substantive.Â  The circuit 
  court, however, did not dismiss the case for failure to comply with its extensions 
  in a timely fashion, but ultimately dismissed the case because of Nelsonâ€™s failure 
  to present an expert.Â  South Carolina law requires an expert witness in medical 
  malpractice cases.Â  When the circuit court dismissed the case for lack of expert 
  testimony, it was a dismissal on the merits because Nelson failed to sustain 
  his burden of proof.Â  The circuit court did not err when it dismissed Thomas 
  W. Phillips, M.D. because the identity of the parties in the two suits was the 
  same and the first lawsuit was disposed of by an adjudication on the merits.
We conclude granting summary judgment 
  in favor of a physician in a medical malpractice case because of the plaintiffâ€™s 
  failure to produce an expert witness as to the applicable standard of care and 
  departure from the standard of care by the physician is an adjudication of the 
  case on the merits.Â  We reject the contention of Nelson that this factual scenario 
  is only a discovery delinquency and does not rise to the level of a disposition 
  on the merits.Â  
Our decision on this issue is efficacious 
  as to Thomas W. Phillips, M.D., but not as to Drs. Coker, Phillips, and 
  Haswell, P.A.
C.Â  Consent Order
Nelson argues that when his counsel consented 
  to the summary judgment order in the first action, the consent barred the use 
  of collateral estoppel or res judicata in this action.
Because a consent judgment has substantially 
  the same effect as any other judgment rendered in the ordinary course, it is 
  generally entitled to the defense of res judicata.Â  46 Am. Jur. 2d Judgments 
  Â§ 222 (1994).Â  However, even in consent orders, the public policy underlying 
  res judicata may have to yield to other public policies.Â  Johns v. Johns, 
  309 S.C. 199, 420 S.E.2d 856 (Ct. App. 1992); James F. Flanagan, South Carolina 
  Civil Procedure 654 (2d ed. 1996).Â  In Johns, a husband and wife 
  signed a consent order where the family court found they were married at common 
  law and ordered their legal separation.Â  At the time the parties entered into 
  the consent order, the husband was married to another person.Â  The wife brought 
  suit against the husband seeking a divorce, custody of the coupleâ€™s child, an 
  increase in alimony and child support, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The husband contested 
  the divorce, arguing the parties were not married.Â  The wife sought to use the 
  consent order declaring they were married at common law to bar the husbandâ€™s 
  defense under res judicata and collateral estoppel grounds.Â  This court did 
  not allow the wife to assert res judicata or collateral estoppel to bar the 
  husbandâ€™s defense because public policy declaring bigamous marriages void overrode 
  the policy concerns for res judicata.  
 Johns is inapposite to this case, 
  however.Â  Nelson misconstrues the nature of his consent in the first case.Â  
  The circuit court imposed monetary sanctions against Nelsonâ€™s counsel for discovery 
  abuse.Â  Nelsonâ€™s counsel consented to the imposition of monetary sanctions.Â  
  He did not consent to the grant of the summary judgment motion.Â  In Johns, 
  the consent order was directly on point as to what was in dispute in the second 
  case.Â  There was no effective consent given allowing the entry of summary judgment 
  and the general rule disallowing the use of res judicata or collateral estoppel 
  for consent orders does not apply.
For the sake of clarity, this conclusion 
  applies only to Thomas W. Phillips, M.D., but not to Drs. Coker, Phillips, 
  and Haswell, P.A.
D.Â  Inadequate Representation in the First Suit
Nelson contends that his counselâ€™s representation 
  in the first suit was inadequate so the doctrines of res judicata and collateral 
  estoppel should not apply.
In Pye v. Aycock, 325 S.C. 426, 
  480 S.E.2d 455 (Ct. App. 1997), the appellant raised the issue that collateral 
  estoppel should not apply because of an inadequate defense and failing to identify 
  witnesses in the first action.Â  This court rejected that argument stating:

[Appellant] presented no affidavits or depositions to the 
  trial court regarding the purported testimony of the alleged additional witnesses.Â  
  Further, prior to the federal action, both parties had a substantial amount 
  of time to prepare for trial and conduct extensive discovery.Â  Both cases had 
  been on the docket for well over a year prior to the [first action].

Id. at 439, 480 S.E.2d at 461.Â  Inadequate 
  representation is not a basis for attacking res judicata.Â  In re Fuhrman, 
  118 B.R. 72 (E.D. Mich. 1990).Â  In Dennis v. First State Bank of Texas, 
  989 S.W.2d 22 (Tex. App. 1998), the Texas Court of Appeals stated:

To allow appellants another chance to relitigate the issues 
  that should have been brought in the [first suit] would circumvent the purpose 
  behind the doctrine of res judicata and would allow a losing party to relitigate 
  a cause of action based solely on an assertion of inadequate representation.Â  
  The doctrine of res judicata does not allow for such a result.

Id. at 28.
Nelsonâ€™s attorney had ample time to develop 
  witnesses. Â The circuit court even granted additional days after the entry of 
  summary judgment to present an expert witness with a motion for reconsideration.
While we sympathize with Nelson and agree 
  that the first attorneyâ€™s conduct in handling the case was reprehensible, the 
  proper course of action to rectify the attorneyâ€™s behavior is legal malpractice 
  and not punishing the opposing party by suspending the operation of res judicata 
  or collateral estoppel.
For the sake of clarity, this conclusion applies 
  only to Thomas W. Phillips, M.D., but not to Drs. Coker, Phillips, and 
  Haswell, P.A.
E.Â  Policy Considerations
Nelson asserts public policy considerations 
  should bar Thomas W. Phillips, M.D. and Drs. Coker, Phillips, and Haswell, P.A. 
  from invoking the doctrines of collateral estoppel and res judicata.
The doctrines of collateral estoppel and 
  res judicata exist to â€œreduce litigation and conserve the resources of the court 
  and litigants and it is based upon the notion that it is unfair to permit a 
  party to relitigate an issue that has already been decided.â€Â  State v. Bacote, 
  331 S.C. 328, 331, 503 S.E.2d 161, 163 (1998).Â  Even when the elements of res 
  judicata and collateral estoppel have been met, they will not be rigidly or 
  mechanically applied, and the application of the doctrines may be precluded 
  where unfairness or injustice results, or public policy requires it.Â  Id.; 
  Carrigg v. Cannon, 347 S.C. 75, 552 S.E.2d 767 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œThus 
  application of res judicata will not be applied where it will contravene other 
  important public policies; the courts must weigh the competing public policies.â€Â  
  Johns v. Johns, 309 S.C. 199, 203, 420 S.E.2d 856, 859 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  
  We recognize that there have been instances when collateral estoppel or res 
  judicata have not been invoked for countervailing public policy concerns.Â  See 
  Bacote, 331 S.C. at 331, 503 S.E.2d at 163 (declining to give collateral 
  estoppel effect to proceedings which occur during an administrative hearing 
  for a driverâ€™s license revocation); Shelton v. Oscar Mayer Foods Corp., 
  325 S.C. 248, 481 S.E.2d 706 (1997) (finding that giving administrative hearings 
  held in front of the Employment Security Commission collateral estoppel effect 
  would frustrate the purposes of the Employment Security Commission); Johns, 
  309 S.C. at 203, 420 S.E.2d at 859 (refusing to apply a consent order entered 
  by the family court finding husband and wife married at common law because giving 
  the order collateral estoppel effect would violate the Stateâ€™s policy finding 
  bigamous marriages void as mandated by statute).Â  However, in these cases, collateral 
  estoppel was in conflict with existing public policy concerns. 
In Bacote and Shelton, the public 
  policy weighed against res judicata was the efficiency and speed of administrative 
  procedures.Â  In Johns, the policy of res judicata was in direct contravention 
  with a statutorily expressed policy prohibiting bigamous marriages.Â  In this 
  case, Nelson merely states it would be unfair to impose collateral estoppel 
  or res judicata without expressing what public policy considerations are violated.Â  
  Since we can see no existing public policy concerns in preventing litigation 
  for failure to provide sufficient proof in the first action, we find the summary 
  judgment order in the first action has collateral estoppel and res judicata 
  effect which does not run contrary to any public policy.Â  Consequently, the 
  circuit court was correct in finding the second suit against Thomas W. Phillips, 
  M.D. was barred by res judicata and collateral estoppel.
For the sake of clarity, this conclusion applies 
  only to Thomas W. Phillips, M.D., but not to Drs. Coker, Phillips, and 
  Haswell, P.A.
IV.Â  Master-Servant Liability
Nelson argues the circuit court erred 
  when it found that Thomas W. Phillips, M.D. and Drs. Coker, Phillips, and Haswell, 
  P.A. were in a master-servant relationship and the master could not be found 
  liable when the servant was not liable.Â  We agree.
Normally, a master cannot be held liable 
  for the actions of the servant if its liability is based solely upon the actions 
  of its servant.Â  Hundley v. Rite Aid of South Carolina, Inc., 339 S.C. 
  285, 529 S.E.2d 45 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  However, when a masterâ€™s liability is based 
  on its own conduct or the conduct of a non-defendant servant, an exoneration 
  of its defendant servant does not absolve it from liability.Â  Id.Â  
In Rite Aid, the plaintiff sued 
  the pharmacy and the pharmacist for damages that occurred from an improperly 
  filled prescription.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of the plaintiff, 
  awarding the plaintiff punitive damages against the pharmacy, but not against 
  the pharmacist.Â  Rite Aid argued it could not be held liable for punitive damages 
  when the jury failed to find the pharmacistâ€™s action was willful because its 
  liability was predicated on the actions of its servant.Â  This court disagreed, 
  finding that the allegations in the complaint that Rite Aid negligently supervised 
  the pharmacist were a separate basis of liability independent of the pharmacistâ€™s 
  liability.Â  
We have reviewed the complaint in this 
  case and, giving Nelson the benefit of all reasonable inferences, as we must 
  when considering a motion to dismiss, we find that the claims against Drs. Coker, 
  Phillips, and Haswell, P.A. regarding the sufficiency of its medical record 
  keeping is an independent basis of liability separate from Thomas W. Phillips, 
  M.D.â€™s liability.Â  Therefore, Nelson may maintain the suit against Drs. Coker, 
  Phillips, and Haswell, P.A., even though Thomas W. Phillips, M.D. is not liable, 
  due to the entry of the summary judgment motion and Nelson voluntarily dismissing 
  Thomas W. Phillips, M.D.
This holding does not run afoul of either 
  of the cases cited by Thomas W. Phillips, M.D. and Drs. Coker, Phillips, and 
  Haswell, P.A.Â  In Rookard v. Atlanta & Charlotte Air Line R.R., 84 
  S.C. 190, 65 S.E. 1047 (1909), the plaintiff sued Atlanta for damages which 
  occurred in a railroad crossing accident.Â  Southern Railroad Company, a lessee 
  of Atlanta, was operating the rail line at the time of the accident.Â  The court 
  set forth the principle that â€œ[a] judgment on the merits in favor of the agent 
  is a bar to an action against the principal for the same cause, because the 
  principalâ€™s liability is predicated upon that of the agent.â€Â  Id. at 
  192, 65 S.E. at 1047.Â  The same principle is espoused in Logan v. Atlanta 
  & Charlotte Air Line R.R., 82 S.C. 518, 64 S.E. 515 (1909): â€œWhere an 
  agent is sued, and, after trial on the merits, the issue is determined against 
  the plaintiff, the principal, though not a party to the suit, can avail himself 
  of the judgment as a bar, when sued by the same plaintiff on the same cause 
  of action.â€Â  Id. at 523, 64 S.E. at 516.Â  However, both of these cases 
  refer to barring liability for the master when the servant is found not liable 
  for the same cause of action brought against the master.Â  In this case, negligence 
  in keeping medical records and medical record procedures are separate from Thomas 
  W. Phillips, M.D.â€™s potential liability.Â  Rookard and Logan are 
  not germane.
V.Â  Additional Sustaining Grounds
Thomas W. Phillips, M.D. and Drs. Coker, 
  Phillips, and Haswell, P.A. assert as an additional sustaining ground that Nelsonâ€™s 
  suit is barred because it violates the statute of repose.Â  We disagree.
The complaint alleges the negligent medical 
  treatment arising from Nelsonâ€™s delivery occurred on March 5, 1993.Â  The complaint 
  was filed almost eight years later on February 26, 2001.Â  
The time limit to bring a cause of action 
  by a minor in a medical malpractice action is:

(D) Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 15-3-40, if 
  a person entitled to bring an action against a licensed health care provider 
  acting within the scope of his profession is under the age of majority at the 
  date of the treatment, omission, or operation giving rise to the cause of action, 
  the time period or periods limiting filing the action are not tolled for a period 
  of more than seven years on account of minority, and in any case more than one 
  year after the disability ceases.Â  Such time limitation is tolled for minors 
  for any period during which parent or guardian and defendantâ€™s insurer or health 
  care provider have committed fraud or collusion in the failure to bring an action 
  on behalf of the injured minor.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-545 (Supp. 2002).
Thomas W. Phillips, M.D. and Drs. Coker, 
  Phillips, and Haswell, P.A. contend that there is no allegation of fraud or 
  collusion by the parent or guardian with the defendants or their insurance companies 
  and therefore the statute clearly bars the suit.
This court has discretion on whether to address 
  additional sustaining grounds.Â  â€œ[A] respondent - - â€˜the winnerâ€™ in the lower 
  court - - may raise on appeal any additional reasons the appellate court should 
  affirm the lower courtâ€™s ruling, regardless of whether those reasons have been 
  presented to or ruled on by the lower court.â€Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. 
  Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 419, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000).Â Â  â€œAn appellate 
  court may not rely on Rule 220(c) SCACR, when the reason [supporting the additional 
  sustaining ground] does not appear in the record, or when the court believes 
  it would be unwise or unjust to do so in a particular case.Â  It is within the 
  appellate courtâ€™s discretion whether to address any additional sustaining grounds.â€Â  
  Id. at 420, 526 S.E.2d at 723.Â  â€œWhile the current rules do not require 
  the respondent to present an issue to the lower court in order to raise it as 
  an additional sustaining ground, an appellate court is less likely to rely on 
  such a ground when the respondent has failed to present it to the lower court.â€Â  
  Id. at 421, 526 S.E.2d at 724.
We decline to address this issue in the present 
  case because the issue was presented by Thomas W. Phillips, M.D.â€™s motion to 
  dismiss, and therefore Drs. Coker, Phillips, and Haswell, P.A. lacked standing 
  to argue this issue in front of the circuit court and it would be inequitable 
  for us to address this issue.
CONCLUSION
We hold that pursuant to Rule 41(a)(1)(A), SCRCP, 
  a plaintiff may dismiss an action without order of court by filing and serving 
  a notice of dismissal before service by the adverse party of an answer or notice 
  of appearance.Â  A voluntary dismissal under Rule 41(a)(1)(A) is efficacious 
  against a defendant who has not answered or made an appearance, even though 
  another defendant has answered and made an appearance.Â  Once a voluntary dismissal 
  under Rule 41(a)(1)(A) has been filed and served before service by the adverse 
  party of an answer or notice of appearance, the circuit court lacks jurisdiction 
  over the dismissed party and the dismissed party has no standing to subsequently 
  file a motion to dismiss.
We rule that a minor is the plaintiff in an action 
  and the fact that there are two different guardians ad litem is irrelevant to 
  the privity element in a res judicata/collateral estoppel analysis.
We reverse the order of the circuit judge 
  dismissing â€œDrs. Coker, Phillips, and Haswell, P.A.â€ with prejudice 
  and   remand the case against â€œDrs. Coker, Phillips, and Haswell, 
  P.A.â€ for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
Finally, we reverse the order of the circuit 
  judge dismissing Thomas W. Phillips, M.D. with prejudice because the plaintiff 
  had previously filed a voluntary dismissal of Thomas W. Phillips, M.D. under 
  Rule 41(a)(1)(A), SCRCP.
REVERSED and REMANDED.
HUFF, J., and MOREHEAD, Acting Judge, concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
James Pendergast/Father,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Charlene Pendergast/Mother,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Jack Alan Landis, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3627
Submitted March 10, 2003 - Filed April 
  14, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Cynthia Barrier Castengera, of Newland, N.C.; David Dusty
Rhoades, of Charleston, for Appellant. 
Lon H. Shull, III, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  


STILWELL, J.:Â  James Pendergast (Father) 
  appeals the family court order which failed to reduce his unallocated support 
  obligation following the graduation from college of the partiesâ€™ child, and 
  also required him to contribute $6,000 toward Charlene Pendergastâ€™s (Mother) 
  attorney fees.Â  We affirm. [1] 
 FACTS
The parties were married in 1970, had 
  a child in 1979, and were divorced in 1980 in New York.Â  The original decree 
  specified alimony and child support, which was later recast as unallocated support 
  pursuant to a 1984 consent order in New York.Â  Father relocated to South Carolina, 
  but Mother and child remained in New York. Â In 1997, a South Carolina family 
  court continued this characterization of Fatherâ€™s support obligations in a subsequent 
  consent order.Â  
In the present action, the family court 
  terminated Fatherâ€™s child support obligation. Â However, it refused to 
  reduce Fatherâ€™s unallocated support because he had shown no change in circumstances 
  warranting a reduction in the support paid to Mother, and further held that 
  the unallocated support was now clearly alimony.Â  The court found Motherâ€™s recurring 
  monthly expenses were reasonable and found the fact that the partiesâ€™ child 
  was emancipated did not provide a basis for reducing or terminating alimony 
  and that Mother had received no increase in support since 1980 while Fatherâ€™s 
  income had substantially increased.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has 
  the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 
  157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not, however, require this 
  court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 
  276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Neither are we required to ignore 
  the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better 
  position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their 
  testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 
  (1981).Â  Furthermore, our broad scope of review does not â€œrelieve the appellant 
  of the burden of convincing this Court that the family court committed error.â€Â  
  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 523, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979). Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Apportionment of Unallocated Support
Father argues that the family court erred 
  by not reducing his unallocated support obligation by the portion attributable 
  to child support, which the family court terminated.Â  Father further argues 
  that the court is required to allocate the support between child support and 
  alimony under section 20-3-150.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-150 (1976 & Supp. 
  2001).Â  We disagree with this application of the law based on the facts of this 
  case.Â  
  In the absence of South Carolina authority on 
  point, we find it helpful to look to other jurisdictions for guidance.Â  â€œ[A]n 
  alimony award given for the support of a wife and her children is an award to 
  the group as a family unit and cannot automatically be prorated among the wife 
  and children upon the happening of some contingent event regarding the children, 
  . . . except as specifically provided in the decree.â€Â  Van Dyck v. 
  Van Dyck, 429 S.E.2d 914, 916 (Ga. 1993).Â  Such an award is subject to modification 
  based on the changes in financial circumstances of the parties because of events 
  involving the children.Â  Id. at 916-17.Â  However, the reduced support 
  obligation presented by a childâ€™s emancipation may be offset by changes in circumstances 
  affecting the remaining support obligations.Â  See Graffeo v. Graffeo, 
  180 N.Y.S.2d 844 (N.Y. App. Div. 1958) (denying modification where the fact 
  that one child had become self-supporting was offset by a change in circumstances 
  due to the increased cost of maintaining the other child); Barker v. Barker, 
  45 N.Y.S.2d 809 (N.Y. Sup. Ct. 1943) (continuing the original allowance for 
  the benefit of the wife, who was afflicted with a chronic ailment which rendered 
  her unable to work, even though one of the daughters had married and the other 
  was employed, the original award in a separation being for the support of the 
  wife and the two daughters).
Here, a New York consent order subsequent 
  to the divorce decree changed the support from child support and alimony to 
  unallocated support, and the 1997 South Carolina enforcement order continued 
  that characterization.Â  Fatherâ€™s time to appeal these underlying orders is long 
  past.Â  The award was both fully child support and fully alimony with no distinction 
  or proration.Â  Neither provided for automatic proration based upon the contingent 
  event of the partiesâ€™ childâ€™s emancipation.Â  
The family court in the order under appeal 
  held that the support is clearly alimony and should now be characterized as 
  such.Â  The amount of alimony is within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion and 
  â€œwill not be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion is shown.â€Â  Smith 
  v. Smith, 264 S.C. 624, 627-28, 216 S.E.2d 541, 543 (1975).Â  Father deducted 
  amounts paid on his income taxes as alimony.Â  The family court was therefore 
  correct in holding that the entire amount is alimony.Â  
II.Â  Reduction of Alimony
Father asserted a material and substantial 
  change of circumstances had occurred because the partiesâ€™ child was now emancipated 
  and Motherâ€™s living and housing expenses had reduced substantially while she 
  was earning more money than at the time of the divorce hearing and no longer 
  required support.Â  Thus, Father argues he is entitled to termination or modification 
  of alimony.Â  
South Carolina law authorizes a spouse 
  to request modification of alimony based upon a change of circumstances.Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1976 & Supp. 2001).Â  After a hearing in which the 
  parties are given the opportunity to be heard and present evidence, the family 
  court may â€œmake such order and judgment as justice and equity shall require, 
  with due regard to the changed circumstances and the financial ability of the 
  supporting spouse, decreasing or increasing or confirming the amount of alimony 
  provided for in such original judgment or terminating such payments.â€Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 (1976).
The determination â€œâ€˜of whether to increase 
  or decrease support based on a finding of changed circumstances is a matter 
  committed to the sound discretion of the family court.â€™â€ Â Thornton v. Thornton, 
  328 S.C. 96, 111, 492 S.E.2d 86, 94 (1997) (quoting Brunner v. Brunner, 
  296 S.C. 60, 64, 370 S.E.2d 614, 616 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  Thus, â€œthe family courtâ€™s 
  determination whether to modify support will not be disturbed on appeal unless 
  the family court abused its discretion.â€Â  Id.Â  To justify modification, 
  the changes in circumstances must be substantial or material.Â  Id.Â  We 
  find the family court did not abuse its discretion in determining there has 
  been no substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of alimony.Â  

The family court found that the childâ€™s 
  completing college would do relatively little to decrease Motherâ€™s expenses 
  or cost of living.Â  In spite of childâ€™s graduation from college, we find no 
  evidence in the record that Motherâ€™s monthly expenses would decrease.Â  Moreover, 
  in the twenty years since the divorce, Mother never sought a cost-of-living 
  increase.Â  Her income and standard of living has remained relatively unchanged, 
  whereas Fatherâ€™s income and concomitant ability to pay alimony has substantially 
  increased.Â  Father argued that Motherâ€™s living circumstances had changed and 
  asserted that she was living with a man.Â  The family court found, and we agree, 
  that Fatherâ€™s own investigatorâ€™s findings support Motherâ€™s testimony that she 
  is living in the basement of a single family home and moved out of her apartment 
  and sublet it because gangs had moved into the neighborhood.Â  We agree this 
  evidence does not support a decrease in Fatherâ€™s monthly alimony obligation. 

III.Â  Attorney Fees
Father argues that because much of Motherâ€™s 
  attorneyâ€™s time was devoted to her motions which were denied, she has not prevailed 
  and should not be awarded partial attorney fees.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe award of attorney fees is within 
  the discretion of the court.â€Â  Hardwick v. Hardwick, 303 S.C. 256, 261, 
  399 S.E.2d 791, 794 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  In determining whether to award attorney 
  fees, the Court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, 
  the beneficial results obtained by the attorney, the partiesâ€™ respective financial 
  conditions, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. 
  v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 815 (1992).Â  In determining 
  the amount of attorney fees to award, the court should consider the nature, 
  extent, and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted 
  to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the contingency of compensation, 
  the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  
  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  

Father sued Mother in South Carolina 
  to reduce the support.Â  She was required to take time from work and defend the 
  action in South Carolina.Â  Her defense of the alimony reduction action was successful.Â  
  Moreover, the court found Father chose to bring this action in South Carolina 
  and had the income to afford attorney fees, whereas Mother did not without substantially 
  impacting her standard of living.Â  The family court ordered Father to pay part 
  but not all of Motherâ€™s attorney fees.Â  It is apparent from the record that 
  the judge appropriately considered the Glasscock factors in determining 
  the amount of attorney fees to award.Â  The court did not err in requiring Father 
  to contribute $6,000 toward Motherâ€™s attorney fees.Â  
CONCLUSION
Because the courtâ€™s findings are supported 
  by the evidence and the record and are not affected by any error of law, the 
  order of the family court is
 AFFIRMED.
CURETON and HOWARD, JJ. concur.

    215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Wayne Wright       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Published Opinion No. 3628
Submitted March 10, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  14, 2003

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, and Warren B. Giese, all of Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


HOWARD, J.:Â  Wayne Wright was convicted 
  of attempted second-degree burglary.Â  Wright appeals, arguing the indictment 
  was insufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction, and the State violated 
  Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986), by improperly striking a juror 
  based on racial considerations. We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDRUAL BACKGROUND
A grand jury indicted Wright for attempted first-degree 
  burglary.Â  The caption of the indictment stated, â€œAttempted Burglary (Dwelling) 
  FIRST DEGREE Common Law â€“ No Classification,â€ and the text of the indictment 
  alleged:

That Tony Wayne Wright AKA Wayne Bruce Wright did in Richland 
  County on or about June 7, 2000 attempted [sic] to enter the dwelling of Marion 
  Summers without consent and with the intent to commit a crime therein and the 
  defendant has two or more prior convictions for burglary and/or housebreaking 
  or a combination thereof . . . .

When the case was called for trial, the State exercised peremptory 
  challenges to strike three black jurors.Â  Wright objected and requested a Batson 
  hearing.Â  The State averred Juror 22 and Juror 163 were dismissed because they 
  had criminal records.Â  Neither strike is in contention here.Â  As to the dismissal 
  of Juror 29, the assistant solicitor gave the following explanation:

Her employment is listed as a bilingual translator.Â  We didnâ€™t 
  seat any other translators for sure.Â  And just based on her accent, I donâ€™t 
  know, I just am not sure of her command of the English language.Â  My first -- 
  my gut instinct was that, even though she is a translator, she might not have, 
  you know, just based on her accent, I donâ€™t know where she is from, if she is 
  from the United States, and that just gave me some cause of concern.Â  

Responding to the Stateâ€™s explanation, 
  Wrightâ€™s counsel noted the State did not strike Juror 123 who was German and 
  had a â€œhuge accent.â€Â  The State responded:

[Juror 29] was just more soft-spoken than [Juror 123], but 
  -- And maybe Iâ€™m just misreading her employment.Â  I got the sense that [Juror 
  123] was sort of -- she indicated that she worked for the fire department.Â  
  She is some sort of computer operator.Â  I got the sense from that that she was 
  some sort of -- I wonâ€™t say 911 operator, but something to do with communications 
  between the fire department and the public.Â  I could be misreading her employment, 
  but I felt because that that was her line of work she was probably more in tune 
  with, you know, the English language than the [Juror 29].

The State further explained:

I didnâ€™t have any information that [Juror 123] was from Germany, 
  and in fact at the jury qualification she indicated that she worked at the fire 
  department, that is why I made that connection because she works on computers 
  and she works at the fire department that she must do some sort of communications 
  there akin to 911 operations.

The circuit court ultimately ruled the Stateâ€™s 
  peremptory strikes did not violate Batson, and the jury was seated and 
  sworn.Â  Wright was convicted of attempted second-degree burglary and sentenced 
  to fifteen years imprisonment.Â  Wright appeals.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Indictment
Wright argues the indictment does not 
  confer subject matter jurisdiction on the circuit court because common law burglary 
  requires that the entry occur during the nighttime. State v. Washington, 
  338 S.C. 392, 397, 526 S.E.2d 709, 711 (2000). Wright argues the indictment 
  contains no allegation that the entry was attempted at night, and since the 
  caption and body of the indictment label the offense as attempted burglary â€“ 
  common law, it fails to sufficiently allege the elements of the offense.Â  We 
  disagree with this reading of the indictment.
Subject matter jurisdiction may be raised 
  at any time by the parties or sua sponte by the court.Â  See State 
  v. Castleman, 219 S.C. 136, 139, 64 S.E.2d 250, 252 (1951).Â  The circuit 
  court does not have subject matter jurisdiction to convict a defendant of an 
  offense unless there is an indictment that sufficiently states the offense, 
  the defendant waives presentment, or the offense is a lesser-included offense 
  of the crime charged in the indictment.Â Â  State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 
  648, 552 S.E.2d 745, 751 (2001).Â  â€œThe true test of the sufficiency of an indictment 
  is not whether it could be made more definite and certain, but whether it contains 
  the necessary elements of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently 
  apprises the defendant of what he must be prepared to meet.â€Â  Browning v. 
  State, 320 S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995).      
The caption of the indictment reads, â€œAttempted 
  Burglary (Dwelling) FIRST DEGREE Common Law â€“ No Classification.â€Â  
Until 1985, burglary was a common-law offense. See 
  Patricia Seets Watson & William Shepard McAninch, Guide to South Carolina 
  Criminal Law and Procedure, 270-71 (4th ed. 1994).Â  Common law 
  burglary did not have separate degrees.Â  See Washington, 338 S.C. 
  at 397, 526 S.E.2d at 711.
In 1985, the South Carolina legislature enacted South Carolina 
  Code Annotated section 16-11-311 (2003), which divided the offense into three 
  degrees of burglary, including first-degree burglary.Â  See Guide to 
  South Carolina Criminal Law and Procedure, supra, at 270-71.Â  First 
  degree burglary is defined as follows:

(A) A person is guilty of burglary in the first degree if 
  the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a crime 
  in the dwelling, and either:
  
  (1) when, in effecting entry or while in the dwelling or 
  in immediate flight, he or another participant in the crime:
  (a) is armed with a deadly weapon or explosive;Â  or
  (b) causes physical injury to a person who is not a participant 
  in the crime;Â  or
  (c) uses or threatens the use of a dangerous instrument;Â  
  or
  (d) displays what is or appears to be a knife, pistol, revolver, 
  rifle, shotgun, machine gun, or other firearm;Â  or
  (2) the burglary is committed by a person with a prior record 
  of two or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking or a combination of 
  both;Â  or
  (3) the entering or remaining occurs in the nighttime.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311 (2003).
The indictment accused Wright of attempting to commit first-degree 
  burglary.Â  Although first-degree burglary is a statutory offense, an attempt 
  to commit the crime is a common-law offense.Â  See William S. McAninch 
  & W. Gaston Fairey, The Criminal Law of South Carolina, 354 (3d ed. 
  1996); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-80 (2003) (â€œA person who commits 
  the common law offense of attempt, upon conviction, must be punished as for 
  the principal offense.â€).Â  Thus, the State accused Wright of the common-law 
  offense of attempting to commit the statutorily defined crime of burglary in 
  the first degree.Â  Therefore, for the indictment to be sufficient to confer 
  jurisdiction, the State was required to allege the elements of both attempt 
  and first-degree burglary, not attempt and common-law burglary.
The indictment alleges Wright attempted to enter 
  the dwelling of another, without consent, and with the intent to commit a crime.Â  
  The indictment also alleges Wright has two or more prior convictions for burglary 
  and/or housebreaking, or a combination of the two.Â  These allegations are sufficient 
  to allege attempted first-degree burglary, [1]  and the circuit court had subject 
  matter jurisdiction. [2] 
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Batson 
  Violation
Wright argues the circuit court erred by allowing 
  the State to exercise peremptory challenges in a racially discriminatory manner 
  in violation of Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).Â  
It is well settled â€œ[t]he Equal Protection Clause 
  of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the 
  striking of a venire person on the basis of race.â€Â  State v. Shuler, 
  344 S.C. 604, 615, 545 S.E.2d 805, 811 (2001).Â  When one party strikes a member 
  of a cognizable racial group, the circuit court must, upon request by the opposing 
  party, hold a Batson hearing.Â  See State v. Haigler, 334 
  S.C. 623, 629, 515 S.E.2d 88, 90-91 (1999).Â  The proponent of the strike, to 
  successfully rebut the presumption of a Batson violation, must then offer 
  a race-neutral explanation. Id. The opponent must then show the race-neutral 
  explanation was mere pretext, which can be established by showing the proponent 
  did not strike a similarly situated member of another race.Â  Id.
 Whether a Batson violation has 
  occurred must be determined by examining the totality of the facts and circumstances 
  in the record.Â Â  Shuler, 344 S.C. at 615, 545 S.E.2d at 810.Â  The opponent 
  of the strike carries the ultimate burden of persuading the circuit court the 
  challenged party exercised strikes in a discriminatory manner.Â  State v. 
  Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 124, 470 S.E.2d 366, 372 (1996).Â Â  
The record indicates Wright timely objected to 
  the Stateâ€™s peremptory strikes.Â  Thereafter, the State averred a race-neutral 
  reason for each of the peremptory strikes.Â  Specifically, as to Juror 29, the 
  State explained that although she was a bilingual translator, she had a heavy 
  accent, and the State was unsure as to her command of the English language.Â  
  Wright then responded the State did not strike Juror 123, a white German woman 
  who also had a â€œhuge accent.â€Â  The State countered that it was under the impression 
  Juror 123 worked in communications at the fire department and would thus have 
  a better grasp of the English language.Â  Based on this dialogue, the circuit 
  court found the Stateâ€™s peremptory strike did not violate Batson.Â  
The circuit courtâ€™s findings regarding purposeful 
  discrimination rest largely on its evaluation of demeanor and credibility, matters 
  within the peculiar province of the circuit court.Â  Sumpter v. State, 
  312 S.C. 221, 224, 439 S.E.2d 842, 844 (1994); Hernandez v. New York, 
  500 U.S. 325, 364 (1991) (holding often the demeanor of the challenged attorney 
  will be the best and only evidence of discrimination, and â€œevaluation of the 
  prosecutorâ€™s mind lies peculiarly within a circuit courtâ€™s provinceâ€).Â  Even 
  though we are skeptical of the reasons advanced by the striking party, we will 
  not disturb the decision of the circuit court unless its ruling is clearly erroneous.Â  
  Shuler, 344 S.C. at 615, 545 S.E.2d at 810; see also Hernandez, 
  500 U.S. at 365 (holding the United States Supreme Court, when reviewing a state 
  courtâ€™s decision on a Batson claim, will use the clearly erroneous standard). 

Viewing the record in light of our standard of review, 
  the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion was not clearly erroneous.Â  Although we recognize 
  Juror 29 and Juror 123 are similarly situated in that they both have foreign 
  accents, the State distinguished them by their observable command of the English 
  language, as well as what the State perceived their occupations to be.Â  These 
  were proper race-neutral considerations.Â  See Matthews v. Evatt, 
  105 F.3d 907, 918 (4th Cir. 1997) (holding the State is allowed to consider 
  tone, demeanor, facial expression, and any other race-neutral factors when striking 
  jurors).Â  Thus, the circuit court did not err. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, Wrightâ€™s conviction for attempted 
  second-degree burglary is
AFFIRMED.
 CURETON and STILWELL, JJ., concur.     
Â 



 
   [1]  Furthermore, even assuming the 
    caption was defective, there is no jurisdictional flaw.Â  See Tate 
    v. State, 345 S.C. 577, 581, 549 S.E.2d 601, 603 (2001) (â€œIt is the body 
    of the indictment rather than its caption that is important.Â  If the body 
    specifically states the essential elements of the crime and is otherwise free 
    from defect, defect in the caption will not cause it to be invalid.â€ (quoting 
    State v. Marshall & Brown-Sidorowicz, P.A., 577 P.2d 803, 811 (Kan. 
    App. 1978))); cf. State v. Wilkes, Op. No. 25607 (S.C. Sup. 
    Ct. filed March 17, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 10 at 24, 27) (holding when 
    reviewing an indictment for jurisdictional sufficiency, the caption, when 
    consistent with the body, may be used to supplement the body of the indictment).

 
   
    [2] The circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction to convict Wright 
    of attempted second-degree burglary because attempted second-degree burglary 
    is a lesser-included offense of attempted first-degree burglary.Â Â  See 
    Owens, 346 S.C. at 648, 552 S.E.2d at 751 (holding the circuit court 
    has subject matter jurisdiction to convict a defendant of an offense where:Â  
    1) there is an indictment that sufficiently states the offense, 2) the defendant 
    waives presentment, or 3) the offense is a lesser-included offense of the 
    crime charged in the indictment); State v. Watson, 349 S.C. 372, 375, 
    563 S.E.2d 336, 337 (2002) (â€œThe primary test for determining if a particular 
    offense is a lesser included of the offense charged is the elements test.Â  
    The elements test inquires whether the greater of the two offenses includes 
    all the elements of the lesser offense.â€Â  (internal citations omitted)); S.C. 
    Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-312 (2003) (â€œA person is guilty of burglary in the second 
    degree if the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to 
    commit a crime therein.â€).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Redwend Limited Partnership, Wendswept, Inc., and Ron W. McDaniel, Individually,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

  v.

  
    
      
William Ralph Edwards, a/k/a W. Ralph Edwards, a/k/a William R. Edwards, 
  Ralph Edwards & Associates, Inc., William A. Edwards, Long Point Farms, 
  LLC, and John and Jane Doe, Co-conspirators Known and Unknown,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Gerald C. Smoak, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Published Opinion No. 3629
Heard March 13, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  14, 2003

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
Timothy W. Bouch and G. Hamlin Oâ€™Kelley, III, both 
  of Charleston, for Appellants.
Arthur G. Howe, Barry Krell, and Jerry N. Theos, all of Charleston; and John 
  P. Freeman, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 ANDERSON, J.:Â  Redwend Limited Partnership (the 
  Partnership), Wendswept, Inc., and Ron McDaniel (collectively referred to as 
  â€œMcDanielâ€) filed suit against William Ralph Edwards (Edwards), Ralph Edwards 
  & Associates, Inc., William A. Edwards, and Long Point Farms, LLC, (collectively 
  referred to as â€œEdwardsâ€) alleging breach of fiduciary duty, fraud, breach of 
  contract, negligent misrepresentation, constructive fraud, constructive trust, 
  unjust enrichment, tortious interference with contractual relations, breach 
  of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, violations of the South Carolina 
  Unfair Trade Practices Act, civil conspiracy, and rescission or reformation 
  of the contract.Â  The causes of action arise from the withdrawal of Edwards 
  from the Partnership and his subsequent purchase of property believed by McDaniel 
  to be a partnership opportunity.Â  McDaniel appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of 
  summary judgment to Edwards.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Partnership was formed on December 16, 1996, by filing a Certificate 
  of Limited Partnership in the Office of the Secretary of State.Â  The formal 
  agreement of Redwend Limited Partnership is dated February 6, 1997.Â  The Partnership 
  planned to acquire and develop land for resale.
Edwards and McDaniel were both active in the Partnership.Â  At the outset, McDaniel 
  and another partner, Wendswept, [1]  contributed property to the Partnership for 
  development.Â  According to McDaniel, Edwards agreed, as his contribution, to 
  acquire for the Partnership two specific tracts of land, the Boone Tract and 
  the Eddy Farm, which could be developed by the Partnership.Â  The purpose of 
  the Partnership is delineated in paragraph 3.1 of the Partnership Agreement:

3.1 Purpose. The character of the business and the purposes of 
  the Partnership are:
  
a) To acquire, own, develop and sell the Rhettâ€™s Crossing Tract, the Stono Tract 
  and the Boone Tract . . . and in connection therewith to lease and/or acquire 
  or deal with such real and personal property as necessary for the conduct of 
  its business and to engage in all other lawful activity in support of its business; 
  and
b) To reinvest the proceeds of sales and proceeds of capital contributions and/or 
  loans in additional tracts of land or real estate of any nature or other property 
  of any nature or kind, real or personal, tangible or intangible as is deemed 
  to be in the best interest of the Partners as determined in good faith by the 
  General Partner; and
c) To conduct any business and engage in any other activity whatsoever deemed 
  to be lawful and desirable by the General Partner.
  

The Partnership purchased the Boone tract and developed it as planned.Â  
  During the Partnership, McDaniel and Edwards traveled together to the Eddy Farm 
  on numerous occasions.Â  Edwards, using John W. Patrick [2]  as a straw man buyer, made an 
  offer for the Eddy Farm property.Â  The contract to buy the Eddy Farm was dated 
  July 21, 1997.Â  Patrick was listed as the buyer.Â  Drayton Hastie, the attorney 
  for the Partnership, was listed on the contract as the closing attorney.Â  The 
  contract was executed during the course of the Partnership.Â  However, the property 
  was not purchased for the Partnership.Â  McDaniel declared Edwards told McDaniel 
  that he submitted a contract to procure the Eddy Farm property on behalf of 
  the Partnership in 1997.Â  McDaniel professed: â€œWe were trying to purchase the 
  [Eddy Farm] property as a partnership.Â  Thatâ€™s what I thought we were doing.â€Â  
  Edwards disagreed with this assertion, claiming there was no effort by the Partnership 
  to buy the Eddy Farm.
On August 4, 1997, Edwards and his father created Long Point Farms, 
  LLC, which was in the business of acquiring property for development.Â  In June 
  1998, Long Point Farms, along with John W. Patrick, entered into an agreement 
  to purchase the Eddy Farm property.Â  Edwards stated the â€œactual buyerâ€ was â€œ[p]robably 
  Long Point Farms.â€
Â In July 1998, Edwards approached McDaniel about 
  withdrawing from the Partnership.Â  These discussions resulted in a handwritten 
  agreement of withdrawal.Â  The agreement included a provision that the Eddy Farm 
  property would remain a partnership opportunity and asset after Edwardsâ€™ withdrawal.Â  
  Yet, according to McDanielâ€™s deposition testimony, at the August 5, 1998, meeting 
  where Edwards signed the withdrawal agreement, Edwards told McDaniel the Eddy 
  Farm property was lost to other purchasers and should be omitted from the August 
  5 withdrawal agreement.Â  McDaniel stated that Edwards told him â€œthe lawyers 
  from the estate got it.â€Â  McDaniel averred he relied on what Edwards 
  told him and agreed to strike through the provision establishing the Eddy Farm 
  property as a partnership opportunity and prohibiting Edwards from competing 
  for the property.Â  The scratched-through provision in the agreement then referenced 
  â€œonly [the] Folly Beach Tractâ€ as a Partnership opportunity.Â  The August 5 withdrawal 
  agreement contained no merger clause.
On August 6, 1998, the day after Edwards withdrew from the Partnership, 
  Long Point Farms became the sole purchaser of the Eddy Farm.Â  The day after 
  informing McDaniel the Eddy Farm had been â€œlost,â€ Edwards finalized the purchase 
  of the property.Â  McDaniel was not aware that Edwards and his father had purchased 
  the Eddy Farm property until around April of 1999.
McDaniel and Edwards sent the August 5 agreement 
  to Hastie, the Partnership attorney, who telephoned McDaniel and asked him about 
  the scratched-out portion of the agreement.Â  McDaniel responded: â€œ[D]onâ€™t worry 
  about it, thatâ€™s a piece of property the partnership was trying to get and it 
  was sold to somebody else . . . so if itâ€™s been sold to somebody else thereâ€™s 
  no point in dealing with it.â€Â  Hastie declared â€œ[t]he contention was that the
