THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Danny Ray Tutton, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal 
  From Laurens County
Â Gary 
  E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge

Published 
  Opinion No. 3630
Submitted 
  January 10, 2003 â€“ Filed April 21, 2003Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate 
  Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia; for Appellant.
Attorney General 
  Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant 
  Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, Senior Assistant Attorney General 
  Harold M. Coombs, of Columbia; Solicitor William Townes Jones, of Greenwood; 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

 HEARN, C.J.:Â  Danny Ray Tutton was indicted for second-degree 
  criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor, and two counts of lewd act on a 
  minor.Â  A jury found him guilty as charged, and he was sentenced to twenty years 
  confinement on the CSC charge, a consecutive term of fifteen years for the first 
  lewd act, and an additional consecutive term of fifteen years for the second 
  lewd act, which was suspended upon the service of five years probation.Â  Tutton 
  appeals, arguing the trial judge erred by admitting evidence of uncharged criminal 
  conduct under the common scheme or plan exception to State v. Lyle, 125 
  S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923), and Rule 404(b), SCRE.
I. 
  FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In July of 2000, Tuttonâ€™s live-in girlfriend, Tammy, invited thirteen-year 
  old Mary and her younger sisters, Jane[1]
  and Tanya,[2]   to Tuttonâ€™s 
  home for several days to play with Tammyâ€™s daughter, Sarah. Â During the 
  stay, the girls, Tammy, and Tutton spent the days picnicking, washing Tuttonâ€™s 
  truck, and swimming in the river and in Tuttonâ€™s pool.Â  The charges facing Tutton 
  arose out of the following contested facts.Â  
The first 
  night, all four girls slept on the floor by Tuttonâ€™s bed.Â  Jane testified that 
  while she was sleeping, Tutton began rubbing her â€œbutt.â€Â  She alleged 
  that after she rolled over, Tutton was able to reach under the covers and put 
  his hands inside her shorts to rub her private parts.Â  Jane further stated â€œHe 
  stuck his fingers inside of me.â€Â  After Tutton fell asleep, Jane left the room. 
  
On the second night, Tutton was sleeping on the couch while the girls 
  were sleeping on a pallet of blankets placed on the floor nearby.Â  Mary testified 
  that while Tutton was lying on the couch, he began to touch her â€œbuttâ€ outside 
  the covers.Â  When she turned over, he touched her â€œprivate part.â€Â Â  Mary stated 
  she kept the blankets tightly around her, and therefore, Tutton was unable to 
  reach underneath them. Â After Mary pinched her sister to move over, she 
  moved out of Tuttonâ€™s reach and the touching stopped.Â  
The allegations surfaced after the girlsâ€™ father, Chris, became suspicious 
  that something might have happened during their stay at Tuttonâ€™s home.Â  He became 
  concerned because the girls were acting quiet and withdrawn upon returning home 
  and did not kiss him goodnight as they always had done.Â  Chris testified that 
  the next day, he asked the girls if â€œanybody bothered [them] or did anything 
  they shouldnâ€™t have?â€Â  The girls both indicated that Tutton had â€œput his handsâ€ 
  on them.Â  Thereafter, the authorities were notified.
Because of the alleged penetration, Jane saw a pediatrician trained 
  in sexual abuse cases.Â  The doctor performed a genital examination with the 
  aid of a colposcope.Â  The exam revealed no evidence of trauma.Â  However, the 
  doctor testified that while the results of the exam could not prove penetration 
  had occurred, it was possible that digital penetration could have occurred without 
  Janeâ€™s hymen showing any evidence of trauma. 
The issue in this case arose during Janeâ€™s testimony before the court.Â  
  During its direct examination, the State sought to elicit testimony that Tutton 
  had sexually assaulted Jane on another occasion several years prior to the events 
  in question.Â  Counsel for Tutton objected, arguing the testimony amounted to 
  inadmissible character evidence.Â  Outside the presence of the jury, the State 
  proffered Janeâ€™s testimony as to the prior occurrence.Â  
Jane testified that four or five years prior to the time of trial, 
  Tutton sexually assaulted her.Â  The assault allegedly occurred when she and 
  Mary were staying with Tutton and Tammy while their parents were on vacation.Â  
  Jane testified that Tutton forced her to lie on her back and take off her panties.Â  
  She stated Tutton then performed oral sex on her and forced her to perform oral 
  sex on him.Â  She alleged that Tutton threatened to tell her parents she was 
  misbehaving if she spoke of the incident.Â  Jane never told anyone about this 
  incident prior to the investigation into the current charges facing Tutton. 
  
The trial court ruled this evidence was admissible under the common 
  scheme or plan exception to Lyle.Â  Specifically, the trial court found 
  that Janeâ€™s testimony regarding the past misconduct was clear and convincing, 
  and that the prior acts bore a close similarity to the crimes charged; thus 
  the probative value of the evidence was not outweighed by its prejudicial effect.Â  
  The testimony was thereafter presented to the jurors, who ultimately convicted 
  Tutton.Â  
II.Â  
  LAW/ANALYSIS
Evidence of prior crimes or misconduct is inadmissible to prove the 
  specific crime charged unless the evidence tends to establish (1) motive; (2) 
  intent; (3) the absence of mistake or accident; (4) a common scheme or plan 
  embracing the commission of two or more crimes so related to each other that 
  proof of one tends to establish the proof of the other; or (5) the identity 
  of the person charged with the present crime.Â  See Lyle, 125 S.C. 
  at 416, 118 S.E. at 807; Rule 404(b), SCRE.Â  To be admissible, a prior bad act 
  must first be established by clear and convincing evidence.Â  State v. Beck, 
  342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000); State v. Weaverling, 337 S.C. 460, 
  468, 523 S.E.2d 787, 791 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating if a prior bad act is not 
  the subject of a conviction, proof thereof must be by clear and convincing evidence).Â  
  
If the 
  trial judge finds there is clear and convincing evidence that the defendant 
  committed the uncharged acts, it must next be determined whether the prior acts 
  fall within the common scheme or plan exception to Lyle.Â  â€œA close degree 
  of similarity or connection between the prior bad act and the crime for which 
  the defendant is on trial is required to support admissibility under the common 
  scheme or plan exception.â€ State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 546, 552 
  S.E.2d 300, 311 (2001).Â  The connection must be more than just a general similarity.Â  
  State v. Timmons, 327 S.C. 48, 52, 488 S.E.2d 323, 325 (1997).Â  â€œA common 
  scheme or plan involves more than the commission of two similar crimes; some 
  connection between the two is necessary.â€Â  Id.Â  Where the evidence of 
  the bad acts is so similar to the charged offense that the previous act enhances 
  the probative value of the evidence so as to outweigh its prejudicial effect, 
  it is admissible.Â  Weaverling, 337 S.C. at 468, 523 S.E.2d at 791.Â  However, 
  even if the evidence is clear and convincing and falls within a Lyle 
  exception, the trial judge must exclude it if its probative value is substantially 
  outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant.Â  Id.
A.Â  Clear and Convincing Evidence
When 
  considering whether there is clear and convincing evidence of other bad acts, 
  this court is bound by the trial judgeâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly 
  erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001) 
  (finding the appellate court committed error by basing its ruling on its own 
  view of the witnessâ€™s credibility).Â  In this case, there is evidence in the 
  record in the form of Janeâ€™s proffered testimony that the prior assault occurred.Â  
  The determination of a witnessâ€™s credibility must be left to the trial judge 
  who saw and heard the witness and is therefore in a better position to evaluate 
  his or her veracity.Â  State v. Rosier, 312 S.C. 145, 149, 439 S.E.2d 
  307, 310 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Accordingly, the determination as to whether Janeâ€™s 
  testimony clearly and convincingly established that the prior assault occurred 
  is a matter well within the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  We find no abuse of that 
  discretion in light of Janeâ€™s proffered testimony.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. 
  at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829. 
B.Â  
  Common Scheme or Plan Exception
Having found that the record supports the trial judgeâ€™s ruling that 
  Tutton committed the prior bad act, we must next determine whether the evidence 
  falls within the common scheme or plan exception to Lyle.Â  Initially, 
  we note that no South Carolina cases expressly state the standard of review 
  for determining whether the evidence presented at trial is sufficient to establish 
  the existence of a common scheme or plan.Â  Ordinarily, questions concerning 
  the admissibility of evidence are treated as questions of fact.Â  Wilson, 
  345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â  However, there are several cases in which 
  the trial judgeâ€™s admission of evidence under the common scheme or plan exception 
  was reversed after the appellate courts in South Carolina found that the similarities 
  between the charged and uncharged acts were insufficient to establish the existence 
  of such a plan or design.Â  See State v. Timmons, 327 S.C. 48, 
  53, 488 S.E.2d 323, 326 (1997) (â€œReviewing this list of similarities, we disagree 
  with the trial judge.Â  The only point of similarity with any merit is the alleged 
  similar clothing worn by the robbers.â€);Â  State v. Berry, 332 S.C. 214, 
  503 S.E.2d 770 (Ct. App. 1998) (cert. denied, June 24, 1999)Â  (reversing 
  the trial judgeâ€™s admission of the evidence under the common scheme or plan 
  exception after finding insufficient similarities between the separate attacks); 
  State v. Davenport, 321 S.C. 134, 467 S.E.2d 258 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œWe 
  cannot clearly perceive the connection between the [separate] acts based on 
  these criteria, and we therefore conclude [the witnessâ€™s] testimony should have 
  been excluded.â€).Â  Certainly, the factual determination as to whether the prior 
  assault occurred in this case is left to the discretion of the trial judge.Â  
  However, in light of these authorities, we believe the determination of whether 
  the facts surrounding that assault sufficiently evidence a common scheme or 
  plan is a question of law.Â  In Lyle, our supreme court stated:

Whether evidence 
  of other distinct crimes properly falls within any of the recognized exceptions 
  noted is often a difficult matter to determine.Â  The acid test is its logical 
  relevancy to the particular excepted purpose or purposes for which it is sought 
  to be introduced. . . . Whether the requisite degree of relevancy exists is 
  a judicial question to be resolved in the light of the consideration that the 
  inevitable tendency of such evidence is to raise a legally spurious presumption 
  of guilt in the minds of the jurors.Â  Hence, if the court does not clearly perceive 
  the connection between the extraneous criminal transaction and the crime charged, 
  that is, its logical relevancy, the accused should be given the benefit of the 
  doubt and the evidence should be rejected.

Lyle, 125 
  S.C. at 416-17, 118 S.E. at 807.
The trial 
  judge ruled the prior sexual assault on Jane was sufficiently similar to the 
  charged crimes to justify admitting evidence of the prior assault under the 
  common scheme or plan exception.Â  We hold this was error.Â  
1.Â  
  Common scheme or plan in sex crime cases
When 
  he ruled on the admissibility of the uncharged conduct, the trial judge expressly 
  relied on the reasoning in State v. McClellan, 283 S.C. 389, 323 S.E.2d 
  772 (1984), and State v. Weaverling, 337 S.C. 460, 523 S.E.2d 787 (Ct. 
  App. 1999).Â  These cases support the contention that the common scheme or plan 
  exception to Lyle is often satisfied in criminal sexual conduct cases 
  because the evidence tends to prove the defendants engaged in patterns of continuous 
  illicit conduct.Â  
In Weaverling, 
  the court stated, â€œ[t]he common scheme or plan exception â€˜is generally applied 
  in cases involving sexual crimes, where evidence of acts prior and subsequent 
  to the act charged in the indictment is held admissible as tending to show continued 
  illicit intercourse between the same parties.â€™â€Â  337 S.C. at 469, 523 S.E.2d 
  at 791 (quoting State v. Whitener, 28 S.C. 244, 265, 89 S.E.2d 701, 711 
  (1955)) (emphasis added).Â  In Weaverling, the defendant allegedly performed 
  fellatio on the same victim almost every time the two were together for a period 
  of five or six years.Â  The victim testified that he had been assaulted by the 
  defendant in excess of one hundred times.Â  This court found the defendantâ€™s 
  pattern of continuous sexual abuse satisfied the common scheme or plan exception.Â  
  Id. at 469, 523 S.E.2d at 791.Â  
Likewise, 
  in McClellan, the defendant repeatedly engaged in sexual misconduct with 
  each of his three daughters.Â  All of the assaults began around the girlsâ€™ twelfth 
  birthdays, the defendant always quoted Bible verses to the girls, and he always 
  gave the same excuses for his actions.Â  The trial judge found the evidence in 
  the case established a pattern of continuous illicit conduct, and admitted the 
  evidence under the common scheme or plan exception.Â  McClellan, 283 S.C. 
  at 392, 323 S.E.2d at 774.
We interpret 
  these cases to suggest that common scheme or plan evidence in criminal sexual 
  conduct cases will be admitted on a generalized basis only where there is a 
  pattern of continuous illicit conduct.Â  Sex crimes may be unique in this respect 
  because they commonly involve the same victims engaged in repeated incidents 
  occurring under very similar circumstances.Â  The reason for the general admissibility 
  of such evidence under these circumstances is self evident â€“ where there is 
  a pattern of continuous conduct shown, that pattern clearly supports the inference 
  of the existence of a common scheme or plan, thus bolstering the probability 
  that the charged act occurred in a similar fashion.Â  
However, 
  Weaverling and McClellan do not lower the bar for admissibility 
  under Lyle simply because sexual crimes are involved.Â  Regardless of 
  the nature of the charges facing the defendant, there must be evidence that 
  the defendant employed a common scheme or plan in the commission of the crimes.Â  
  Where there is a pattern of continuous misconduct, as commonly found in sex 
  crimes, that pattern supplies the necessary connection to support the existence 
  of a plan.Â  Presumably, this is so because the same evidence that establishes 
  the continuous nature of the assaults will generally suffice to prove the existence 
  of the common scheme or plan as well.Â  In Weaverling and McClellan, 
  the sheer volume of repeated occurrences, together with the close similarities 
  in the assaults, evidenced a pattern of continuous illicit conduct.Â  Accordingly, 
  these cases fall squarely within the plain meaning of common scheme or plan 
  evidence.Â  McClellan, 283 S.C. at 392, 323 S.E.2d at 774 (stating it 
  would be difficult to conceive of evidence more within the common scheme or 
  plan exception);Â  Weaverling, 337 at 469, 523 S.E.2d at 791 (stating 
  the pattern of sexual abuse represented â€œquintessential common scheme or plan 
  evidenceâ€).Â  
Weaverling 
  and McClellan involved longstanding histories of continuous abuse between 
  the same parties.Â  However, such is not necessary to find common scheme or plan 
  evidence.Â  For example, in Whitener, the defendant had nonconsensual 
  intercourse with the victim at a hotel room, left the scene with the victim, 
  and returned with the victim shortly thereafter to perform oral sex on her in 
  the same room.Â  In the Stateâ€™s prosecution for rape, the court allowed testimony 
  regarding the subsequent oral sex act on the basis that this uncharged act was 
  part of the same â€œcontinued illicit intercourse between the same parties.â€Â  
  Whitener, 228 S.C. at 265, 89 S.E.2d at 711.Â  The continuous nature of 
  the illicit conduct in Whitener is established by the fact that the separate 
  assaults occurred during the same series of continuous events on the day in 
  question.Â  The court found the evidence tended to â€œestablish a common scheme 
  or plan embracing the commission of two or more crimes so related to each other 
  that proof of one tend[ed] to establish the other[].â€Â  Id. (finding that 
  the oral sex act performed shortly after the rape was relevant to the proof 
  of the rape charge because it tended to explain the absence of spermatozoa on 
  the victim).
However, 
  the suggestion that common scheme or plan evidence will generally be admitted 
  in cases involving patterns of continuous misconduct is misleading.Â  The court 
  must still clearly perceive the same logical relevance of the extraneous acts 
  to the charged offense.Â  Where the evidence discloses a pattern of continuous 
  illicit conduct, as in Weaverling, for example, the logical relevance 
  is apparent and the evidence will generally be admitted.Â  In Whitener, 
  the uncharged act was logically relevant to the charged offense because both 
  acts arose from a single, continuous series of events, and proof of one act 
  tended to establish that the other had occurred.Â  
Here, 
  we are compelled to find there is no pattern of continuous illicit conduct similar 
  to that found in Weaverling and McClellan.Â  Therefore, we believe 
  the trial judge erred to the extent he based his ruling on the reasoning of 
  these cases.Â  Furthermore, Whitener does not reconcile the trial judgeâ€™s 
  reasoning because there is no continuous series of events tying the uncharged 
  act to the charged offenses in the present case.Â  To the extent we find there 
  is no continuous illicit conduct in this case, we do so only to distinguish 
  the present case from the authorities relied on by the trial judge.Â  It goes 
  without saying that the conduct need not be continuous to fall within the common 
  scheme or plan exception.Â  In this case, there is no continuous conduct, but 
  that fact, standing alone, does not preclude the existence of a scheme or plan.Â  
  Instead, the determination of the admissibility of the uncharged act rests solely 
  on whether the requisite degree of similarity between the separate acts is present 
  in this case.Â  Lyle, 125 S.C. at 416-17, 118 S.E. at 807; see also 
  State v. Rogers, 293 S.C. 505, 362 S.E.2d 7 (1987) (revâ€™d on other grounds 
  by State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993)) (refusing 
  to allow testimony regarding uncharged sexual intercourse under the common scheme 
  or plan exception where the charged assault involved only â€œtouchingâ€). 
2.Â  
  The logical relevance of Tuttonâ€™s uncharged acts
In this 
  case, as with many criminal sexual conduct cases, the question before the jury 
  is not whether the State has charged the correct person with the crime; instead, 
  the question is whether the charged crime actually occurred.Â  The purpose of 
  admitting evidence of other instances of sexual misconduct under the common 
  scheme or plan exception is to bolster the probability that the charged acts 
  occurred.Â  See 2 Wigmore on Evidence Â§ 304 (Chadborne rev. ed. 1979) 
  (stating that where the evidence is introduced to prove the existence of a plan, 
  the purpose â€œis to show (by probability) a precedent design which in turn is 
  to evidence (by probability) the doing of the act designed.â€).Â  Here, if the 
  evidence suggests Tuttonâ€™s prior abuse of Jane was part of an overall plan or 
  scheme devised by him to perpetuate the type of misconduct that occurred, it 
  is relevant to prove the charged assaults on Jane and Mary occurred.Â  Id.
Where 
  such a plan exists, the charged and uncharged acts represent individual achievements 
  of the purposes for which the plan was established. See 2 Wigmore, Â§ 
  304 (stating that where separate offenses are sufficiently similar, there is 
  an inference that they are manifestations of a common scheme or plan).Â  Accordingly, 
  the evidence in such cases speaks to the existence of the defendantâ€™s plan, 
  not to the defendantâ€™s character.Â  This is so because the jury is not asked 
  to draw an inference that the prior bad acts would evince the defendantâ€™s propensity 
  to commit the charged offenses; instead, the jury is asked to infer that the 
  defendant developed a criminal scheme and employed that scheme as probative 
  evidence that the charged acts occurred.Â  People v. Sabin, 614 N.W.2d 
  888, 900, n. 10 (Mich. 2000).Â  â€œThe logical relevance of the evidence is based 
  on the system, as shown through the similarities between the charged and uncharged 
  acts, rather than on [the] defendantâ€™s character, as shown by the uncharged 
  act.â€Â  Id.
For purposes 
  of analyzing evidence of prior misconduct under the common scheme or plan exception, 
  we believe it is crucial to distinguish similarities that merely link the two 
  crimes from those similarities that tend to paint the broader, more relevant 
  picture.Â  Where, for example, the similarities are used to prove only the defendantâ€™s 
  intent, very little is required because the charged act in such cases is assumed 
  done.Â  2 Wigmore, Â§ 304.Â  However, â€œwhere the very act is the object of proof, 
  and is desired to be inferred from a plan or system, the combination of common 
  features that will suggest a common plan as their explanation involves so much 
  higher a grade of similarity as to constitute a substantially new and distinct 
  test.â€ Id. Â â€œThe added element, then, must be, not merely a similarity 
  in the results, but such a concurrence of common features that the various 
  acts are normally to be explained as caused by a general plan of which they 
  are the individual manifestations.â€Â  Id. (emphasis in original).Â  
  
In this 
  case, there are similarities between the charged offenses and the prior alleged 
  assault.Â  First and foremost, the incidents involve the same parties.Â  Also, 
  both the prior uncharged assault on Jane and the charged offenses took place 
  while she and her sisters were staying at Tuttonâ€™s residence. [3]  
Importantly, 
  however, the separate offenses are dissimilar in several significant ways.Â  
  First, the uncharged assault on Jane is dissimilar in that it was more egregious 
  than the assaults for which Tutton was charged. In Rogers, the victim 
  and her sister both testified that the defendant had â€œtouchedâ€ them.Â  In addition, 
  the sister testified that the accused had sexual intercourse with her.Â  Our 
  supreme court held the testimony regarding the alleged intercourse was inadmissible.Â  
  The court stated, â€œEven if the common scheme exception would have permitted 
  the evidence of the prior touching, 
  [4]  the evidence of sexual intercourse would not have been within the scope 
  of the common scheme.Â  Its introduction was highly prejudicial.â€Â  Rogers, 
  293 S.C. at 507, 362 S.E.2d 8.Â  Likewise, we hold Janeâ€™s testimony regarding 
  the alleged incidents of oral sex is highly prejudicial in light of the nature 
  of the charged offenses.Â  See Weaverling, 337 S.C. at 468, 523 
  S.E.2d at 791 (stating that even if the evidence falls within a Lyle 
  exception, it must be excluded it if its probative value is substantially outweighed 
  by its prejudicial effect).
The dissimilarities 
  also include the fact that after the uncharged incident, Tutton allegedly threatened 
  Jane that she would be in trouble if she told anyone.Â  Neither girl received 
  a similar warning after the charged assaults.Â  In addition, unlike in the present 
  case, Tutton apparently attempted no other assaults against the others at the 
  time of the uncharged act.Â  Moreover, there was a substantial period of time 
  between the prior uncharged assault and the charged offenses. 
  [5] Â  The girls stayed with Tutton on several occasions during this interim, 
  apparently without incident.
When ruling on 
  the evidence, the trial judge expressed his initial concern about the substantial 
  gap in time between the incidents, but apparently put his concerns to rest in 
  light of his understanding that Tutton had moved away during the interim.Â  However, 
  the trial judge apparently based this ruling on incomplete facts â€“ it was more 
  than two years after the first incident occurred when Tutton moved away from 
  the neighborhood.Â  Significantly, the victims stayed with Tutton several times 
  during the period between the alleged assaults.Â  The fact that no other incidents 
  occurred during these interim visits weakens the Stateâ€™s contention that Tutton 
  acted pursuant to a plan of sexually assaulting the victims when they spent 
  the night at his house.Â  Certainly, it is not necessary that Tutton assaulted 
  the victims on every occasion to establish a common scheme or plan, but there 
  must be sufficient evidence connecting the overnight stays to the alleged assaults 
  to clearly indicate that a scheme or plan is in use.Â  
The balancing 
  of the similarities in cases concerning the admission of common scheme or plan 
  evidence is a difficult task.Â  While inferential leaps are at the heart of such 
  decisions, we are compelled to find that the similarities in this case are insufficient 
  to support the inference that Tutton employed a common scheme or plan to commit 
  the assaults alleged in this case.Â  As stated in Lyle, â€œif the court 
  does not clearly perceive the connection between the extraneous criminal transaction 
  and the crime charged, that is, its logical relevancy, the accused should be 
  given the benefit of the doubt and the evidence should be rejected.â€ Lyle, 
  125 S.C. at 417, 118 S.E. at 807; see also State v. Henry, 313 
  S.C. 106, 432 S.E.2d 489 (Ct. App. 1993) (cert. dismissed as improvidently 
  granted) (stating the defendant must be given the benefit of the doubt regarding 
  the introduction of common scheme testimony where the admissibility was a close 
  question). [6] Â  Because we do not clearly perceive 
  the required connection, we hold the trial judge erred by admitting Janeâ€™s testimony 
  about the uncharged assault under the common scheme or plan exception to Lyle. 
  
Moreover, we believe 
  the error in admitting this evidence was not harmless.Â  Whether the improper 
  introduction of evidence is harmless requires us to look at the other evidence 
  admitted at trial in order to determine whether the defendantâ€™s guilt is conclusively 
  established by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion could 
  be reached by the jury.Â  Berry, 332 S.C. at 220, 503 S.E.2d at 773.Â  
  Here, the evidence at trial consisted entirely of the victimsâ€™ accusations against 
  the defendant.Â  The defendant vehemently denied the accusations and the medical 
  evidence was inconclusive.Â  Considering this contested evidence and the fact 
  that the prior uncharged assault on Jane was more egregious than the charged 
  offenses, we cannot say that without this testimony, the evidence before the 
  jury was so overwhelming that a guilty verdict was the only rational conclusion.Â  
  Id.Â  at 221, 503 S.E.2d at 774.Â  Accordingly, we reverse Tuttonâ€™s conviction 
  and remand for a new trial.
 
  REVERSED.
GOOLSBY and SHULER, JJ., concur.
 

 
   [1] Â  Jane is approximately one year younger than Mary.

 
   
    [2]  The names of these three children have been changed in this opinion 
    to protect their identities.

 
   
    [3] Â Â  Regarding the charged offenses, there was detailed testimony as 
    to where the victims and Tutton were lying and as to how Tutton commenced 
    the assaults.Â  This evidence was completely lacking as to the prior uncharged 
    assault.Â  Accordingly, there is little to aid this court in finding that similar 
    tactics were employed by Tutton as to that incident. 

 
   
    [4] Â Â  We note the court also found insufficient similarities between 
    the charged and uncharged offenses.Â  Rogers, 293 S.C. at 507, 362 S.E.2d 
    at 8.Â  The only connection between the assaults, which were ten years apart, 
    is that the accused touched both of his daughters. Id. 

 
   
    [5] Â  Remoteness in time, however, is not dispositive.Â  State v. Blanton, 
    316 S.C. 31, 33, 446 S.E.2d 438, 440 (Ct. App. 1994) (cert. denied, 
    March 9 1995) (admitting testimony from sufficiently similar assaults that 
    occurred seven to eight years prior). 

 
   
    [6] Â  In Sabin, the Michigan Supreme Court gave deference to the 
    trial judgeâ€™s decision to admit the evidence because it believed reasonable 
    minds could differ on the issue of its admissibility in what it considered 
    to be a close case.Â  South Carolina does not follow this approach.Â  Lyle 
    demands that the defendant be given the benefit of the doubt where the connection 
    is not clearly perceived.Â  Lyle, 125 S.C. at 417, 118 S.E. at 
    807.Â  See also, Henry, 313 S.C. 106, 432 S.E.2d 489 (giving 
    the accused the benefit of the doubt where the admissibility of the evidence 
    is a close case).Â  In any event, we find the common features in Sabin, 
    especially the defendantâ€™s tactic of playing on the victimsâ€™ fears of breaking 
    up the family in order to silence them, far more compelling than in the instant 
    case. Â See Sabin, 614 N.W.2d at 901.

title: State v. Dunbar
description: In this criminal appeal, Dunbar argues the trial court erred in failing to suppress evidence based on two allegedly impermissible searches, one incident to his arrest, and the other pursuant to a search warrant.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Michael Dunbar, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3631
Heard September 11, 2002 â€“ Filed April 
  21, 2003

AFFIRMED IN PART AND
REVERSED IN PART 


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of 
  SC Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for respondent.
      
    
  


 CONNOR, J.:Â  Michael 
  Dunbar was indicted for trafficking in cocaine 100 to 200 grams, trafficking 
  in cocaine 200 to 400 grams, and trafficking in crack cocaine 200 to 400 grams.Â  
  A jury convicted Dunbar of all three charges. The trial court sentenced him 
  to concurrent twenty-five-year sentences for the trafficking in cocaine offenses, 
  and a consecutive fifteen-year sentence for trafficking in crack cocaine.Â  Dunbar 
  appeals, arguing the trial court erred in failing to suppress evidence obtained 
  as a result of two allegedly impermissible searches.Â  We affirm in part and 
  reverse in part.
FACTS
Acting on information from a confidential 
  informant, investigators from the Lexington County Sheriffâ€™s Department initiated 
  an undercover drug bust.Â  In Officer Rainwaterâ€™s presence, the informant contacted 
  Dunbar and another individual to set up a drug transaction.Â  The informant arranged 
  to purchase five ounces of cocaine.Â  The two men arrived in their car to meet 
  the informant and deliver the drugs at the pre-designated time and place.Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Police officers approached the car upon 
  receiving the informantâ€™s signal that drugs were present in the vehicle.Â  The 
  driver of the vehicle, Jonathan Small, fled on foot.Â  The defendant, Dunbar, 
  remained seated in the vehicle until the officers asked him to step out. Â The 
  officers searched the car and found a paper bag containing approximately five 
  ounces of cocaine.Â  The officers also noticed a hotel room key on the key chain 
  left in the carâ€™s ignition.Â  Dunbar informed Rainwater that he and Small were 
  staying at the Ramada Inn in West Columbia.Â  
Rainwater sought a warrant to search the 
  hotel room.Â  The search of the room turned up $3,795.00 in cash, digital scales, 
  a 9-millimeter pistol, powder cocaine, and crack cocaine.
Prior to trial, Dunbar moved to suppress 
  the evidence obtained as a result of the warrantless search of the car and the 
  search of the hotel room pursuant to the execution of the search warrant.Â  The 
  trial court denied Dunbarâ€™s motion to suppress the evidence.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â 
Warrantless 
  Search of Vehicle
Dunbar argues the trial court erred in 
  failing to suppress the cocaine found in the vehicle because it was obtained 
  as a result of an unreasonable warrantless search.
Generally, warrantless searches are per 
  se unreasonable unless an exception to the warrant requirement is present.Â  State v. Peters, 271 S.C. 498, 248 S.E.2d 475 (1978).Â  Recognized exceptions 
  to the warrant requirement include: (1) a search incident to a lawful arrest; 
  (2) â€œhot pursuitâ€; (3) stop and frisk; (4) automobile exceptions; (5) the â€œplain 
  viewâ€ doctrine; and (6) consent.Â  State v. Bailey, 276 S.C. 32, 274 S.E.2d 
  913 (1981).Â  Dunbar argues the warrantless search of the vehicle was not pursuant 
  to any of the possible exceptions.Â  
As noted, one possible exception to the 
  warrant requirement is a search incident to a lawful arrest.Â  Once probable 
  cause exists for an arrest,Â  â€œ[p]olice officers may make a search of an arresteeâ€™s 
  person and the area within his immediate control for weapons and destructible 
  evidence.â€Â  State v. Ferrell, 274 S.C. 401, 405, 266 S.E.2d 869, 871 
  (1980).Â  Dunbarâ€™s motion to suppress the evidence stated his â€œarrest was made 
  absent probable cause.â€ Thus, we focus on whether probable cause existed to 
  arrest Dunbar.
â€œThe fundamental question in determining 
  whether an arrest is lawful is whether there was â€˜probable causeâ€™ to make the 
  arrest.â€Â  Wortman v. City of Spartanburg, 310 S.C. 1, 4, 425 S.E.2d 18, 
  20 (1992).Â  Probable cause for an arrest â€œgenerally exists â€˜where the facts 
  and circumstances within the arresting officerâ€™s knowledge are sufficient for 
  a reasonable person to believe that a crime has been or is being committed by 
  the person to be arrested.â€™â€Â  State v. Moultrie, 316 S.C. 547, 552, 451 
  S.E.2d 34, 37 (Ct. App. 1994) (quoting United States v. Miller, 925 F.2d 
  695, 698 (4th Cir. 1991)).Â  Stated otherwise, â€œ[a] police officer has probable 
  cause to arrest without a warrant where he, â€˜in good faith, believes that a 
  person is guilty of a felony, and his belief rests on such grounds as would 
  induce an ordinarily prudent and cautious man, under the circumstances, to believe 
  likewise . . . .â€™â€Â  State v. Roper, 274 S.C. 14, 17, 260 S.E.2d 705, 
  706 (1979) (quoting State v. Swilling, 249 S.C. 541, 558, 155 S.E.2d 
  607, 617 (1967)). 
In determining whether probable cause 
  exists, â€œall the evidence within the arresting officerâ€™s knowledge may be considered, 
  including the details observed while responding to information received.â€Â  Roper, 
  274 S.C. at 17, 260 S.E.2d at 706; see Moultrie, 316 S.C. at 552, 
  451 S.E.2d at 37 (â€œIn assessing whether an officer has probable cause, the totality 
  of the circumstances surrounding the information at the officerâ€™s disposal must 
  be considered.â€). 
Here, the confidential informant told 
  Officer Rainwater he had previously purchased cocaine from two men who traveled 
  to Columbia from Florida.Â  The informant told Rainwater that he had dealt with 
  the two men on several occasions when they had been in the Columbia area.Â  The 
  informant agreed to set up a â€œstingâ€ operation in which these persons would 
  deliver cocaine to him at a gas station.Â  Rainwater met with the informant and 
  listened as the informant telephoned his drug sources 
  [1]  and requested that they deliver the drugs to him.Â  The informant told 
  Rainwater the men would be driving a blue Cadillac with wire rims.Â  Acting on 
  this information, the police set up surveillance and waited for the men to arrive 
  at the gas station.Â  The officers observed a blue Cadillac with wire rims drive 
  into the gas station.Â  They watched as the informant approached the car and 
  sat down in the back seat.Â  The informant then immediately exited the vehicle.Â  
  The informantâ€™s act of getting out of the car was the cue for the officers to 
  move in based on the presence of drugs in the car.Â  Based on these facts and 
  observations, Rainwater and the other surveilling officers then moved in to 
  arrest the carâ€™s occupants.Â  After removing Dunbar from the passenger seat, 
  Rainwater retrieved a bag of cocaine from the passenger-side floorboard.Â  
The informantâ€™s description of the vehicle 
  was corroborated when the informant approached the car immediately upon its 
  arrival at the gas station.Â  Moreover, Rainwater listened while the informant 
  called to arrange the drug transaction.Â  When viewed under the totality of the 
  circumstances, the information provided by the informant, together with Rainwaterâ€™s 
  observations and verification of the information, was sufficient to give rise 
  to probable cause that the occupants of the car were conducting a drug transaction, 
  and that drugs could be found in the car.Â  See Moultrie, 316 S.C. 
  at 552, 451 S.E.2d at 37-38 (recognizing the validity of warrantless arrests 
  based on an informantâ€™s tip where arresting officers conduct no independent 
  investigation and corroboration consists of nothing more than observing predictions 
  supplied by the tip); cf. Roper, 274 S.C. at 16-19, 260 S.E.2d 
  at 706-707 (finding probable cause existed to stop an automobile matching a 
  witnessâ€™s description of two black males driving a late model, green Thunderbird 
  with a red and white license tag bearing the letters â€œMVBâ€ or â€œMVFâ€); Peters, 
  271 S.C. at 504, 248 S.E.2d at 478 (finding an informantâ€™s tip that a yellow 
  Grand Prix with a white top and South Carolina tags bearing the digits â€œ308â€ 
  would be leaving Folly Beach shortly and transporting marijuana was sufficient 
  to constitute probable cause to stop the vehicle).Â  
Therefore, the warrantless arrest of Dunbar, 
  as well as the search incident to Dunbarâ€™s arrest, was proper.Â  The trial court 
  did not err in refusing to suppress the cocaine found inside the car.Â Â Â Â  
II. Validity of 
  Search Warrant
Dunbar argues the trial court erred in 
  failing to suppress the evidence obtained as a result of the search of the hotel 
  room.Â  Dunbar contends the affidavit is deficient and cannot form the basis 
  for a search warrant because the affiant admittedly had no direct knowledge 
  of numerous facts recited in the affidavit. 
After retrieving the cocaine from the 
  vehicle, Officer Rainwater noticed a hotel room key on the key chain left in 
  the carâ€™s ignition.Â  The key was inscribed with a room number.Â  Based on the 
  confidential informantâ€™s previous dealings with Dunbar, he knew Dunbar stayed 
  at a hotel while in Columbia.Â  The informant had alerted Rainwater to this fact 
  and told Rainwater to look for a hotel key.Â  Upon being asked, Dunbar informed 
  Rainwater that he and Small were staying at the Ramada Inn in West Columbia. 

Based on the seizure of the cocaine and the information 
  concerning the hotel room, Rainwater sought a warrant to search the room. Rainwater 
  telephoned the magistrate and discussed the probable cause to issue the search 
  warrant.Â  Rainwater did not, however, proceed to the magistrateâ€™s office to 
  obtain the warrant, but instead sent Officer Oâ€™Quinn. 
When Oâ€™Quinn arrived at the magistrateâ€™s office 
  the magistrate was on the telephone with Rainwater.Â  Oâ€™Quinn testified the magistrate 
  drafted the affidavit based on information received over the telephone from 
  Rainwater. [2] Â  Oâ€™Quinn stated 
  he â€œmerely signedâ€ the affidavit after reviewing it and did not offer any information 
  to the magistrate involving the probable cause for the search.Â  Oâ€™Quinn admitted 
  he had no â€œpersonal knowledgeâ€ of the facts contained in the affidavit other 
  than an awareness that five ounces of cocaine had been delivered to undercover 
  agents.Â  Oâ€™Quinn was stationed in a marked patrol car during the surveillance 
  of the gas station and testified that â€œit would not have been conducive for 
  me to be within a line of sight of the suspects or where the deal was taking 
  place.â€ Â Oâ€™Quinn did not speak with the confidential informant nor with Dunbar, 
  and was not present and did not observe Rainwater retrieve the cocaine from 
  the car.Â  There is no evidence the magistrate even inquired concerning Oâ€™Quinnâ€™s 
  knowledge of the facts stated in the affidavit.Â  Oâ€™Quinn stated the facts in 
  the affidavit came from â€œno place elseâ€ but Rainwater.Â  After signing the affidavit 
  and obtaining the search warrant, Oâ€™Quinn delivered the warrant to the officers 
  waiting at the hotel.Â  
In State v. Jones, 342 S.C. 121, 536 S.E.2d 
  675 (2000), our Supreme Court stated the constitutional and statutory requirements 
  for issuing a search warrant:

The General Assembly has imposed stricter requirements than 
  federal law for issuing a search warrant.Â  Both the Fourth Amendment of the 
  United States Constitution and Article I, Â§ 10 of the South Carolina Constitution 
  require an oath or affirmation before probable cause can be found by an officer 
  of the court, and a search warrant issued.Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV; S.C. Const. 
  art. I, Â§ 10.Â  Additionally, the South Carolina Code mandates that a search 
  warrant â€œshall be issued only upon affidavit sworn to before the magistrate, 
  municipal judicial officer, or judge of a court of record . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (1985).

Id. at 128, 536 S.E.2d at 678.Â  
â€œAn affidavit is a voluntary ex parte statement 
  reduced to writing and sworn to or affirmed before some person legally authorized 
  to administer an oath or affirmation.â€Â  State v. McKnight, 291 S.C. 110, 
  113, 352 S.E.2d 471, 472 (1987); see also Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 
  58 (7th ed. 1999) (defining an affidavit as a â€œvoluntary declaration of facts 
  written down and sworn to by the declarant before an officer authorized to administer 
  oathsâ€).Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In McKnight, our Supreme Court found a warrant 
  defective where a sworn officer orally recited facts upon which the warrant 
  was based but never executed an affidavit. 
  [3] Â  The Supreme Court found that such a sworn, oral statement may be sufficient 
  to satisfy constitutional requirements, but the statement would not satisfy 
  the statutory requirement of an affidavit.Â  McKnight, 291 S.C. at 113, 
  352 S.E.2d at 472.Â  McKnight required an affiant to execute a written 
  affidavit.Â  Similarly, in this case Officer Rainwater orally recited facts relating 
  to the probable cause for the warrant but did not execute an affidavit.Â  Instead, 
  Rainwater sent Oâ€™Quinn to sign an affidavit drafted by the magistrate.Â  
Under these facts, the statutory mandate requiring 
  that a search warrant be based on an affidavit was not met because the affiant 
  did not recite any of the facts stated in the affidavit and his direct personal 
  knowledge of the facts stated in the affidavit was limited to the delivery of 
  cocaine.Â  The affiant, Oâ€™Quinn, did not prepare an affidavit and the magistrateâ€™s 
  recitation of the facts in the affidavit was not verified by anyone known by 
  the magistrate to possess knowledge of the facts stated in the affidavit.Â  Because 
  Oâ€™Quinn had no direct personal knowledge of numerous facts, he could not have 
  sworn to the truth of the statements in the affidavit.Â  At oral argument, the 
  State explained Oâ€™Quinn was swearing that he believed the statements 
  in the affidavit were truthful.Â  The statutory affidavit requirement is not 
  met where one officer recites facts over the phone to a magistrate, the magistrate 
  drafts an affidavit, and subsequently an affiant who offers no facts establishing 
  probable cause signs the affidavit.Â  In essence, like McKnight, the magistrate 
  was never presented with an affidavit executed by the affiant.
This opinion in no way affects the validity of 
  search warrants issued through the use of hearsay.Â  See, e.g., State 
  v. Sullivan, 267 S.C. 610, 230 S.E.2d 621 (1976) (recognizing the validity 
  of an affiant attesting to information supplied him by a fellow officer).Â  Here, 
  there is no evidence Oâ€™Quinn repeated to the magistrate any facts he may have 
  obtained from other officers.Â  The dissent characterizes this as a hearsay case 
  and upholds the validity of the warrant based in part on Oâ€™Quinnâ€™s hearsay knowledge.Â  
  Even assuming in this case Oâ€™Quinn obtained knowledge as a result of hearsay, 
  it is of no consequence given Oâ€™Quinn did not relate any of this information 
  to the magistrate and did not present an affidavit.Â  
As the dissent correctly notes, an affidavit can 
  show probable cause even when based on hearsay.Â  Sullivan, 267 S.C. at 
  614, 230 S.E.2d at 623.Â  However, any probable cause established in the affidavit 
  here is not based on hearsay, it is based on oral statements by an officer who 
  did not present an affidavit. 
A search warrant affidavit insufficient in itself 
  to establish probable cause may be supplemented by sworn oral testimony.Â  Jones, 
  342 S.C. at 128, 536 S.E.2d at 678-679; McKnight, 291 S.C. at 113, 352 
  S.E.2d at 472.Â  â€œHowever, sworn oral testimony, standing alone, does not satisfy 
  the statute.â€Â  Id. at 113, 352 S.E.2d at 473.Â  Even if Rainwaterâ€™s telephone 
  conversation with the magistrate was under oath, Rainwater presented only sworn 
  oral testimony, not an affidavit.Â  The rule allowing supplementation presupposes 
  an affiant presented the magistrate with a written affidavit.Â  If not presented 
  with an affidavit, the magistrate is left to depend totally on oral information.Â  
  A magistrate cannot depend solely on oral testimony in issuing a search warrant.Â  
  Here, Rainwaterâ€™s oral statements to the magistrate did not supplement 
  an affidavit.Â  Rather, the magistrate used the statements to draft the affidavit 
  subsequently signed by an affiant who did not supply the magistrate with any 
  facts.Â  This procedure did not satisfy section 17-13-140.Â Â Â Â  
Accordingly, the trial court erred in refusing to 
  suppress the evidence obtained during the search of the hotel room.
CONCLUSION
The trial court properly admitted 
  the cocaine found in the car into evidence and we thus affirm Dunbarâ€™s conviction 
  for trafficking in cocaine of more than one hundred but less than two hundred 
  grams of cocaine.Â  The trial court erred in refusing to suppress the powder 
  and crack cocaine found in the hotel room and we therefore reverse Dunbarâ€™s 
  convictions for trafficking in cocaine of more than 200 grams and less than 
  400 grams, and trafficking in crack cocaine.
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART. 
STILWELL, J. concurs and ANDERSON, J. dissents in 
  a separate opinion.
 ANDERSON, J. (dissenting):Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  
  The majority concludes the trial court erred in failing to suppress the evidence 
  obtained as a result of the search of the motel room because the search warrant 
  was based on an affidavit signed by a law enforcement officer who had no direct 
  knowledge of the information contained in the affidavit.Â  I disagree.Â  I vote 
  to affirm.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  
  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001).Â  We are bound by 
  the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State 
  v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000).Â  This same standard 
  of review applies to preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility 
  of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d 
  at 829.Â  On review, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused 
  his discretion.Â  State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998); State 
  v. Rochester, 301 S.C. 196, 391 S.E.2d 244 (1990).Â  This Court does not 
  re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence 
  but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.Â 
Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829; see also State v. 
  Corey D., 339 S.C. 107, 529 S.E.2d 20 (2000) (an abuse of discretion is 
  a conclusion with no reasonable factual support).
An appellate court reviewing the decision to issue a search warrant 
  should decide whether the magistrate had a substantial basis for concluding 
  probable cause existed.Â  State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 561 S.E.2d 640 
  (Ct. App 2002).Â  This review, like the determination by the magistrate, is governed 
  by the â€œtotality of the circumstancesâ€ test.Â  State v. Jones, 342 S.C. 
  121, 536 S.E.2d 675 (2000); King, 349 S.C. at 148, 561 S.E.2d at 643.Â  
  The task of the issuing magistrate is simply to make a practical, common sense 
  decision whether, given all the circumstances set forth in the affidavit before 
  him, including the â€œveracityâ€ and â€œbasis of knowledgeâ€ of persons supplying 
  hearsay information, there is a fair probability that contraband or evidence 
  of a crime will be found in a particular place.Â  Illinois v. Gates, 462 
  U.S. 213, 103 S.Ct. 2317, 76 L.Ed.2d 527 (1983).Â  The appellate court should 
  give great deference to a magistrateâ€™s determination of probable cause.Â  State 
  v. Weston, 329 S.C. 287, 494 S.E.2d 801 (1997); see also State 
  v. Sullivan, 267 S.C. 610, 230 S.E.2d 621 (1976) (magistrateâ€™s determination 
  of probable cause should be paid great deference by reviewing court).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Requirement of Sworn Affidavit
â€œBoth the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution and Article I, 
  Â§ 10 of the South Carolina Constitution require an oath or affirmation before 
  probable cause can be found by an officer of the court, and a search warrant 
  issued.â€Â  State v. Jones, 342 S.C. 121, 128, 536 S.E.2d 675, 678 (2000).Â  
  Furthermore, the South Carolina Code mandates that a search warrant shall be 
  issued only upon affidavit sworn to before the magistrate, municipal judicial 
  officer, or judge of a court of record establishing the grounds for the warrant. 
  Id.; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (1985).Â  The purpose of the statute requiring 
  that a warrant be issued only upon affidavit is to provide for timely recording 
  of facts presented to a judicial officer.Â  State v. Sachs, 264 S.C. 541, 
  216 S.E.2d 501 (1975).
  II.  Sufficiency of Affidavit Supporting
Search Warrant
An affidavit in support of a search warrant may be based on hearsay information 
  and need not reflect the direct personal observations of the affiant.Â  State 
  v. Sullivan, 267 S.C. 610, 230 S.E.2d 621 (1976); see alsoÂ Â  Jones 
  v. United States, 362 U.S. 257, 80 S.Ct. 725, 4 L.Ed.2d 697 (1960), overruled 
  on other grounds by United States v. Salvucci, 448 U.S. 83, 100 S.Ct. 
  2547, 65 L.Ed.2d 619 (1980) (affidavit for search warrant which sets out personal 
  observations relating to existence of cause to search is not to be deemed insufficient 
  by virtue of fact that it sets out not the affiantâ€™s observations but those 
  of another, so long as a substantial basis for crediting the hearsay is presented).Â  
  An affidavit can show probable cause even when based on hearsay statements.Â  
  Sullivan, 267 S.C. at 614, 230 S.E.2d at 623;Â  see also Morris 
  v. State, 62 S.W.3d 817 (Tex. App. 2001) (information with which magistrate 
  is supplied, in affidavit for search warrant, may be hearsay).
Hearsay, even second hearsay, may provide a legal basis for a search warrant.Â  
  United States v. Welebir, 498 F.2d 346 (4th Cir. 1974); see also 
  State v. York, 250 S.C. 30, 156 S.E.2d 326 (1967) (affidavit for search 
  warrant may be based on hearsay information); State v. Elkhill, 715 So. 
  2d 327 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1998) (finding affidavit established probable cause 
  to search defendantâ€™s residence for drugs, even though affiant did not continuously 
  observe confidential informant during controlled buy; informant was under almost 
  constant supervision of one of two officers during buy, and what affiant did 
  not see, the other officer did; as long as specific facts are set forth to justify 
  finding of probable cause to issue search warrant, those facts may be based 
  on hearsay information).
The fact that the information provided is double hearsay is relevant to its 
  value in determining probable cause, but hearsay testimony will not per se invalidate 
  a judgeâ€™s determination of probable cause.Â  State v. Taylor, 612 N.E.2d 
  728 (Ohio Ct. App. 1992).Â  The fact that the affiantâ€™s knowledge may be the 
  result of double or multiple levels of hearsay does not, per se, invalidate 
  the resulting search warrant.Â  United States v. Jenkins, 525 F.2d 819 
  (6th Cir. 1975); see also United States v. One Hundred Forty-Nine 
  Thousand Four Hundred Forty-Two and 43/100 Dollars ($149,442.43) in U.S. Currency, 
  965 F.2d 868 (10th Cir. 1992) (hearsay, even multiple hearsay, may be used to 
  establish probable cause for a search warrant); United States v. McCoy, 
  478 F.2d 176 (10th Cir. 1973) (fact that affidavit in support of search warrant 
  contains some double hearsay and perhaps even a bit of triple hearsay does not 
  in and of itself render the affidavit insufficient).
The fact that there is hearsay upon hearsay involved in a case, as far as the 
  information upon which the affidavit is based, does not preclude a finding of 
  probable cause.Â  Lewis v. State, 508 S.E.2d 218 (Ga. Ct. App. 1998); 
  see also Hennessy v. State, 660 S.W.2d 87 (Tex. Crim. App. 1983) 
  (when viewing the affidavit, hearsay upon hearsay will support issuance of warrant 
  as long as underlying circumstances indicate there is a substantial basis for 
  crediting hearsay at each level).
III.Â  Direct Knowledge of Affiant Officer Not Required
The propriety of an affiant attesting to information supplied him by a fellow 
  officer has been judicially endorsed.Â  State v. Sullivan, 267 S.C. 610, 
  230 S.E.2d 621 (1976).Â  It is well settled that an affiant seeking a search 
  warrant can base his information on information in turn supplied him by fellow 
  officers.Â  United States v. Ventresca, 380 U.S. 102, 85 S.Ct. 741, 13 
  L.Ed.2d 684 (1965); United States v. Welebir, 498 F.2d 346 (4th Cir. 
  1974).Â  Observations by fellow law enforcement officers engaged in a common 
  investigation with the search warrant affiant are a reliable basis for a warrant 
  applied for by one of their number.Â  Ventresca, 380 U.S. at 111, 85 S.Ct. 
  at 747, 13 L.Ed.2d at 690; State v. Hage, 568 N.W.2d 741 (N.D. 1997).Â  
  See also United States v. Morales, 238 F.3d 952 (8th Cir. 2001) 
  (probable cause may be based on collective knowledge of all law enforcement 
  officers involved in an investigation and need not be based solely on information 
  within knowledge of officer on scene if there is some degree of communication).Â  

Probable cause is to be evaluated by the collective information of the police 
  as reflected in the affidavit and is not limited to the firsthand knowledge 
  of the officer who executes the affidavit.Â  State v. Stickelman, 299 
  N.W.2d 520 (Neb. 1980); see also Iddings v. State, 772 N.E.2d 
  1006 (Ind. Ct. App. 2002) (probable cause for a search warrant may be based 
  upon information known to the law enforcement organization as a whole).Â  A police 
  officer making the affidavit for issuance of a warrant may do so in reliance 
  upon information reported to him by other officers in the performance of their 
  duties.Â  State v. Pearson, 566 S.E.2d 50 (N.C. 2002).
It is not unusual for an affidavit of a law enforcement officer to contain 
  hearsay information from another, which, in turn, is based on other information 
  gathered by that person.Â  Sullivan, 267 S.C. at 615, 230 S.E.2d at 623.Â  
  Hence, when a magistrate receives an affidavit which contains hearsay upon hearsay, 
  he need not categorically reject this double hearsay information.Â  Sullivan, 
  267 S.C. at 615, 230 S.E.2d at 623.Â  Rather, he is called upon to evaluate this 
  information as well as all other information in the affidavit in order to determine 
  whether it can be reasonably inferred that the information was gained in a reliable 
  way.Â  Sullivan, 267 S.C. at 615, 230 S.E.2d at 623-24.
IV.Â  Efficacy of Affidavit in Present Case
The affidavit in the present case clearly justified the issuance of the warrant.Â  
  Officer Keith Oâ€™Quinn was â€œpart of the initial responding units for the take-down 
  of the operationâ€ and was at the scene of the arrest.Â  Oâ€™Quinn testified that 
  he had â€œpersonal knowledge . . . that a narcotics deal had been performed at 
  the Exxon station on Bush River Roadâ€ and that two subjects had been arrested.Â  
  Officer Oâ€™Quinn had knowledge there was cocaine in the car.Â  He declared that, 
  â€œ[b]ased on [his] conversation in dealing with Investigator Rainwater,â€ he obtained 
  a search warrant.Â  Oâ€™Quinn signed an affidavit based on information which was 
  obtained through a joint investigation.Â  When asked â€œ[w]as there a reason for 
  the belief contained in the affidavit that there was cocaine in Sheraton (sic) 
  room 158,â€ Officer Oâ€™Quinn responded: â€œFrom the information that I gathered 
  that was told to Investigator Rainwater by the C.I., yes, sir, there was.â€Â  
  Moreover, although Officer Rainwater actually communicated the information to 
  the magistrate, Officer Oâ€™Quinn read over and reviewed the affidavit for accuracy 
  before he signed it.
I find the affidavit was properly executed.Â  The affidavit included 
  information Officer Oâ€™Quinn learned through his participation in the investigation, 
  as well as hearsay information.Â  Thus, the affidavit justified the issuance 
  of the search warrant.Â  Under the totality of the circumstances, the magistrate 
  had a substantial basis for concluding probable cause existed.Â  I would affirm 
  the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow the evidence obtained as a result of the 
  search of the motel room.
CONCLUSION
The opinion of the majority acknowledges the viability of the rule 
  that hearsay is admissible to show probable cause.Â  This declaration rings hollow 
  because the majority opinion neglects to give any efficacy to the rule.
With etymological precision, the majority in cathartic verbiage concludes 
  the rule should not be applied.Â  The statement is made that the magistrate never 
  heard the â€œhearsay.â€Â  The record belies this averment.
The judicial embargo countenanced by the majority flies in the face 
  of the universal rule of evidence allowing â€œhearsay, even second hearsayâ€ to 
  determine probable cause in the magisterial warrant scenario.
Without question, the appellate entity will â€œrue the dayâ€ of the 
  â€œstatutory affidavit deficiencyâ€ rule adopted in this case.Â  This court-created 
  albatross in search warrant proceedings is anathema to the law extant in the 
  field of criminal law.
 I VOTE TO AFFIRM.

 
   
    [1]  Rainwater testified he was unaware at the time of the telephone conversation 
    whether the informant was speaking with the defendant, Dunbar, or with Jonathan 
    Small. Â 

 
   [2]  The affidavit stated:
  
  That a confidential informant 
    stated that the subject stays at motel while in the area, that Co Def stated 
    that the subject left Ramada Inn at I-26 [at] 378 after Co-Def called subject 
    in that room, that Co Def saw subject leave location to pick him up at location 
    across from Ramada, that subject had on his possession a key to said room, 
    that subject delivered approx. 5oz. of cocaine to undercover agents. 
  

 
   
    [3] Â Â  The record does not indicate Rainwater was sworn.Â  The magistrate 
    placed Oâ€™Quinn under oath before he signed the affidavit.Â  However, Oâ€™Quinn 
    was unaware whether Rainwater was under oath during the telephone conversation 
    with the magistrate.Â  See State v. York, 250 S.C. 30, 156 S.E.2d 
    326 (1967) (finding a sheriffâ€™s testimony that he had a â€œconversationâ€ with 
    a magistrate was insufficient to establish that the sheriff furnished information 
    under oath or affirmation).Â  Assuming, as we must, given the lack of evidence 
    on this point in the record, the magistrate did not place Rainwater under 
    oath, the search warrant issued in this case offends even the less stringent 
    constitutional standard requiring a search warrant be â€œsupported by oath or 
    affirmation.â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10; see also 
    State v. Wimbush, 9 S.C. 309 (1877) (finding a warrant illegal where 
    the information on which the warrant was founded was not given upon oath).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Raul H. Aragon, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3632
Submitted January 29, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  21, 2003 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John J. Stathakis, of Anderson; for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson 
  and Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson; for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Raul H. Aragon appeals his 
  convictions for 1) simple assault and battery and 2) assault and battery of 
  a high and aggravated nature.Â  His appeal focuses entirely upon the admission 
  by the trial court of a taped conversation between him and one of the victims.Â  
  We affirm. [1] 
Aragon assaulted two women one evening.Â  
  He admitted he slapped one of them.Â  That victim, however, complained of a more 
  extensive assault upon her.Â  She stated that Aragon, among other things, smashed 
  her head against a door jamb, rammed a chair into her stomach, dragged her from 
  her bedroom into the kitchen, and made her plead for her life while threatening 
  to stab her.Â  
Following the assault and at the request of the 
  investigating officer, the victim called Aragon from the sheriffâ€™s office and 
  engaged him in a taped conversation.Â  The solicitorâ€™s office took custody of 
  the tape after the victim reviewed it.Â  The State introduced the tape into evidence.Â  
  Aragon argues the State failed to properly authenticate the tape because the 
  State did not establish a chain of custody.Â  
We think the State, consistent with the 
  requirements of Rule 901, SCRE, [2] 
   regarding authentication, sufficiently established that the tape in question 
  is what it claimed.Â  The victim who made the call to Aragon testified that she 
  had known him for over ten years and once had a relationship with him, that 
  she telephoned Aragon from the sheriffâ€™s office and knew the conversation was 
  taped, that she listened to the tape, that she recognized the tape from her 
  initials on it, that the tape fairly and accurately represented the phone conversation, 
  and that the tape had not been edited or altered in any way. [3] Â  
As for establishing a chain of custody, 
  that was not necessary since the tape was otherwise authenticated. [4] 
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and SHULER, J., concur.
 

 
   [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2] Â  
    Rule 901, SCRE, provides as follows:
  
  (a)Â  General Provision.Â  The requirement of authentication 
    or identification as a condition precedent to admissibility is satisfied by 
    evidence sufficient to support a finding that the matter in question is what 
    its proponent claims.
  (b)Â  Illustrations.Â  By way of illustration only, and 
    not by way of limitation, the following are examples of authentication or 
    identification conforming with the requirements of this rule:
    
  (1)Â  Testimony of Witness With Knowledge.Â  Testimony 
    that a matter is what it is claimed to be.
  . . .
  (5)Â  Voice Identification.Â  Identification of a voice, 
    whether heard firsthand or through mechanical or electronic transmission or 
    recording, by opinion based upon hearing the voice at any time under circumstances 
    connecting it with the alleged speaker.Â  
    
  

 
   [3] Â  After the tape was admitted and published, the 
    victim further testified she knew her conversation was held with Aragon because 
    she dialed his number and she recognized his voice.Â  See Rule 901(b)(6), 
    SCRE (stating that an example of authentication regarding telephone conversations 
    may include â€œevidence that a call was made to the number assigned at the time 
    by the telephone company to a particular person or business. . . .â€).Â  At 
    no point in his testimony did Aragon challenge the genuineness of the tape 
    or in any way suggest the tape had been tampered with.Â  Indeed, he seemed 
    to embrace the correctness of the tape, saying when questioned about its contents, 
    â€œWhat I said on the tape you heard it.Â  Itâ€™s all on the tape.â€ 

 
   [4] Â  See United States v. Tropeano, 
    252 F.3d 653 (2d Cir. 2001) (holding that a chain of custody need not be established 
    where the witnesses had first-hand knowledge of conversations and identified 
    the voices on the tape); McCollum v. State, 582 N.E.2d 804 (Ind. 1991) 
    (holding that a chain of custody need not be established where a participant 
    in a conversation listened to the tape the night before and testified the 
    tape was a true and accurate recording of the conversation).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Loren John Murphy, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
NationsBank, N.A., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3633
Submitted February 20, 2003 - Filed 
  April 28, 2003Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James J. Raman, of Spartanburg; for Appellant.
Donald E. Rothwell and Scott L. Hood, both of Irmo; for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Loren John Murphy appeals from a 
  circuit court order denying his request for a witness fee and mileage for attending 
  a deposition in an action in which Murphy was the plaintiff.Â  Murphy contends 
  the circuit court erred because a party who testifies at a deposition is a witness 
  entitled to the witness fee and mileage pursuant to Rule 30(a)(2), SCRCP.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In 1984, Murphy executed a Money Line Agreement 
  with NationsBank in order to obtain a $25,000.00 revolving line of credit. 
  Murphy defaulted on his repayment obligation to NationsBank, and in 1993, 
  the bank agreed to accept a lump sum payment from him in full satisfaction of 
  the account. NationsBank continued to report the account as charged off to consumer 
  credit reporting agencies.Â  Murphy commenced this action against NationsBank 
  in 1999, seeking actual and punitive damages because of the bankâ€™s action in 
  allegedly filing a false credit report about Murphy.Â  NationsBank answered, 
  denying liability and asserting numerous defenses, among them that the credit 
  information provided by it concerning Murphy was true.Â  
During the course of the lawsuit, NationsBank noticed 
  the deposition of Murphy.Â  Counsel for Murphy then notified NationsBank that 
  Murphy expected to receive a witness fee of $25.00 and mileage, for a total 
  of $29.14.Â  NationsBank then filed a notice of motion and motion to enforce 
  discovery.Â  On June 28, 2001, a hearing on NationsBankâ€™s motion was heard before 
  the Honorable John C. Hayes, III.Â Â  Judge Hayes ruled that a party such as Murphy 
  was not entitled to the witness fee and mileage under Rule 30(a)(2), and compelled 
  Murphy to appear for his deposition. Thereafter, by order dated February 1, 
  2002, the Honorable Donald W. Beatty granted summary judgment to NationsBank 
  based on the statute of limitations. Murphy appeals Judge Hayesâ€™ decision 
  to deny him the witness fee and mileage.Â  
DISCUSSION
Rule 30(a)(2), SCRCP, sets forth certain limitations 
  on depositions.Â  The first paragraph of the subsection provides: â€œA witness 
  (excluding a party) may be compelled to attend only in the county in which 
  he resides or is employed or transacts his business in person, or at such other 
  convenient place as is fixed by an order of the court.â€ (Emphasis added.)Â  The 
  second paragraph states:Â  â€œThe deposition of any party or witness may 
  only be taken one time in any case except by agreement of the parties through 
  their counsel or by order of the court for good cause shown.â€ (Emphasis added.)Â  
  The third paragraph of the subsection, which is the one at issue here, provides: 


A witness attending any deposition held pursuant 
  to these rules shall receive for each dayâ€™s attendance and for the time necessarily 
  occupied in going to and returning from the same, $25.00 per day, and mileage 
  for going from and returning to his place of residence, in the same amounts 
  as provided by law for official travel of state officers and employees. 

(Emphasis added.)
Â Judge Hayes, in ruling that Murphy, as a party, 
  was not entitled to the witness fee and mileage, noted that Rule 30(a)(2) accorded 
  different status to witnesses and parties.Â  Murphy, however, relied upon the 
  case of Perry v. Minit Saver Food Stores of South Carolina, Inc., 255 
  S.C. 42, 177 S.E.2d 4 (1970), for the proposition that a party who testifies 
  at a deposition is a witness and is entitled to the witness fee and mileage.Â  
  This 1970 decision is the basis for the truncated argument in Murphyâ€™s brief.Â  

We agree with Judge Hayes that Rule 30(a)(2), SCRCP, 
  clearly treats witnesses and parties differently.Â  The first paragraph of the 
  subsection deals with witnesses and specifically excludes parties.Â  The second 
  subsection, by its language, applies to both parties and witnesses, and 
  the third paragraph, which is applicable here, is limited to â€œa witness 
  attending any deposition.â€Â  (emphasis added)Â  By its plain language, the paragraph 
  of the subsection concerning witness fees and mileage applies only to witnesses.Â  
  The Perry case relied on by Murphy is inapposite because it pre-dates 
  the adoption of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  See Sunamerica 
  Finâ€™l Corp. v. Equi-Data, Inc., 299 S.C. 175, 177, 383 S.E.2d 8, 9 (1989) 
  (holding that cases decided prior to the adoption of the South Carolina Rules 
  of Civil Procedure are inapplicable when deciding an issue involving construction 
  of a rule).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., CURETON and GOOLSBY, JJ., concur.
