THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Margaret Murray, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Bank of America, N.A., formerly known as NationsBank, N.A.,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Donald W. Beatty, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3634
Submitted February 10, 2003 - Filed 
  April 28, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William S. Brown, Christine M. Harrington, of Greenville; 
  for Appellant.
Patrick E. Knie, of Spartanburg; for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â  Margaret Murray sued Bank of 
  America, formerly known as NationsBank, (Bank) alleging it was negligent when 
  it allowed an imposter to open an account in her name.Â  The jury awarded Murray 
  $300,000 in actual damages.Â  The Bank appeals.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
Margaret Murray lost her driverâ€™s license 
  in May 1997.Â  On May 14, 1997, a woman opened an account with the Bank in Murrayâ€™s 
  name.Â  The imposter presented Murrayâ€™s driverâ€™s license and a social security 
  card to the Bank employee and deposited $100.00 in the account.Â  The employee 
  contacted Check Systems, which is a company that verifies credit, to determine 
  if Murray had any prior check writing problems.Â  Check Systems did not reveal 
  any detrimental information about Murray.Â  The imposter wrote sixty fraudulent 
  checks from the account totaling approximately $7,500.Â  
Murray had never had a checking account 
  with the Bank or any other bank.Â  Murray did not become aware of the account 
  opened in her name until employees of Thermax Carpet Cleaning came to her apartment 
  and asked for her to return a rented carpet cleaner.Â  When Murray went to Thermax, 
  the manager established that she was not the one who rented the cleaner.Â  The 
  manager told Murray that the cleaner had been rented by someone writing a check 
  in her name with the account at the Bank.Â  
On June 2, 1997, Murray went to the Bank and discovered 
  an imposter had opened the account in her name using her driverâ€™s license.Â  
  Murray demanded the Bank close the account.Â  She also requested the Bank inform 
  the merchants who submitted the checks that were returned for insufficient funds 
  that she was innocent and that this was a fraudulent account.Â  She testified 
  that she trusted the Bank to take the requested actions.Â  The Bank, however, 
  failed to close the account until June 30, 1997.Â  Murray also reported the fraudulent 
  account to the police.Â  
In November 1997, Murray was arrested 
  in front of her son, and served with warrants for fifteen fraudulent checks.Â  
  Murray spent twelve hours in jail.Â  After Murray was arrested, she obtained 
  a letter from the Bank stating she was not the one who opened the account.Â  
  Murray went to the post office box the imposter provided the bank and found 
  forty-four letters merchants had written her about the bad checks.Â  
Murray was required to appear at three 
  criminal court hearings.Â  Although she was exonerated of the criminal charges 
  she faced, Murray continued to worry about the existence of other unresolved 
  checks.Â  She suffered from stress and anxiety from the incident and had difficulty 
  sleeping.Â  Her face tightened and became numb.Â  She sought medical treatment 
  from the local hospital.Â  Murray was embarrassed by being arrested in front 
  of her son and her neighbors and felt she had to move into another apartment, 
  which was more expensive than the one she had lived in before.Â  
Murray sued the Bank in negligence.Â  The 
  Bank moved for directed verdict at the close of Murrayâ€™s case asserting the 
  Bank did not owe any duty of care to Murray.Â  The trial court denied the motion.Â  
  The jury found for Murray and awarded her $300,000 in damages.Â  The trial court 
  denied the Bankâ€™s post trial motions.Â  The Bank appealed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Existence of a Duty of CareÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The Bank asserts the trial court erred when it 
  denied the Bankâ€™s directed verdict motion.Â  We disagree.
In ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the 
  trial court must view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be 
  drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motion.Â  
  Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 336 S.C. 
  373, 386, 520 S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999).Â  The trial court must deny the motions 
  when the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  
  Id.Â  The appellate courts will reverse the trial court only when there 
  is no evidence to support the ruling below or the ruling is controlled by an 
  error of law.Â  Id. 
In order to establish a claim for negligence 
  the plaintiff must prove the following elements:Â  1) a duty of care owed by 
  the defendant to the plaintiff; 2) a breach of that duty by the defendantâ€™s 
  negligent act or omission; 3) the plaintiff was damaged; and 4) the damages 
  proximately resulted from the breach of the duty.Â  Thomasko v. Poole, 
  349 S.C. 7, 11, 561 S.E.2d 597, 599 (2002).Â  â€œAn essential element in a cause 
  of action for negligence is the existence of a legal duty of care owed by the 
  defendant to the plaintiff.â€Â  Bishop v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 
  331 S.C. 79, 86, 502 S.E.2d 76, 81 (1998).Â  The issue of whether the law recognizes 
  a particular duty is an issue of law to be decided by the court.Â  Ellis by 
  Ellis v. Niles, 324 S.C. 223, 479 S.E.2d 47 (1996).
Duty is generally defined as â€œthe obligation to 
  conform to a particular standard of conduct toward another.â€Â  Shipes v. Piggly 
  Wiggly St. Andrews 269 S.C. 479, 483, 238 S.E.2d 167, 168 (1977).Â  Ordinarily, 
  the common law imposes no duty on a person to act.Â  Carson v. Adgar, 
  326 S.C. 212, 486 S.E.2d 3 (1997).Â  An affirmative legal duty to act exists 
  if created by statute, contract, relationship, status, property interest, or 
  some other special circumstance.Â  Id.Â  
On June 2, Murray went to the Bank and spoke with 
  Thomas Wright, a former vice-president and banking center manager with the Bank.Â  
  She testified that she requested the Bank close the fraudulent account and notify 
  the merchants who submitted checks written on the account that the account was 
  fraudulent.Â  When she left, she felt assured that the Bank would handle the 
  matter.Â  Wright testified he notified the Bankâ€™s headquarters in Charlotte on 
  May 21, 1997 that the account was overdrawn and requested its closure.Â  The 
  Bank did not close the account until June 30, 1997, which was almost a month 
  after Murray requested it close the account and notify the merchants.Â  Wright 
  stated the Bank failed to follow its own procedures.Â  
We find a relationship between the Bank and Murray 
  arose sufficient to impose upon the Bank a duty of care when Murray went to 
  the Bank seeking closure of the account.Â  The Bank failed to follow its own 
  procedures, did not timely close the account, and did not notify any merchants 
  that the account was fraudulent.Â  We find sufficient evidence in the record 
  from which the jury could determine the Bank breached its duty to Murray after 
  this duty arose.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not err in denying 
  the Bankâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  
II.Â  New trial absolute
The Bank argues the trial court erred 
  in denying its motion for a new trial absolute as the jury verdict was so large 
  it must have been the result of caprice, prejudice, or passion.Â  We disagree. 

The trial courtâ€™s decision to deny a 
  motion for new trial absolute is within its discretion and will not be reversed 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Cock-N-Bull Steak House, Inc. v. Generali 
  Ins. Co., 321 S.C. 1, 466 S.E.2d 727 (1996).Â  When deciding a motion to 
  grant a new trial, the court must look at the testimony and inferences raised 
  in favor of the nonmoving party.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 536 
  S.E.2d 408, 420 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The court should only grant a motion for a 
  new trial absolute when the verdict is so grossly excessive that it shocks the 
  conscience of the court and clearly indicates the verdict was the result of 
  caprice, passion, prejudice, partiality, corruption, or other improper motive.Â  
  Knoke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Parks, Recreation & Tourism, 324 
  S.C. 136, 141, 478 S.E.2d 256, 258 (1996).Â  A juryâ€™s determination of damages 
  is entitled to substantial deference by this court.Â  Id.Â  Mere undue 
  liberality on the part of the jury does not warrant an inference that the verdict 
  resulted from caprice, passion, prejudice, or other improper motives.Â  Hutson 
  v. Cummins Carolinas, Inc. 280 S.C. 552, 559, 314 S.E.2d 19, 24 (Ct. App. 
  1984). 
Murray was arrested in front of her son 
  and taken to the police car in front of her neighbors, causing her great humiliation.Â  
  She spent twelve hours in jail.Â  Although Murray suffers from a kidney ailment, 
  the jail attendant refused to allow her to use the bathroom, increasing her 
  embarrassment and discomfort.Â  Due to her stress over the situation, Murray 
  suffered from sleeplessness.Â  In addition, her face tightened up and became 
  numb, prompting a visit to the doctor.Â  She had to hire a lawyer and attend 
  three hearings on the warrants.Â  She stated that after her arrest, she was terrified 
  that the police would come back and arrest her again on more charges.Â  Due to 
  her acute embarrassment of being arrested in front of her neighbors, she moved 
  to a more expensive apartment, which strained her finances and caused more stress.Â  

Most of the damages Murray suffered were 
  intangible.Â  â€œOne cannot easily or with any mathematical certainty place a value 
  on the amount of a personâ€™s pain and suffering.â€Â  Smalls v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Educ., 339 S.C. 208, 218, 528 S.E.2d 682, 687 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
  We find the juryâ€™s verdict of $300,000 is not so shocking to the conscience 
  of the court that it clearly indicates the verdict was the result of improper 
  motive.Â  Thus, we hold the trial court did not err in denying the Bankâ€™s motion 
  for a new trial absolute.Â  
III.Â  Supplemental jury instructionÂ Â  
The Bank argues the trial court committed 
  reversible error by giving supplemental jury instructions.
After it began deliberations, the jury 
  requested additional instructions from the trial court on actual damages.Â  The 
  court repeated its earlier charge on actual damages.Â  After the jury left the 
  courtroom, Murrayâ€™s attorney suggested the jury may have been wondering what 
  can be considered as elements of actual damages.Â  The court agreed.Â  The Bank 
  objected to the court giving an additional charge, asserting the courtâ€™s original 
  charge was a fair statement of the law and Murray had waived any objection by 
  failing to object after the original charge.Â  Over the Bankâ€™s objection, the 
  court charged the jury:

Okay let me talk to you a little bit about [actual damages].Â  
  Mental anguish, pain and suffering, loss of [t]he enjoyment of life, meaning 
  not being able to do the kinds of things you normally did or you did prior to 
  the incident, embarrassment.Â  Those kinds are things that can be considered 
  as actual damages.Â  Youâ€™re not limited to medical bills, that kind of thing, 
  in determining actual damages.Â  

On appeal, the Bank first argues Murray 
  waived the right to complain about the courtâ€™s charge on actual damages.Â  It 
  relies on Lundy v. Lititz Mutual Insurance Company, 232 S.C. 1, 100 S.E.2d 
  544 (1957), in which the supreme court stated:

At the conclusion of the main charge, the trial Judge . . 
  . excused the jury and asked counsel if any further instructions were desired 
  or if there were any objections to the charge.Â  No objection was offered by 
  either party but appellantâ€™s counsel requested an additional instruction relating 
  to a certain phase of the case.Â  The jury was then recalled and the requested 
  instruction given.Â  After doing so, the Court gave certain other instructions 
  which appellant now contends constituted a charge on the facts.Â  However, in 
  the main charge, . . . the Court gave substantially the same instructions as 
  those now complained of.Â  If appellant thought these instructions violated Article 
  5, Section 26 of the Constitution, which we are inclined to think they did, 
  counsel should have made timely objection when the jury was excused at the conclusion 
  of the main charge.Â  They waived the objection by failing to do so.Â  Appellant 
  cannot now complain of the Court's repeating substantially the same instructions 
  to which counsel failed to object when given an opportunity to do so.

Id. at 10, 100 S.E.2d at 548.Â Â Â Â  
It is certainly true that an appellant 
  who failed to object to a jury charge at the first opportunity cannot complain 
  about the charge on appeal.Â  However, that appellate rule of error preservation 
  does not prevent the trial court from supplementing its charge if it decides 
  to do so.Â  
The Bank also argues the trial court 
  erred in giving the supplemental charge because it emphasized the recoverability 
  of damages for mental distress.Â  The Bank, however, did not raise this objection 
  to the trial court when it gave the supplemental charge.Â  Accordingly, we find 
  this argument is not preserved for our review.Â  State v. Benton, 338 
  S.C. 151, 526 S.E.2d 228 (2000) (stating issue not preserved if party argues 
  one ground for objection at trial and a different ground on appeal).
IV.Â  Statements in closing argument.Â  
The Bank argues Murrayâ€™s counsel made 
  improper remarks to the jury during his closing.Â  We find no reversible error.Â  

The Bank first contends Murrayâ€™s counsel attempted to appeal 
  to the sympathy of the jury by asking them to put themselves in Murrayâ€™s place.Â  
  During the closing, Murrayâ€™s counsel stated, â€œAnd on November 25th, 
  1997, some four or five months later, thereâ€™s an officer at her door, and just 
  put yourself in your home, in your home---.â€Â  The Bankâ€™s attorney objected.
The following colloquy then occurred:

The Court:Â  Mr. Knie (Murrayâ€™s attorney).
Mr. Knie: Okay.
Mr. Brown (the Bankâ€™s attorney):Â  Thatâ€™s improper.
The Court:Â  Rephrase that, sir.
Mr. Knie:Â  Just try to imagine the---
Mr. Brown:Â  Again, Your Honor, heâ€™s asking them to imagine being 
  in that same position.Â  Itâ€™s improper.
The Court:Â  Mr. Knie.
Mr. Knie:Â  All right.Â  Iâ€™ll do my best, Your Honor.

Although the trial court did not use 
  the word â€œsustain,â€ it is obvious that the court sustained the Bankâ€™s attorneyâ€™s 
  objection.Â  The Bankâ€™s attorney failed to ask the trial court to strike the 
  statement or give the jury a curative instruction.Â  We find the Bankâ€™s argument 
  complaining about Murrayâ€™s attorneyâ€™s comments is not properly before this court.Â  
  See State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 18, 482 S.E.2d 760, 766 (1997) 
  (holding the alleged impropriety of closing argument was not preserved for review 
  where the trial court sustained an objection by opposing counsel, but counsel 
  did not move to strike or request a curative instruction).Â  
The Bank also argues that during his 
  closing argument Murrayâ€™s counsel improperly sought the jury to make a judgment 
  regarding questions of law.Â  During the closing, the following colloquy occurred:

MR. KNIE:Â  I asked for permission to publish what [the Bankâ€™s] 
  net worth was, and obviously it was met with objection as you could well imagine.
MR. BROWN:Â  Iâ€™m gonna object to that.Â  Itâ€™s for the Court 
  to decide objections.Â  Itâ€™s not for counsel to make comments about objections.Â  

THE COURT:Â  Iâ€™m going to overrule the objection.Â  But Mr. 
  Knie, youâ€™re treading on thin ice.

We find any error in the trial court 
  overruling the Bankâ€™s objection to this testimony harmless.Â  See GTE 
  Sprint Communications Corp. v. Public Serv. Commâ€™n of S.C., 288 S.C. 174, 
  181, 341 S.E.2d 126, 129 (1986) (stating that where a party shows no prejudice, 
  the error, if any, is harmless).
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing reasons, the juryâ€™s verdict in favor of Murray 
  isÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED.
CONNOR and ANDERSON, J.J., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
LaQuinces Delvecchio Davis, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3635
Heard February 13, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  28, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Appellate Defender Daniel T. Stacey and Deputy Chief 
  Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz of SC Office of Appellate Defense, both 
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia;Â  and 
  SolicitorÂ  Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 HOWARD, J.: LaQuinces Delvecchio 
  Davis appeals his convictions for trafficking in crack cocaine and possession 
  of marijuana, arguing the search warrant which led to the discovery of the illegal 
  drugs was not based on probable cause and arguing the underlying search warrant 
  affidavit was defective because it contained false information and did not include 
  allegedly exculpatory information.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On July 13, 2000, Officer Brian Evans of the York 
  County Multijurisdictional Drug Enforcement Unit received two calls from an 
  anonymous informant stating a person known as â€œQâ€ was driving an older model 
  Chevrolet, ice-blue or black in color with a broken front grill, and was selling 
  crack cocaine in the Green Street area of Rock Hill.Â  The informant provided 
  a license plate number for the vehicle. 
Officer Evans recognized the nickname â€œQâ€ as Davisâ€™ 
  street name and knew Davis had a prior conviction involving crack cocaine.Â  
  A check of South Carolina motor vehicle records revealed that the vehicle described 
  by the informant was registered to Davisâ€™ mother and that the license plate 
  was suspended for failure to pay insurance.Â  Officer Evans went to the area 
  where the informant indicated Davis was selling drugs, but was unable to locate 
  Davis or the vehicle. 
The same informant called again the next day, reporting 
  that â€œQâ€ had left the Ramada Inn motel in Rock Hill and was headed to Green 
  Street with crack cocaine to sell.Â  In response, police surveilled Green Street 
  looking for Davis.Â  They spotted the vehicle described by the informant being 
  driven near Green Street, at which time one of the officers turned on his blue 
  lights to initiate a traffic stop.Â  The vehicle accelerated, ran a stop sign, 
  and attempted to evade the police for several blocks.Â  Davis, the lone occupant, 
  jumped from the moving vehicle and ran.Â  The unguided vehicle crashed into two 
  parked cars.Â  Shortly thereafter, Davis was apprehended and arrested for failure 
  to stop for a blue light.Â  He told police he had run because he had smoked marijuana 
  shortly before his arrest. 
In a search of Davis incident to his arrest, the 
  police found $156.00 in cash, a pager, and a motel key card.Â  Davis stated the 
  motel key card belonged to a motel room in Orangeburg in which he had stayed 
  the night before.Â  Davis repeatedly denied the key card belonged to a motel 
  room in Rock Hill.Â  Notwithstanding his denials, police confirmed that a â€œQuincy 
  Davisâ€ was registered as a guest at the Rock Hill Ramada Inn motel and that 
  the key card fit the door of the motel room. 
Police obtained a search warrant for the room from 
  the local magistrate based upon the following affidavit, supplemented with oral 
  sworn testimony:

Affidavit for Search Warrant
Attachment #1 Ramada Inn 911 Riverview Rd. Room 227 Rock Hill, 
  S.C.
The affiant, a sworn police officer with the York County Multijurisdictional 
  Drug Enforcement Unit, with over 20 years of narcotic experience, states the 
  following facts to support probable cause to search the premises listed within.
On July 13, 2000, Officer Brian Evans of the York County Multijurisdictional 
  Drug Enforcement Unit received information that â€œQâ€ was selling crack in the 
  Green St. area of Rock Hill.Â  The source stated that â€œQâ€ was in an old ice blue 
  or ice black Chevrolet and gave Officer Evans the vehicleâ€™s license number.Â  
  The source stated that â€œQâ€ does not have a driverâ€™s license.Â  The tag came back 
  to Rosa Hinton, which is the mother of Quincy Davis.Â  Also the printout indicated 
  the tag was suspended.Â  Officers have personal knowledge that Quincy Davis is 
  known as â€œQâ€ and has convictions for selling crack.Â  Officer Evans was unable 
  to locate the vehicle.
On July 13, 2000, Officer Evans received a second call that 
  â€œQâ€ was back on Green St. in a yard and selling crack.Â  Officer Evans responded 
  and was unable to locate Davis.
On July 14, 2000, Officer Evans received a call from the same 
  source that â€œQâ€ was leaving the Ramada Inn in Rock Hill going to Green St. and 
  that â€œQâ€ had crack to sell.Â  Officer Evans went to the area and observed the 
  vehicle on Lucky Ln. traveling towards Whitgreen St. towards Green St.Â  Officer 
  Evans attempted a traffic stop and the vehicle accelerated failing to stop for 
  the police blue light.Â  The vehicle drove in a reckless manner speeding and 
  failed to stop for stop signs.Â  The driver then jumped from the vehicle while 
  moving and the vehicle struck two parked vehicles.Â  The driver fled on foot 
  and was caught a short distance away and identified as Quincy Davis.Â  Search 
  incident to arrest revealed a Ramada Inn Motel Key Card in Davisâ€™ pants pocket.Â  
  Davis stated that he spent the night in the Ramada Inn in Orangeburg and kept 
  the motel key.Â  Officers of the DEU went to the Ramada Inn on Riverview Rd. 
  in Rock Hill and the key matched a room registered to Davis.Â  Davis was asked 
  to sign a consent form to search the room and Davis denied completely and fully 
  that he has a motel room in Rock Hill.Â  Davis was asked 3 times and each time 
  he denied having a room.Â  Davis refused to sign the consent stating that it 
  is not his room.Â  Davis stated that he ran because he had smoked marijuana.Â  
  Record check revealed in fact that Davis has been convicted of selling crack 
  in the past and narcotic officers of the DEU have received information from 
  sources recently that Quincy Davis is selling crack in the Rock Hill area.
Based on past narcotic investigations it is common that drug 
  dealers secrete contraband and proceeds of drug sales in motel rooms. 

In a subsequent search of the room, police found 
  32.44 grams of crack cocaine, 23.54 grams of marijuana, and drug paraphernalia.Â  

In a pretrial suppression hearing, Davis argued 
  the evidence found in the motel room should be excluded.Â  Davis asserted the 
  only corroborated information was his identity, and under the authority of Florida 
  v. J.L., 529 U.S. 266 (2000), the search was not based upon probable cause. 

The court denied the motion to suppress, concluding 
  the affidavit, as orally supplemented, provided probable cause for the issuance 
  of the search warrant.Â  At trial, Davis was convicted of trafficking in crack 
  cocaine, failure to stop for a blue light, and possession of marijuana.Â  Davis 
  was sentenced to thirty years for trafficking crack cocaine, five years for 
  failure to stop for a blue light, and one year for possession of marijuana, 
  with the sentences to run concurrently.Â  
Davis appeals his convictions for trafficking in 
  crack cocaine and possession of marijuana.Â  In his appeal, Davis makes the same 
  argument as he made at the suppression hearing.Â  He also contends the drugs 
  should have been suppressed because the affidavit stated the attesting officer 
  had personal knowledge of Davisâ€™ prior conviction for selling crack cocaine, 
  when in fact, his prior conviction was only for possession of crack cocaine.Â  
  Davis contends the affiantâ€™s personal verification of information later determined 
  to be incorrect provides evidence that this false information was intentionally 
  or recklessly conveyed to the magistrate, rendering the warrant defective under 
  a Franks v. Delaware [1]  analysis.Â  In addition, Davis 
  argues the affidavit was defective because it did not inform the magistrate 
  of the exculpatory fact that Davis had no drugs in his possession when he was 
  arrested, contrary to the assertions of the informant.
ISSUES PRESENTED

  
    
       1.)
       Did the magistrate err 
  in issuing the search warrant because it was not based on probable cause to 
  believe contraband would be found in the motel room?
    
    
       2.) 
      
  Was the incorrect information concerning Davisâ€™ prior criminal record intentionally 
  or recklessly presented to the magistrate, rendering the search warrant defective?
      
    
    
       3.) 
       Did the omission of the fact that no drugs were found in Davisâ€™ possession 
  at the time of arrest constitute exculpatory information that was intentionally 
  or recklessly withheld from the magistrate, rendering the search warrant defective?
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The duty of a reviewing court is to 
  decide whether â€œthe magistrate had a substantial basis for concluding that probable 
  cause existed.â€ Illinois v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213, 238-39 (1983) (internal 
  quotations omitted); State v. Bellamy, 336 S.C. 140, 144, 519 S.E.2d 
  347, 349 (1999) (adopting the Gates standard of review).Â  â€œA reviewing 
  court should give great deference to a magistrateâ€™s determination of probable 
  cause.â€ State v. Weston, 329 S.C. 287, 290, 494 S.E.2d 801, 802 (1997); 
  see Gates, 462 U.S. at 236 (holding the Fourth Amendment evidences 
  a â€œstrong preference for searches conducted pursuant to a warrantâ€).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Totality of 
  the Circumstances
Davis argues the magistrate should not have issued the search 
  warrant because it was not based on probable cause.Â  We disagree.
A magistrate may issue a warrant only upon a finding of probable 
  cause. Bellamy, 336 S.C. at 143, 519 S.E.2d at 348.Â  A probable cause 
  determination requires the magistrate to analyze the totality of the circumstances, 
  meaning he should â€œmake a practical, common-sense decision whether, given all 
  the circumstances set forth in the affidavit before him, . . . there is a fair 
  probability that contraband or evidence of a crime will be found in a particular 
  place.â€Â  Gates, 462 U.S. at 238; see State v. Johnson, 
  302 S.C. 243, 247-48, 395 S.E.2d 167, 169 (1990) (adopting the Gates 
  totality-of-circumstances test); State v. Crane, 296 S.C. 336, 338-39, 
  372 S.E.2d 587, 588-89 (1988) (holding the magistrate should determine probable 
  cause based on all the information available to him at the time the warrant 
  is issued, including sworn oral testimony); State v. Adams, 291 S.C. 
  132, 133-34, 352 S.E.2d 483, 485 (1987) (â€œA determination of probable cause 
  depends upon the totality of the circumstances.â€).
In this case, a police officer received three phone calls 
  over a two-day period from an anonymous informant stating that Davis was selling 
  illegal drugs.Â  In each of the phone calls, the informant referred to the suspect 
  as â€œQ.â€Â  The officer knew from personal knowledge that Davis was known by the 
  street name â€œQâ€ and that Davis had a drug-related conviction.Â  Thus, the informantâ€™s 
  information was corroborated by the knowledge and prior experience of the police 
  officer. See United States v. Harris, 403 U.S. 573, 583 (1971) 
  (holding â€œa policemanâ€™s knowledge of a suspectâ€™s reputation . . . is . . . a 
  â€˜practical consideration of everyday lifeâ€™ upon which an officer (or a magistrate) 
  may properly relyâ€ (single quotation marks and parentheses as in original)); 
  cf. State v. Dupree, 319 S.C. 454, 459, 462 S.E.2d 279, 282 (1995) 
  (â€œThe â€˜experience of a police officer is a factor to be considered in the determination 
  of probable cause.â€™â€ (quoting United States v. Fisher, 702 F.2d 372, 
  378 (2d Cir. 1983))).Â  
The informant also stated Davis was driving a late model 
  Chevrolet, ice blue or black in color, with a broken front grill.Â  The description 
  included the license plate number.Â  By checking the license plate number provided, 
  the police independently verified that Davisâ€™ mother owned a vehicle fitting 
  the description given by the informant, further corroborating the informantâ€™s 
  information. See Gates, 462 U.S. at 244 (â€œBecause an informant 
  is right about some things, he is more probably right about other facts, including 
  the claim regarding . . . illegal activity.â€ (internal quotation marks and internal 
  citation omitted)).Â  
It is true that this corroboration only verified the identity 
  of â€œQâ€ and his otherwise legal activity of driving an ice blue or black Chevrolet.Â  
  Absent further information, we agree the analysis in Florida v. J.L., 
  529 U.S. 266 (2000), would be implicated.Â  In J.L., the police received 
  an anonymous tip that a suspect fitting a certain description would be standing 
  at a certain location and would be in possession of a firearm. Id. at 
  271.Â  After verifying the suspectâ€™s description and location, the police approached 
  the suspect and frisked him. Id. at 268.Â  The frisk was held to have 
  violated the suspectâ€™s Fourth Amendment rights because the tip was not â€œreliable 
  in its assertion of illegality,â€ and the police had no basis for the frisk other 
  than the tip.Â  Id. at 271-72.Â  However, in contrast to J.L., the 
  independent investigation by police in this case revealed the vehicleâ€™s license 
  plate was suspended for failure to pay insurance.Â  This provided a basis for 
  a traffic stop once the police observed Davis driving the vehicle.Â  Thus, J.L. 
  is not controlling.
Shortly before police stopped Davis for driving with a suspended 
  license plate, the informant made his last phone call to police in which he 
  stated that Davis had left a Rock Hill Ramada Inn motel room and was headed 
  to Green Street with drugs to sell.Â  According to the affidavit, the attesting 
  officer was a twenty-year veteran of the narcotics unit who knew from his experience 
  that drugs and proceeds of drug sales are often kept in motel rooms.Â  Notwithstanding 
  Davisâ€™ argument to the contrary, the law is well settled that the officerâ€™s 
  knowledge of general trends in criminal behavior is a relevant consideration 
  in determining probable cause. See Gates, 462 U.S. at 243 (holding 
  defendantâ€™s trip to Florida provided part of the basis for probable cause to 
  issue a warrant to search defendantâ€™s vehicle and house for drugs because police 
  work has shown that â€œFlorida is well-known as a source of narcotics and other 
  illegal drugsâ€).
When a police officer observed Davis driving the vehicle 
  with the suspended license plate towards the area where the informant stated 
  Davis intended to sell drugs, the officer initiated a traffic stop.Â  Based upon 
  the status of the vehicleâ€™s suspended license plate this stop was proper, a 
  point not contested by Davis in this appeal.Â  After the officer turned on his 
  blue lights, Davis tried to evade police by accelerating, running through a 
  stop sign, jumping and running from the moving vehicle.Â  After being arrested 
  for failure to stop for a blue light, Davis admitted he ran from police because 
  he had smoked marijuana earlier in the day.Â  This information was imparted to 
  the magistrate, and under well-settled law allows a reasonable inference of 
  guilty conduct. See State v. Ballenger, 322 S.C. 196, 200, 470 
  S.E.2d 851, 854 (1996) (holding defendantâ€™s flight from police was â€œat least 
  some evidence of guiltâ€).Â  
In the search of Davis incident to his arrest, police found 
  a Ramada Inn motel key card in Davisâ€™ pocket which he denied opened a room in 
  the Rock Hill Ramada Inn.Â  Davis repeatedly denied the key card belonged to 
  the Rock Hill motel room, even after he was told the key card fit the door of 
  the Rock Hill motel room.Â  The independent verification of the identity of the 
  key card further corroborated the informantâ€™s information, and Davisâ€™ subterfuge 
  provided a reasonable inference that something was located in the room which 
  he did not want police to discover. See Gates, 462 U.S. at 241 
  (â€œOur decisions applying the totality of the circumstances analysis . . . have 
  consistently recognized the value of corroboration of details of an informantâ€™s 
  tip by independent police work.â€); cf. State v. Bultron, 318 S.C. 
  323, 333, 457 S.E.2d 616, 622 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding defendantâ€™s suspicious 
  activity was part of the basis for finding that probable cause existed for a 
  search).Â  
The magistrate based his decision to issue the warrant to 
  search the motel room on the affidavit and oral sworn testimony of the officer 
  which detailed the information provided by the informant, the police work conducted 
  as a result of the informantâ€™s tips, the personal knowledge of the police officer, 
  the fact that Davis engaged in the independent illegal act of driving a vehicle 
  with a suspended license plate, and the suspicious conduct engaged in by Davis.Â  
  Thus, the magistrate had a substantial basis for concluding probable cause existed. 
  See Gates, 462 U.S. at 241-46 (upholding the issuance of a warrant 
  to search for drugs based on an anonymous letter that outlined detailed travel 
  plans of husband and wife, police corroboration of the coupleâ€™s activities, 
  and informantâ€™s allegation that couple was engaged in drug trafficking); cf. 
  State v. McLaughlin, 307 S.C. 19, 22, 413 S.E.2d 819, 821 (1992) (holding 
  probable cause to search a toolbox was established by defendantâ€™s suspicious 
  behavior, his possession of large amounts of cash, the presence of a marijuana 
  cigarette, and his repeated denials of ownership of the toolbox).
II. Veracity of 
  the Warrant Affidavit
Davis next argues the magistrate should not have issued the 
  search warrant because the warrant affidavit included false information and
